Accounting.title: Accounting Principles I
Accounting.description: Introduction to basic principles, concepts, and theoretical framework of financial accounting with the emphasis on its use by economically rational decision makers. Topics include the decision-making environment and the accounting cycles, processes, and statements.

Accounting.title: Accounting Principles II
Accounting.description: Emphasizes the role of accounting information within a firm. Topics include budgeting, responsibility accounting, cost allocations, cost behavior, decision models, capital budgeting, and an introduction to product costing in manufacturing and service sector firms. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000

Accounting.title: Intermediate Accounting I
Accounting.description: Studies the theory, concepts, and practices underlying financial reporting and measurement. Primary focus is on income measurement, and the valuation of assets, like cash, receivables, inventory, and long-lived assets, as well as multinational issues. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000

Accounting.title: Intermediate Accounting II
Accounting.description: A continuation of ACC 3000 with theories, concepts, and practices underlying financial measurement and reporting. Focuses on the measurement and reporting of liabilities and equities, and includes multinational issues. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 3000 and FIN 3000(C)

Accounting.title: Managerial/Cost Accounting I
Accounting.description: The primary emphasis is on traditional and contemporary product costing techniques, cost allocation practices, and basic cost-management issues. Topics include process costing, standard costing, activity- based costing, backflush costing, cost allocation issues, balanced scorecard, strategic profitability analysis, and the role of accounting in contemporary management practices. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2100 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 1

Accounting.title: Foundations of Taxation
Accounting.description: Introduction to basic principles, concepts, and theoretical framework of taxation systems, emphasizing income taxation and its impact on decision making. Topics include tax planning and compliance for individuals, corporations, and partnerships. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000

Accounting.title: Accounting Data Analytics
Accounting.description: Develop knowledge and competencies in data analytic techniques to generate accounting information used for business intelligence. Applied exercises with software tools are used to cover topics including data preparation, analysis, visualization, and scenario analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000 and ACC 3000(C)

Accounting.title: Audit and Assurance
Accounting.description: Auditing procedures and techniques associated with public accounting and with internal auditing for business entities. Topics include auditor's responsibilities, professional ethics, generally accepted auditing standards, purpose and types of audits, objectives, internal control, evidence, organization within the public accounting profession, the audit program, and auditing procedures and techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 3000 or ACC 5050

Accounting.title: Accounting Theory
Accounting.description: The course will focus on the advanced theories of financial accounting. It identifies the conceptual framework of financial reporting and emphasis on the "how" of accounting. Topics include information asymmetry, Bayesian decision theory, efficient market hypotheses, efficient contracting, positive accounting theories, executive compensation, and earning management. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 3000

Accounting.title: Managerial/Cost Accounting II
Accounting.description: Emphasizes information requirements of contemporary management decision-making and strategic- planning processes. Covers contemporary control and evaluation practices (such as activity-based management), determining the costs of quality, and productivity analysis in the context of accounting information systems. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 2

Accounting.title: Advanced Tax Topics
Accounting.description: Continuation of ACC3600. Introduction to advanced principles and concepts of taxation, emphasizing income taxation and its impact on decision making. Topics include tax planning and compliance for estates and trusts, gratuitous transfers, multi-jurisdictional operations, and entity formations, liquidations, and reorganizations. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 3600

Accounting.title: Governmental and Not-for-Profit Accounting
Accounting.description: An in-depth study of the accounting principles and financial reporting unique to the governmental and not- for-profit sectors of the U.S. economy. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 3000

Accounting.title: Accounting Systems
Accounting.description: Introduction to the basic principles, concepts, and theoretical framework for the design and operation of accounting information systems, emphasizing its use to enhance decision making. Topics include system design, internal controls, the use of databases, and electronic commerce. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2100 or ACC 5050

Accounting.title: Special Topics in Accounting
Accounting.description: Examines current issues in Accounting and other topics of interest to faculty and students in greater depth. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 3000 Air Force ROTC

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Air Force ROTC.title: Physical Conditioning
Air Force ROTC.description: Activities that promote physical conditioning. Emphasis is on individual conditioning through strength and aerobic training and team sports such as ultimate frisbee and football. May be used once as a general education co-curricular course. Sports physical required prior to start of class (contact instructor for details). Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 3

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Air Force ROTC.title: Air Force Elite Forces Workout
Air Force ROTC.description: An intense workout program that develops personal physical fitness and self-confidence. Workouts include an elite U.S. Military special operations training. Basic swimming skills required. Pre-Requisite(s): AF 0120

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Air Force ROTC.title: Precision Drill Team
Air Force ROTC.description: Techniques and skills involved in precision drill movements, including marching, rifle spinning, ceremonial sabre handling, and color guard performance. Each student must have or purchase an appropriate drill-team uniform. May be used once as a general education co-curricular course. Non- cadets are required to provide a uniform cleaning deposit and purchase some non-returnable uniform items.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Air Force ROTC.title: Field Training
Air Force ROTC.description: A rigorous program of physical conditioning, team activities, and survival training. Offered the summer semester after acceptance into the Field Training program. Course completed off campus. Pre-Requisite(s): AF 2002

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Air Force ROTC.title: US Air Force Heritage and Values I
Air Force ROTC.description: Introduction to the USAF and ROTC. Topics include Air Force mission and organization, officership, professionalism, military customs and courtesies, officer opportunities, and communication skills. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and provides cadets with followership experiences.

Air Force ROTC.title: US Air Force Heritage and Values II
Air Force ROTC.description: Introduces students to the USAF and ROTC. Topics include Air Force operations and installations, evolution of USAF, principles of war and tenets of Airpower, ethical decision making under pressure and what our Air Force 'brings to the fight'. Leadership lab is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and provides cadet with followership and leadership experiences. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 4

Air Force ROTC.title: Team and Leadership Fundamentals I
Air Force ROTC.description: Introduction to team building and leadership development. Topics include effective listening, followership, and problem solving and motivation techniques for creating a successful workplace.

Air Force ROTC.title: Team and Leadership Fundamentals II
Air Force ROTC.description: Advanced concepts for developing team and leadership abilities. Topics include human relations, conflict management, stress management and resiliency and the importance of ethical decision making in the workplace. Pre-Requisite(s): AF 2001

Air Force ROTC.title: Leading People and Effective Communication I
Air Force ROTC.description: Study and practice of leadership in civilian and military organizations, with emphasis on development of effective oral and wirtten communication. Topics include Air Force leader development, effective supervision, diversity, cross-cultural competence and ethics. The course includes discussion, informal lecture, case studies, self-evaluation of leadership traits, and experiential exercises.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Air Force ROTC.title: Leading People and Effective Communication II
Air Force ROTC.description: Study of leadership in civilian and military institutions. Topics include leadership theory, mentoring, feedback, organizational climate, and professionalism. The course includes discussion, informal lecture, case studies, and experiental exercises.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Air Force ROTC.title: National Security/Leadership Responsibilities/Commissioning Preparation I
Air Force ROTC.description: This course is designed to develop an understanding of the nature of conflict and how the United States military forces are developed, organized, and employed. Topics include the need for national security, the evolution and formulation of American defense policy and strategy, the origins of regional security issues, cross cultural competence, and joint doctrine. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 5

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Air Force ROTC.title: National Security/Leadership Responsibilities/Commissioning Preparation II
Air Force ROTC.description: This course examines selected roles of the military in society, unconventional warfare, current issues affecting the military profession, and the military justice system. Special topics of interest focus on information warfare, the law of armed conflict, the military as a profession, and officership. Army ROTC

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Army ROTC.title: Introduction to the Army and Critical Thinking
Army ROTC.description: Introduces cadets to the competencies that are critical for effective leadership. Cadets learn how the personal development of "life skills" such as critical thinking, time management, goal setting, stress management, and comprehensive fitness relate to the Army profession.

Army ROTC.title: Leadership and Competence
Army ROTC.description: Introduces Cadets to the competencies that are critical for adaptive leadership. Cadets learn the basics of the communication process and the importance of developing the essential skills to effectively communicate in the Army. Students will examine the Army profession in depth.

Army ROTC.title: Basic Leadership Lab I
Army ROTC.description: Practicum in basic military topics such as drill and ceremony, emergency preparedness, survival skills, and military communication. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights training at Fort MCoy in late September.

Army ROTC.title: Basic Leadership Lab II
Army ROTC.description: Practicum in basic military topics such as first aid, teambuilding, orienteering, profession of arms, and ethics in problem solving. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort MCoy in April and 1 Saturday in March.

Army ROTC.title: Leadership and Ethics
Army ROTC.description: Explores the dimensions of creative tactical leadership styles by examining team dynamics and historical leadership theories that form the basis of the Army leadership framework. Aspects of motivation and team building are practiced through planning, executing, and assessing team exercises. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 6

Army ROTC.title: Army Doctrine and Decision Making
Army ROTC.description: Examines the challenges of leading teams in complex operational environments. The course highlights terrain analysis, patrolling, and operation orders. Cadets develop greater self-awareness as they assess their own leadership styles and practice communication and team building skills.

Army ROTC.title: Intermediate Leadership Lab I
Army ROTC.description: Practicum in basic military topics, such as drill and ceremony, emergency preparedness, survival skills, and military communication. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort McCoy in late September.

Army ROTC.title: Intermediate Leadership Lab II
Army ROTC.description: Practicum in basic military topics, such as first aid, teambuilding, orienteering, profession of arms, and ethics in problem solving. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort McCoy in April and 1 Saturday in March.

Army ROTC.title: Fall Military Physical Conditioning
Army ROTC.description: Develops physical fitness, personal confidence, self-esteem and military skills. Students are exposed to both individual and group physical fitness procedures and techniques. Emphasis is on developing a good fitness program for each individual student. May be used once as a general education co- curricular course.

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Army ROTC.title: Spring Military Physical Conditioning
Army ROTC.description: Develops physical fitness, personal confidence, self-esteem and military skills. Students are exposed to both individual and group physical fitness procedures and techniques. Emphasis is on developing a good fitness program for each individual student. May be used once as a general education co- curricular course.

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Army ROTC.title: Warfighting Functions
Army ROTC.description: Teaches cadets to plan, coordinate, navigate, motivate, and lead a squad and platoon in the execution Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 7 of mission during a classroom PE, a leadership lab, or during a leader training course. Co-Requisite(s): AR 3011

Army ROTC.title: Leadership and Operations
Army ROTC.description: Cadets will study, practice, and apply the fundamentals of Army leadership, officership, Army value and ethics, personal development, and small unit tactics at the platoon level. Co-Requisite(s): AR 3012 Pre-Requisite(s): AR 3001

Army ROTC.title: Advanced Leadership Lab I
Army ROTC.description: Practicum in basic military topics, such as drill and ceremony, emergency preparedness, survival skills, and military communication. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort McCoy in late September. Co-Requisite(s): AR 3001

Army ROTC.title: Advanced Leadership Lab II
Army ROTC.description: Practicum in basic military topics, such as first aid, teambuilding, orienteering, profession of arms, and ethics in problem solving. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort McCoy in April and 1 Saturday in March. Co-Requisite(s): AR 3002 Pre-Requisite(s): AR 3011

Army ROTC.title: Military Physical Leadership I
Army ROTC.description: Develops a cadet's leadership abilities to design, implement, and assess a platoon level Army physical training program. Cadets learn the basic leadership of designing and developing a physical conditioning program. May be used once as a general education co-curricular course. Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): AR 2068 and AR 2069

Army ROTC.title: Military Physical Leadership II
Army ROTC.description: Develops a cadet's leadership abilities to design, implement, and assess a platoon level Army physical Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 8 training program. Cadets improve their small group's level of physical conditioning while honing their own leadership skills. May be used once as a general education co-curricular course. Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): AR 3068

Army ROTC.title: Mission Command I and the Army Profession
Army ROTC.description: Completes the Cadet to commissioned officer transition. Course stresses mission command and ethics to assist the Cadet in further embracing their role as an Army officer. Co-Requisite(s): AR 4011 Pre-Requisite(s): AR 3001 and AR 3002

Army ROTC.title: Mission Command II and the Company Grade Officer
Army ROTC.description: Course will teach critical knowledge, skills, abilities, and competencies that newly commissioned officers will need to succeed in their first unit of assignment. Cadets will examine the Army profession in depth. Co-Requisite(s): AR 4012 Pre-Requisite(s): AR 3001 and AR 3002

Army ROTC.title: Battalion Staff Operations I
Army ROTC.description: Develops personal confidence and advanced leadership ability using basic and advanced military skills. Students are given responsibility for planning and controlling the activities of the cadet battalion. Applied creativity, problem solving, decision making, and leadership are the cornerstones of this course. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort McCoy in late September. Co-Requisite(s): AR 4001

Army ROTC.title: Battalion Staff Operations II
Army ROTC.description: Develops personal confidence and advanced leadership ability using basic and advanced military skills. Students are given responsibility for planning and controlling the activities of the cadet battalion. Applied creativity, problem solving, decision making, and leadership are the cornerstones of this course. This course will require 4 days, 3 nights, training at Fort McCoy in April and 1 Saturday in March. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 9 Co-Requisite(s): AR 4004

Army ROTC.title: Special Topics Leadership Development
Army ROTC.description: Study and discussion of topics in Military Leadership not included in regular undergraduate courses. This course will require the support of one weekend training event up to 3 nights, 4 days, in length such as: Fall Field and Tactical Exercise, Ranger Challenge, or Super Lab. Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Army ROTC.title: Leadership Development
Army ROTC.description: Study and discussion of Military Leadership. This course will require the support of one weekend training event up to 3 nights, 4 days, in length such as: Spring Field and Tactical Exercise, Ranger Buddy, or Super Lab. Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Art

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; May not be enrolled in one of the following

Art.title: Art Appreciation
Art.description: Introduces students to analytical tools to critically observe the visual world. By studying arts media, artists and designers, creative and technical processes, principles of design, as well as major works of art, students will express their own ideas about the visual experience in written and visual form.

Art.title: Drawing I
Art.description: Exploration of fundamental principles of drawing. Develop skills in representational drawing, perspective, and composition. Develop creative and modern drawing techniques using a wide range of subject matter. Presentations and discussions illustrate classic principles. Course encourages development of individual expression.

Art.title: Art + Design Studio
Art.description: Introduction to art and design. Explores design principles and creative problem solving using multiple materials. Students also examine design's ability to shape and interpret information. Hands-on studio work, lectures, and discussions. Emphasizes creativity, inventiveness, and experimentation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 10

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Art.title: Drawing II
Art.description: Observational and imaginative drawing including the human figure and abstraction techniques. Contemporary drawing systems, concepts, and processes. Emphasis is on proportion, structural framework, visual measurement, movement, and relationships. Students work in a variety of drawing media. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2050 or FA 2150 or FA 2190 or FA 2300 or ART 1100 or ART 1110 or ART 1110 or ART 2130 or ART 2190

Art.title: Art on Site
Art.description: An introductory arts class focused on making works of art outdoors. Classes meet on the Michigan Tech trails or other outdoor locations. Students develop their own works of art and their own creative language. Includes conversations, local field trips, studio work, lectures, and readings.

Art.title: Creative Drawing Processes
Art.description: Students redefine "drawing" through a range of exercises using materials such as pencils, ink, and photo. Practice drawing as you closely observe objects such as fruit and flora, interpret music, and visualize data you collect on your daily activities.

Art.title: Ceramics I
Art.description: Introduces hand building ceramic techniques, including coil, slab, and pinch. The goal is to allow students to be individually creative through experimenting with the possibilities in three-dimensional form. Historical, contemporary, functional and sculpture processes will be explored.

Art.title: Beginning Wheel Throwing
Art.description: Students will learn the fundamental techniques of using a pottery wheel, as a tool, to shape clay into utilitarian and sculptural forms. Historical and contemporary practices will support each individuals' creative abilities. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 11

Art.title: Creative Practices
Art.description: Students cultivate creativity while making art connected to the world they observe daily. Work with cell phone photo collage. Explore theories of how artists/designers find inspiration, analyze, and strengthen their work through application of visual attentiveness. Prior art experience recommended.

Art.title: Art, Nature, and Contemplative Photography
Art.description: Explore "nature spaces" and the "unbuilt world" through art using materials ranging from cell phone photography to materials you find outdoors to create installations. Hikes provide inspiration and practice with creative fundamentals. Cultivate "flow" attentiveness, visual analysis and collaboration.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Art.title: Art History I - Prehistory to Renaissance
Art.description: Surveys western art and architecture from Paleolithic (30,000BCE) to the Renaissance (1500CE). Class focuses on city building, cave painting, glass, ceramics, frescoes, and metal casting, Students will interpret the visual arts as historical evidence and expressions of cultural beliefs.

Art.title: Art History II - Renaissance to Today
Art.description: Surveys Western art from the Renaissance (1500CE) to today. Focused on painting, sculpture, architecture, and photography. Students study art in relation to national, international, social, cultural, and historical contexts.

Art.title: Scenic Art & Scenic Illustration
Art.description: Students will learn small-format drawing, painting, and illustration techniques for theatre and architectural design, as well as large-scale scenic painting techniques for painting of murals, faux finishes, theatre, and opera. Lectures, discussions, and hands-on studio practice. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1701 or THEA 1110(C)

Art.title: Creative Campus: Local Arts Immersion
Art.description: Experiential arts learning. Students attend local/regional gallery exhibits, museums, design festivals, music events, and performances on campus and off; participating in and reflecting on cultural life. Art, music, theatre, and arts engagement. Includes events, discussions, and creative projects. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 12

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Art.title: Creative Ceramics
Art.description: Addresses ceramic theory, history, and science, and aims to develop the content and quality of students' work in clay. Students will learn new ways of creating forms through use of the wheel, molds, and study of clay and glaze technologies. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Art.title: Ceramic Sculpture
Art.description: Explores the material properties and expressive potential of clay. Learning a variety of sculptured techniques, students will demonstrate the ability to incorporate the elements and principles of art (line, space, form, harmony) to create aesthetic artwork. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2135 or FA 2305 or FA 3305 or ART 2140 or ART 2145 or ART 3140

Art.title: Color and Creativity: Exploring the Power of Color through Paint, Composition, and
Art.description: Design Course emphasizes use of water-based paint to study color theory and explore the expressive potential of color. Exercises in creative thinking and being, including work with basic photo and collage, underpin experimentation with design and composition of color in visual images. Pre-Requisite(s): (ART 1100 or ART 1110 or ART 2110 or ART 2130 or ART 2140 or ART 2145 or ART 2190 or ART 2350 or ART 2160) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Art.title: Contemporary Sculpture Studio
Art.description: Introduction to contemporary sculpture using a range of materials and approaches. Emphasizes development of student's creative language. Hands-on studio work, lectures, discussions. Class takes place in Rozsa gallery; includes student exhibit at end of semester. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2050 or FA 2110 or FA 2150 or FA 2160 or FA 2190 or FA 2300 or FA 2305 or FA 2315 or FA 2361 or ART 1100 or ART 1110 or ART 2110 or ART 2130 or ART 2140 or ART 2145 or ART Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 13 2160 or ART 2190 or ART 2350) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Art.title: World Sculpture Traditions
Art.description: Introduction to traditional ways of making sculpture around the world. Students develop studio skills while studying creative traditions from varied cultures. Hands-on studio work, lectures, discussions. Class takes place in Rozsa gallery; includes student exhibit at end of semester. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2050 or FA 2110 or FA 2150 or FA 2160 or FA 2190 or FA 2300 or FA 2305 or FA 2315 or FA 2361 or ART 1100 or ART 1110 or ART 2110 or ART 2130 or ART 2140 or ART 2145 or ART 2160 or ART 2190 or ART 2350) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Art.title: Special Topics: Art
Art.description: Examines important themes, processes, and issues in art, including local and global traditions. Spans a variety of creative practices. Creative projects, lectures, readings, and discussions. May be repeated if topic differs. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Biomedical Engineering.title: Undergraduate Biomedical Engineering Seminar
Biomedical Engineering.description: An overview of biomedical engineering designed especially for freshmen and sophomores that includes presentations by faculty, members of the community and other guest lecturers. Topics ranging from clinical engineering through basic biomedical engineering research are covered.

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biomedical Engineering.title: Statistical Methods for Biomedical Engineering
Biomedical Engineering.description: Topics include descriptive statistics, sampling methods, probability, statistical inference, causality, elementary design of experiments, statistical process improvement methods including Six-Sigma techniques, clinical trial methodology, and variance analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121

Biomedical Engineering.title: Cellular and Molecular Biology
Biomedical Engineering.description: General principles and engineering applications of science and biology, including cell biology, physiology, molecular biology, genetics, and biotechnology. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 16 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomedical Signals & Systems
Biomedical Engineering.description: Introduces the origin, processing and interpretation of biological signals. Mathematical modeling techniques used in the analysis of linear systems. Topics include: Fourier, Laplace and z-transforms, signal comparison techniques, power spectrum analysis, 2-dimensional signals, transfer functions, convolution, and simulations. Prerequisite of CH1150, MA2160, and PH2100 with a C or better is required. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 or CH 1112 and PH 2100 and MA 2160 and ENG 1102

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomaterials I: Fundamental Materials Science and Engineering
Biomedical Engineering.description: Introduction to the fundamental materials science principles and different classes of biomaterials (metals, ceramics, polymers and their composites), and some practical professional issues concerning the field of biomaterials. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 2400

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomechanics I: Statics and Dynamics
Biomedical Engineering.description: Course provides overview of two and three-dimensional force and structure systems and their applicability to human body. Course topics will include principle of equilibrium, concept of free-body diagram, moment of inertia, centroids. Kinematics and equations of motion, principle of energy, work and momentum. Course materials tailored for biological applications, particularly for applications at human organ level. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 2400 and (MA 2321 or MA 2320 or MA 2330) and (MA 3521 or MA 3520 or MA 3530) and BL 2010(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Sophomore, Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomechanics II: Soft Tissue and Bio-Fluid Mechanics
Biomedical Engineering.description: This course teaches basic principles of mechanics that are closely related to human soft tissue and bio- flow, particularly, at the human organ level. Emphases are given to both engineering fundamentals and biomedical applications. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3300

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Sophomore, Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.title: Experimental Techniques in Biomedical Engineering
Biomedical Engineering.description: Introduction to the experimental techniques used in biomedical engineering, technical report writing, and record keeping. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 17 Pre-Requisite(s): BE 2800

Biomedical Engineering.title: Fluid Mechanics
Biomedical Engineering.description: This course introduces fundamental fluid mechanics principles in a unified fashion so that students can describe biological fluid problems in precise mathematical language. Topics include nature of fluids, hydrostatics, differential and integral equations about conservation of mass and momentum, dimensional analysis and various types of flow. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 3160 and (MA 3520 or MA 3521) and BE 3300

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomedical Instrumentation
Biomedical Engineering.description: Introductory theory of measurement and analysis from biological systems. Covers the principles and use of transducers, data recording and analysis systems and signal processing techniques. Example measurements include life science research and clinical measurements such as the vital signs. Co-Requisite(s): BE 3701 Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3010 and PH 2200(C) and BL 2020(C) and BE 2700

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Sophomore, Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomedical Instrumentation Lab
Biomedical Engineering.description: Laboratory exercises to demonstrate basic instrumentation principles and biomedical measurements. Students will learn how to make non-invasive measurements on themselves and how to evaluate measurement instrumentation. Course will coincide with BE3700 lectures. Co-Requisite(s): BE 3700

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Sophomore, Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biomaterials II: Properties and Biological Interactions
Biomedical Engineering.description: Biomaterials properties including structure-function relationships (materials composition and properties), protein/cell materials interactions, characterization methods, and handling and processing considerations. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 18 Pre-Requisite(s): BE 2700(C) and BE 2800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biomedical Engineering.title: LabVIEW Basics
Biomedical Engineering.description: Learn how to program LabVIEW, a popular data acquisition and automation language used by engineers. Programming is done graphically which makes it easy to learn and use. Some of the topics covered: LabVIEW environment, how to construct graphical user interfaces, loops, debugging, writing data to disk and an intro to data acquisition.

Biomedical Engineering.title: Independent Study
Biomedical Engineering.description: Students undertake an independent study under the guidance of a Biomedical Engineering faculty member. The course of study may either be research or academic and is decided upon between the student and faculty member.

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; Repeatable to a Max of 12
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor and department required

Biomedical Engineering.title: Finite Element Modeling
Biomedical Engineering.description: This course teaches both fundamentals of finite element theory and hands-on experience for bio engineers. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 2320 or MA 2321) and (MA 3520 or MA 3521) and (BE 3350 or MEEM 2150)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biomedical Engineering.title: Cellular and Molecular Biology II
Biomedical Engineering.description: Covers, at an advanced level, the general principles and engineering applications of science and biology, including cell biology, physiology, molecular biology, genetics, and biotechnology. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 2400

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.description: This course will introduce basic concepts of tissue engineering; scaffold materials and biotechnologies for tissue engineering; basic concept of stem cells; review of stem cell sources and related policies; current progress in stem cell research, and application of stem cells in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.description: Light plays a significant role in modern clinical diagnostics and in the clinical treatment of disease. Examples include non-invasive surgery, optical biopsy, and cancer therapy. This course will focus on the study of how light propagates through biological tissue. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 2320 or MA 2321 or MA 2330) and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560) and MA 3160

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biomedical Engineering.description: This course focuses on the use of of polymeric materials in biomedical engineering. Topics will include synthesis and characterization of polymers, structure-properties relationships, degradation behavior, and biomedical applications for polymeric biomaterials. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Topics include the discovery and incorporation of biological designs into novel materials and their application in the biomedical field. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3350 and BE 3800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biomedical Engineering.description: This course introduces students to smart polymers that change their physical properties in response to various environmental stimuli. Topics include the molecular origin of the stimuli responsiveness of these materials and their applications in the biomedical field. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3350 and BE 3800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biomedical Engineering.title: Biocompatibility
Biomedical Engineering.description: Students will learn the general principles and biomedical engineering applications of biocompatibility. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 20 enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior Pre-Requisite(s): BE 2400 or BE 4200 or BE 5200

Biomedical Engineering.description: This course is designed to introduce the mechanical analysis and characterization of mammalian cells. Mechanotransduction, whereby cells detect loading and respond to the morphology and mechanical properties of the surrounding extracellular matrix, will be emphasized. tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of Engineering; Must be

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.description: This course will cover the principles of 3D bioprinting to develop therapeutic products. Biomedical Engineering.description: This course will cover systems that use electrical stimulation to restore normal function following injury or disease. The underlying biophysical basis and technology for treatment, clinical applications and challenges will be studied. Topics include spinal cord stimulation for pain relief, cochlear implants, brain and neuromascular stimulation. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 22 Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3700 and BL 2010 and BL 2011 and BL 2020 and BL 2021

Biomedical Engineering.description: This course introduces the student to the fundamentals of biosensor development and applications. It provides an understanding of biological components, immobilization methods, transducers, and fabrication techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3700 and BE 3701

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biomedical Engineering.description: An introduction to medical devices used for diagnosis, monitoring, and treatment in clinical medicine. Topics covered include product planning, reliability, clinical trial design, regulatory as well as technical aspects of common medical devices.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biological Sciences.description: Students will develop and improve their skill level in searching for scientific literature, incorporating that into scientific writing, evaluating and incorporating the work of others, and develop critique skills for review of scientific source material and basic statistical methods. Ecology & Evolutionary Biology, Human Biology, Biological Sciences, Computational Biology; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Medical Mycology, Virology, and Parasitology
Biological Sciences.description: An overview of medically relevant fungal, viral, and parasitic infections, including disease pathology. Emphasis on identification, diagnoses, and disease monitoring, as well as identifying and reducing pre- analytical, analytical, and post-analytical errors. Quality control, quality assurance, and safety will be addressed. be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2410 and BL 3210 and BL 2020(C)

Biological Sciences.title: Biochemical Laboratory Techniques I
Biological Sciences.description: Laboratory techniques basic to biochemistry and molecular biology with emphasis on protein isolation, characterization and kinetics. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 33 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3020(C) or CH 4710(C) or BL 3025(C)

Biological Sciences.title: Urinalysis and Body Fluids
Biological Sciences.description: Advanced theory and practical applications used in analysis of urine and body fluids. Topics include pathology of relevant body systems as well as physical, chemical, and microscopic examination of body fluids. Quality control and safety will be addressed in addition to pre-analytical, analytical, and post- analytical errors in testing. be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2410(C)

Biological Sciences.title: Current Health Issues
Biological Sciences.description: Introduction to health issues, such as: infectious diseases, obesity, mental health, healthcare disparities, health insurance, drug addiction, and vaccines. Students will analyze health issues from a diverse cultural, ethical, social, and global perspective. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Biological Sciences Teaching Experience
Biological Sciences.description: Development of teaching skills through assisting in the instruction of a section of biological sciences laboratory. Students gain experience in leadership, group work, organization skills, laboratory preparation, and laboratory instruction.

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Biological Sciences.title: Biological Sciences Field Experience
Biological Sciences.description: In this course students will gain intensive field experience in Biological Sciences emphasizing immersion and observation in novel field settings. Students in this course will visit different ecosystems during day and weekend trips that explore aspects of ecology, evolution, community dynamics and human impacts on ecosystems.

tags.Credits: variable to 9.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Biological Sciences.title: Research in Biology
Biological Sciences.description: Students conduct empirical, theoretical, or computational research under the direction of a faculty member. The work culminates in a written report, product, or presentation resulting from work performed. Specifics to be agreed upon between faculty mentor and student. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 34

tags.Credits: variable to 9.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Biological Sciences.title: Biochemistry II
Biological Sciences.description: Dynamic aspects of living systems. Broad exposure to cellular metabolic pathways, intermediary metabolism and its regulation and bioenergetics. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3020

Biological Sciences.title: Molecular Biology
Biological Sciences.description: Molecular biology of gene structure, expression and regulation. Also topics covering various molecular techniques and applications of these techniques and biotechnology. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3020 or CH 4710 or BL 3025

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.title: Advanced Evolutionary Ecology
Biological Sciences.description: This is an advanced course that looks at the study of ecology and evolutionary biology at the community level: how populations interact with the abiotic environment and each other to determine patterns of diversity, distribution, and abundance of plants and animals. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3490

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.title: Bioimaging
Biological Sciences.description: Current concepts in light and electron microscopy and scanning probe techniques. Theory and practice of fluorescence (including confocal and multi-photon), atomic force, scanning and transmission electron, and video microscopy as applied to biological specimens with emphasis on sample preparation. Half semester course.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biological Sciences.title: Epigenetics
Biological Sciences.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of epigenetic control that is not encoded by genomic DNA sequences of an organism. Topics include major regulatory mechanisms including DNA methylation, histone modification, and non-coding RNA (ncRNA) mediated gene regulation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 35 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3300 or BL 4030

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.title: Human Pathophysiology
Biological Sciences.description: Course will cover abnormal function (physiology) and investigate the signs and symptoms of major diseases in humans. Extension of Anatomy & Physiology by working through the systems of the human body. Course will include a clinical focus and case-study approach. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2010 and BL 2020

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Fluorescence and Video Microscopy of Biological Specimens
Biological Sciences.description: Hands-on training in fluorescence microscopy and video microscopy. Students prepare biological specimens of their choice for observation. Half semester course. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 4035

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biological Sciences.title: Environmental Toxicology
Biological Sciences.description: Introduction to the range of anthropogenic pollutants released into the environment. Concepts of bioaccumulation, biomagnification and environmental persistence, modes of toxicity and detoxification, transport and fate in aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. Toxic equivalent factors and quotients, regulatory guidelines and practices. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1020 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or BL 1040 or (BL 1400 and BL 1410) and CH 1150 and CH 1160

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.title: Tropical Island Biology
Biological Sciences.description: Survey of tropical island biology presented on campus and in the Bahamas over spring break. Topics include geological and societal history, and the biology and ecology of terrestrial, intertidal, and coral reef communities. Special course fees. Consult department prior to enrolling. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 36

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Biological Sciences.title: Special Topics in Biological Sciences
Biological Sciences.description: A study of recent developments in the biological sciences.

tags.Credits: variable to 10.0; Repeatable to a Max of 10
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Biological Sciences.title: Environmental Remediation
Biological Sciences.description: Toxicology of major environmental pollutants, their dose-response relationships and fundamentals of environmental remediation. Topics include physical, chemical, and biological remediation methods and effect of environmental toxins on biological systems. Laboratory will involve the application of chemical and biological remediation techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1020 or BL 1040 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.title: Plant Physiology
Biological Sciences.description: Physiology and biochemistry of plants. Emphasizes photosynthesis, plant hormones, water and nutrient relations, and light-regulated development. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2160 and CH 2420

Biological Sciences.title: Algae
Biological Sciences.description: The Lake Superior watershed has a rich, diverse, algal flora inhabiting numerous acid bogs, peatlands, ponds, lakes, fens, streams, rivers. This course emphasizes field collections and microscopic identification and includes discussions of algal culture techniques, invasives, blooms, limnology, and algal biotech. Pre-Requisite(s): (BL 1010 or BL 1100 and BL 1110) and (BL 1020 or BL 1200 and BL 1210) or BL 1040 or (BL 1400 and BL 1410) or BL 3080

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Plant-Microbe Interactions
Biological Sciences.description: Interactions between plants and microorganisms in the environment. Topics include microbial virulence, signaling, gene expression, beneficial interactions and disease resistance in plants. Laboratory will focus on plant biochemical and microbiological methods as they relate to environmental problems. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 37 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2200

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.title: Applied Genome Editing
Biological Sciences.description: This course offers hands-on training in genome editing design and implementation. Objectives will include knockout, tagging, and targeted mutation of genes in model organisms or cell lines. The history and ethics of genome editing will be discussed. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2200 or FW 3230

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Biological Sciences.title: Microbial Physiology
Biological Sciences.description: Structure and function of microorganisms, with emphasis on mechanisms for responding to changing environmental and nutritional conditions. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3210 or BL 3310

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Biological Sciences.title: Applied Bacterial Genomics
Biological Sciences.description: This course is an overview of techniques involved in genomics including hands-on experience in next- generation sequencing (NGS) platforms, and NGS sequence analysis including de novo assembly, gene annotation, and analysis including comparative genomics, pathway mapping, and core and pan genome analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2200

Biological Sciences.title: Applied Eukaryotic Genomics
Biological Sciences.description: This course is designed as a hands-on experience in eukaryotic genomic experiments involving next generation sequencing (NGS) techniques, including eukaryotic gene annotation, comparative genomics, and gene regulation analyses. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2200 and BL 2210

Biological Sciences.title: Advanced Cell Biology
Biological Sciences.description: Celebration of the commonalities of life as exhibited in the basic building block of organisms - the cell. Course topics include details of basic genetic mechanisms, cell structure and function, and an examination of cells in their social context. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 38 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2200 and CH 2420

Biological Sciences.title: Cardiopulmonary Physiology
Biological Sciences.description: Using a problem-based learning approach, course examines the physiology of the human body. In-class case- study analyses provide in-depth learning about the cardiovascular and pulmonary systems and their relationship with other organ systems. Promotes development of problem-solving skills. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020

Biological Sciences.title: Microbial Ecology
Biological Sciences.description: Interactions between microorganisms and between microorganisms and the environment with focus on the processes mediated by and controls on microbial life, and the methods used in the rapidly evolving field of microbial ecology. Emphasis on primary literature and discussion. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3210 or BL 3310 or BL 3490

Biological Sciences.title: Developmental Biology
Biological Sciences.description: The course will cover developmental biology topics from gametogenesis over fertilization, embryonic development to postembryonic development, including aging. Developmental genetics and the evolution of development (evo-devo) are an important component of this course. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2200 and (BL 3012(C) or BL 4370(C))

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Lake Superior Exploration
Biological Sciences.description: A field intensive course with significant time spent on a research vessel (R/V Agassiz or other) where students will learn the use of a variety of state-of-the-art techniques to characterize biological communities and measure important physical and biological processes.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biological Sciences.title: Fish Biology
Biological Sciences.description: Fishes and their habitat, native and exotic fishes of the Great Lakes region, and ocean fishery resources will be examined. Basic topics in Ichthyology and fish ecology, evolution, genetics, reproduction strategies and identification of early life stages, fish community structure, food webs and dynamics. Laboratory exercises on sampling, identification and classification of fishes and basic fish anatomy and discussion of Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 39 scientific papers relevant to the subject material. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1020 or BL 1040 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Stream Ecology
Biological Sciences.description: Field course combining river and stream ecosystem and foodweb study with fishes in lake systems. Students will be exposed to research methods used in lakes for comprehensive abiotic and biotic understanding. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1010 or (BL 1100 and BL 1110) or BL 1040 or (BL 1400 and BL 1410) or BL 3400

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Biological Sciences.title: Limnology
Biological Sciences.description: The study of biological, physical, and chemical processes of freshwater eco systems using a watershed perspective, with emphasis on lakes.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.description: This course is designed for students focusing their studies in ecology and evolutionary biology and seeking advanced understanding of pattern, science, and theory of ecological systems. Topics will range from individuals to communities and landscapes. Lectures and discussions will be guided by published literature. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3003 and BL 3490

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Biological Sciences.title: Ecosystem Ecology
Biological Sciences.description: Study of processes in aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems, including energy flow, ecosystem production, and nutrient cycling. We will explore these processes through a historical overview of influential research programs and regional to global case studies. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3490 and CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 40

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Biological Sciences.description: An overview of ocean environments and marine life. Biological Sciences.description: Emphasis on characteristic genetic, molecular, and cellular changes leading to cancer. Topics will include the role of tumor viruses, oncogenes, tumor suppressors, immortalization, apoptosis, and angiogenesis in cancer initiation and/or progression. Biological Sciences.description: This course describes advanced concepts in molecular diagnostics as applied to the practice of laboratory medicine. Business.description: Introduction to planning, organizing, decision-making, leadership and control in a business. Business disciplines of accounting, finance, information systems, management, marketing, and operations are introduced, along with discussions of business ethics and social responsibility.

Business.description: Introduction to basic concepts and methods of probability and statistics, including the following topics: collection, description and presentation of data, probability, random variables, sampling, probability distributions, estimation and hypothesis testing, ANOVA, and selected non-parametric techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121

Business.title: Business Law
Business.description: Provides an understanding of the legal basis of contracts and their enforcement in the areas of general contracts, contracts of commercial sales and of agency, and commercial paper.

Business.description: Stresses development of quantitative decision and analysis skills to solve problems with cases, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 44 exercises, simulations, and mathematical modeling. Topics include regression analysis, decision analysis, stochastic environments, data sources and errors, utility theory risk preference, linear programming, and simulation analysis. Business.title: Introduction to Business Analytics
Business.description: Provides an introduction to the collection, processing, and communication of business data to inform business decisions. Some topics include: finding reliable and trustworthy data sources, collecting data, cleaning and transforming date, and basic descriptive statistics. The course introduces industry leading data processing and statistical tools. Pre-Requisite(s): BUS 2300

Business.description: Provides students with hands-on entrepreneurial learning experience by placing them in close proximity of real-world entrepreneurs and innovators. Students ascertain commercial viabilities of intellectual property, senior design or enterprise projects, independent new ventures or early stage business incubators. Pre-Requisite(s): BUS 1100 and BUS 2300 and ACC 2000 and ACC 2100 and BUS 2200 and MGT 2000 and MIS 2000 and FIN 3000 and OSM 3000 and MGT 3000 or MKT 3000
