Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Civil Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: An introduction to the civil engineering profession with emphasis on careers open to the civil engineering students. Topics include: scope, specialties, education, professional practice, life-long learning, contemporary issues, ethics and societal impacts related to civil engineering.

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Sustainability and Civil Engineering Practice
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Course will focus on characterizing the motivation for and principles of sustainable engineering and provide an introduction to tools used in sustainable design. Course topics follow a logical and linear progression which includes the societal context, scientific motivation, and application of sustainable practices in civil engineering.

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Introduction to Computer Aided Drafting
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Fundamentals of creating engineering drawings with modern CAD software. Topics include basic Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 46 geometric construction, drawing modification, dimensioning, and working with layers. Designed for students with no CAD experience.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Experiences in Environmental Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Provides a series of activities that explore the field of environmental engineering. Through completion of the course, students will gain fundamental experiences with the skills, knowledge, and attitudes needed to solve the complex environmental problems needing solutions from today's environmental engineers.

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Civil Engineering Materials
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Covers properties and behavior of typical civil engineering materials, including wood, metals, aggregates, asphalt cement concrete, portland cement concrete, and composites. Laboratory exercises demonstrate selected engineering mechanics principles, including elastic, inelastic, and time- dependent material behavior. Additional topics include testing techniques, materials standards, report writing, and presentation of experimental data. Pre-Requisite(s): ENG 2120 or MEEM 2150 or CMG 2120

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Thermodynamics/Fluid Mechanics
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Provides engineering students with a unified understanding of the fundamental conservation laws and property accounting applied to thermodynamic and fluid dynamic systems. Topics will include but are not limited to: ideal gas behavior; heat, work, and energy; 1st and 2nd laws of thermodynamics; heat pumps; cycles; hydrostatics; Bernoulli; pipe flow and loss; and lift and drag. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and CH 1151 and PH 2100 and ENG 1102 and MA 2160

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Structural Analysis
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to structural concepts and techniques for analyzing trusses, determinate and indeterminate beams, and frame structures. Apply concepts from statics and mechanics of materials to determine internal forces and deflections of structural members and systems, including loads and load paths. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 47 Pre-Requisite(s): (ENG 2120 or MEEM 2150) and (MA 2320(C) or MA 2321(C) or MA 2330(C))

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Professional Practice
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Professional expectations of civil and environmental engineers demonstrated through readings, discussion, and writing. Topics include the consequences of engineering, design issues, legal aspects, ethical considerations, government requirements, management, leadership, and contract issues.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Fundamentals of Construction Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to concepts required by professionals involved in the construction industry. Includes contracts, bidding, estimating, scheduling, cash flow, safety, labor issues, equipment ownership, and productivity.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Transportation Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to transportation in the United States, transportation mode characteristics and applications, highway geometrics and design standards, pavement design and management.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Introduction to Sustainable Rail Transportation
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to topics related to rail transportation and industry. Overview of North American passenger and freight railroads in the past and today, concentrating on aspects and developments highlighting railroads as the sustainable mode of transportation.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Environmental Engineering Fundamentals
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Basic principles and calculations for environmental engineering. Covers application of mass balance, energy balance, and physical/chemical/biological principles to water and wastewater treatment, surface water quality, air quality, solid waste management, and groundwater quality. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 1160 or MA 1161) and MA 2160 and (CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 48

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Environmental Monitoring and Measurement Analysis
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to environmental data acquisition and interpretation, fundamentals of environmental monitoring, instrumentation, measurement techniques, and statistical analyses. Measurements are conducted in a variety of engineered and natural environments. Probability and statistical analyses are applied to the collected data. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160 and CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Environmental Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Application of fundamental chemical, biological, and physical principles of environmental engineering to design and operation of systems used for water and wastewater treatment, solid waste management, air pollution control, and analysis of quality of surface water, air, and groundwater. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160 and CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Water Resources Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to hydrologic engineering, including rainfall-runoff modeling and hydrologic frequency analysis. Analysis and design of hydraulic systems such as pipe networks and storm water management systems. Computational, field, and experimental laboratory sessions reinforce lectures and provide hands-on learning opportunities. Pre-Requisite(s): (ENG 3200 or CEE 3200) and (MA 3710(C) or MA 2710(C) or MA 2720(C) or CEE 3502(C) or CEE 3710(C))

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Uncertainty Analysis in Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to probability, statistics, and uncertainty analysis with examples from civil engineering (e.g. models of vehicle arrivals, structural reliability, flood distributions). Topics include: discrete probability theory, probability distributions, parameter estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests, linear regression, and model selection. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Soil Mechanics for Engineers
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Develops the terminology and descriptions common to the field. Studies soil compressibility, fluid flow, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 49 response to mechanical compaction, and strength as well as methods of determining geostatic stresses and stress changes due to boundary loadings. An experimental laboratory experience reinforces the lecture material. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000(C) and (MEEM 2150 or ENG 2120) and (ENG 3200 or CEE 3200 or GE 3850)

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Digital Project Delivery
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Problem-solving using industry standard software, such as Civil3D, is applied to civil and environmental engineering projects such as terrain modeling, earth work calculations, and road alignment. Concepts involving data management, data visualization, and risk analysis are introduced. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3332 or CEE 3401(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Bituminous Materials
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Applications and properties of asphalt binder, aggregates for bituminous mixtures, and analysis and design of asphalt concrete mixtures. Includes asphalt cement production, rheology, chemistry, and grading, aggregate grading and blending, and mixture design and characterization. Also discusses asphalt mixture production, construction, and recycling. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3101

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Matrix Structural Analysis
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Analysis of trusses and frames by the direct stiffness method. Use of a typical commercial computer code is stressed as a tool for complex structures. Introduces three-dimensional structures. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3202

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Structural Concrete Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to design of reinforced concrete structural components. Analyze and design reinforced concrete beams, columns, and footings. Understand material behavior, limit state criteria, and practical detailing considerations. Application of the ACI 318 to cast-in-place and precast systems. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3202 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 50

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Steel Design I
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Behavior and design of structural steel members using both ASD and LRDF approaches. Covers material behavior, external loads, and the design of tension, compression, and flexural members (rolled, built-up, and composite), and simple welded and bolted connections. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3202

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Structural Timber Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to the use of wood as a structural engineering material. Includes design of beams, columns, nailed and bolted connection, glulam members, including tapered beams, tapered and curved beam, and design of wood shear walls and diaphragms. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3202 or CMG 3250

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Loads for Civil Structures
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: The course focuses on the theory and building code requirements for civil structural loadings that are used in design. The loads and load combinations will include dead loads, occupancy live loads, snow loads, wind loads, and seismic loads. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3202

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Estimating and Planning of Construction Projects
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Examination of the principles and techniques of estimating construction costs leading to the development of an estimate and proposal submission. The relationship between the contract specification, drawings, and the estimate will be illustrated. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3332 or CMG 3265

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Construction Scheduling
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: This course will introduce students to the basics of construction scheduling. Topics covered will include: Fundamentals of different scheduling methods such as Critical Path Method and linear scheduling, Resource allocation in schedules, and Schedule monitoring and control methods. Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 3265 or CEE 3332

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Pavement Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Analysis, behavior, performance, and structural design of highway pavements. Introduces pavement Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 51 types and performance concepts, highway traffic and subgrade characterization, materials employed in highway construction, and highway drainage. Presents common methods used for designing pavement structures as well as mechanistic- empirical approaches. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3401 and CEE 3101

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Traffic Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to traffic engineering, traffic characteristics, data collection techniques, capacity analysis, traffic control devices, intersection control, traffic signal systems, parking, and street operations.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Railroad Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Rail transportation systems require infrastructure, vehicles, motive power and energy, and control systems to move goods and people. This multi-disciplinary course provides students with understanding of these system components and related engineering and technology enabling efficient operation of today's system.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Airport Planning and Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to the air transportation system, airport planning studies, demand forecasting, aircraft characteristics, runway requirements, airport layout and design. Also includes environmental impacts, airport capacity and operations, terminal and ground access planning and analysis.

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Transportation Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to computer aided geometric design of highways and railways. Covers design principles and use of standards for horizontal and vertical alignments and cross sections, including road intersections, railway turnouts and grade crossings. Students develop engineering drawings and related cost estimates for road/rail project. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3401 and SU 2000

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Transportation Planning
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 52 An introduction to urban transportation planning, planning data collection, transportation planning models, and development and evaluation of transportation plans. Includes extensive use of transportation planning software to evaluate transportation plans in multimodal networks.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Environmental Engineering Chemical Processes
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Application of chemistry, conservation principles, and mathematics to the analysis of chemical processes occurring in natural and engineered environments. Topics include acid-base phenomena, the carbonate system, precipitation/dissolution, redox chemistry, diffusion, mass transfer, and applications to engineering design. Pre-Requisite(s): (CEE 3501 or CEE 3503) and CEE 3502 and (ENG 3200 or CEE 3200)

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Wastewater Treatment Principles and Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Principles of physical, chemical, and biological processes employed in wastewater treatment. Design of selected individual units within wastewater treatment systems. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3501 or CEE 3503

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Drinking Water Treatment Principles and Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Provides an overview of the principles and design of municipal water treatment practices. Understand the physical and chemical processes employed in water treatment. Design individual unit processes with a view toward integration into complete treatment systems. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3501 or CEE 3503

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Air Quality Engineering and Science
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Overview of air quality regulation in the U.S. and world, including basic concepts of atmospheric chemistry and transport; fugitive, point, and area emissions; principles and tradeoffs of operation and design of air pollution control systems; and application of air quality models. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3501 or CEE 3503

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Surface Water Quality Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Develops the scientific basis for water quality management in lakes and rivers. Considers the origin, behavior, and fate of nutrients and toxic substances. Introduces engineered approaches for lake Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 53 management, including mass balance modeling. Presents techniques for water quality restoration and the legal framework supporting pollution control. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3501 or CEE 3503

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Sustainable Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Study of sustainability, engineering and design including systems analysis, life cycle analysis, biogeochemical cycles, energy balances, energy conservation and development, models for sustainable engineering, environmental regulations as sustainability instruments, sustainability in the build environment, and industrial ecology and compliance. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3501 or CEE 3503

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Water Distribution and Wastewater Collection
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Application of basic principles in civil and environmental engineering to the analysis and design of water distribution systems, wastewater collection systems, and their appurtenances. Pre-Requisite(s): (CEE 3501 or CEE 3503) and CEE 3620

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Environmental Process & Simulation
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Provides a rigorous hands-on introduction to process control, laboratory and pilot-plant experimentation focused on physical, chemical and biological treatment systems used in environmental engineering. Pre-Requisite(s): (CEE 3501 or CEE 3503) and (ENG 3200 or CEE 3200) and (CEE 4502 or CEE 4503(C))

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Baccalaureate Thesis
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Independent baccalaureate research project performed under the supervision of one or more faculty. Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Solid and Hazardous Waste Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Characterization, treatment, separation, and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes. Science and engineering for the management of solid and hazardous waste problems. Technologies discussed include incineration, landfilling, vapor extraction, soil washing, and bioremediation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 54 Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3501 or CEE 3503

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Aquatic Biogeochemistry
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Covers interactions among chemical, biological, and physical processes within aquatic ecosystems as well as role of aquatic ecosystems in global biogeochemistry. Modeling as an integrative tool is stressed. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 4501(C) and CEE 4505(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Bioremediation Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Introduction to the microbiological and engineering fundamentals of bioremediation. Topics include relevant microbial biochemistry, physiology, and ecology; necessary site data; design and operation of current and emerging bioremediation systems; monitoring methods for bioremediations projects; and technical evaluation of selected case studies. Pre-Requisite(s): (CEE 3501 or CEE 3503) and BL 3310

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Global Biogeochemistry
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: This course gives an overview of important biogeochemical processes occurring in land, air, and water. An emphasis is put on modeling as an integrating tool. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 4501(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Water Resources System Modeling & Design
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Solve complicated, open-ended real-world water resources problems in natural and built systems by developing and executing models using state of the practice technologies. Includes programming to manage large datasets and validation or calibration and optimization of models for design. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3620 or CEE 3650

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: River and Floodplain Hydraulics
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Analysis and modeling strategies of open channel systems, including natural channels, designed Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 55 channels, flow transitions, non-uniform flow, and unsteady flow. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3620

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Stormwater Management and Low Impact Development
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Design techniques for stormwater collection, conveyance, infiltration, and detention storage systems are discussed, both traditional stormwater management systems and newer approaches based on the philosophy of low impact development (LID) that seek not to alter the natural ecology of a site. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3620

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Hydraulic Structures
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Application of basic principles fluid mechanics in civil and environmental engineering to the analysis and design of hydraulic structures. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3620(C)

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Stream Restoration
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Basic mechanics of the transport of sediments in natural systems, including tractive forces and geomorphic functions. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3620

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Optimization Methods in Civil and Environmental Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Decision analysis and optimization techniques, including linear programming, nonlinear programming, and dynamic programming. Computer-based solutions of design problems in various civil and environmental engineering specialty areas are considered. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160 and (MA 2320 or MA 2321 or MA 2330)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Foundation Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: This course is designed to provide students in civil engineering with methods of analysis and design for various geotechnical systems. Topics to be covered include subsurface investigations, footings, pile foundations and drilled shafts, earth pressure theories, retaining walls, and slope stability analysis. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 56 Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3810

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Geosynthetics Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Geosynthetic materials are grouped by mechanical characteristics and engineering use. They are widely used in highway, landfill, and embankment design. Develop designs for filters, soil separators, reinforced earth, and impermeable membranes. Also learn when using a geotextile is appropriate. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3810

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Rock Engineering for Civil Engineers
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: This course focuses on the applied behavior of rock encountered primarily in civil engineering projects. Topics include rock classification, rock durability, rock mass strength classification, use of stereo nets, rock reinforcement, blasting, rock socket application and bearing capacity on rock. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3810(C)

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Engineering Design Project I
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: An engineering design project related to civil and environmental engineering. Not available to students who have taken CE4905. Students must complete both CE4900 and CE4910 to fulfill senior design requirements. Must be senior project ready as defined by major department.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Engineering Design Project
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: An engineering design project related to civil and environmental engineering. Not available to students who have taken CE4900 or CE4910. (Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites) Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Engineering Design Project II
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Continuation of CE4900. Not available to students who have taken CE4905. Students must complete both CE4900 and CE4910 to fulfill senior design requirements. Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 57 Pre-Requisite(s): CE 4900 or CEE 4900

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: International Engineering Field Experience
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: An engineering design project that incorporates an international experience. Must be taken in conjunction with CE4916 in order to fulfill senior design requirements. Must be senior project ready as defined by major department.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: International Senior Design Field Project
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: An engineering design project that incorporates an international experience. Must be taken in conjunction with CE4915 in order to fulfill senior design requirements. Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites. Pre-Requisite(s): CE 4915 or CEE 4915

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Civil Engineering Independent Study
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Approved research or design project in civil engineering, originating with an individual student or assigned by the instructor. Freshman, Sophomore

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 3
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Environmental Engineering Independent Study
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Approved research or design project in environmental engineering, originating with an individual student or assigned by the instructor. Freshman, Sophomore

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 3
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Topics of special interest in civil or environmental engineering. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 58

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Civil and Environmental Engineering.title: Engineering with Developing Communities
Civil and Environmental Engineering.description: Study of applying appropriate, community-based, and sustainable engineering in developing communities. Concepts of human-centered design and sustainable development are covered. Topics are drawn from several areas of engineering, including water and wastewater treatment, construction materials, solid waste, energy, and information systems. Pre-Requisite(s): BE 3350 or CM 3110 or ENG 3200 or MEEM 3201 or CEE 3200 Chemistry

Chemistry.title: Introductory Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Introduces fundamental concepts of chemistry to students who are interested in how chemical processes shape the world. Covers fundamental chemical concepts and integrates applications of chemistry that are relevant to the global community. High school chemistry is not required.

Chemistry.title: University Chemistry - Studio Laboratory I
Chemistry.description: Introduces experimental and theoretical chemical concepts from a hands-on, inquiry-based perspective. Emphasis is placed on experimental methods, reactions and stoichiometry, states of matter, thermochemistry, periodicity and bonding, solutions, and kinetics. Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Chemistry, Cheminformatics Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Biochem & Molec Biology-Chem,

Chemistry.title: University Chemistry - Studio Laboratory II
Chemistry.description: Introduces more complex experimental and theoretical concepts from a hands-on, inquiry-based perspective. Emphasis is on experimental methods, kinetics, equilibria, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, and special topics which may include chemical analysis, organic synthesis, computational methods, and biochemistry. Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Chemistry, Cheminformatics Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Biochem & Molec Biology-Chem,

Chemistry.title: Professional Development for Chemists I
Chemistry.description: Required for all entering chemistry majors. Intro to department, cover writing, technical software, library resources, reading and writing reports, academic integrity, career services, and other orientation topics. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 59 First course in a four-part professional development sequence. Biochem & Molec Biology-Chem, Cheminformatics, Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Medicinal Chemistry, Chemistry (BA), Chemistry

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Comp Chemistry & Chem Infrmtcs,

Chemistry.title: University Chemistry I
Chemistry.description: Introduces the foundations of chemistry, including electronic structure of atoms and molecules, intermolecular forces, states of matter, chemical reactions, organic chemistry, chemical equilibria, kinetics, and acid-base chemistry. Includes laboratory component that emphasizes lecture components. Co-Requisite(s): CH 1151 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1135(C) or MA 1121(C) or ALEKS Math Placement >= 56 or CEEB Calculus AB >= 2 or CEEB Calculus BC >= 2 or CEEB Calculus AB Subscore >= 2 or ACT Mathematics >= 22 or SAT MATH SECTION SCORE- M16 >= 540

Chemistry.title: University Chemistry Lab I
Chemistry.description: Laboratory to accompany CH1150. Co-Requisite(s): CH 1150 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1135(C) or MA 1121(C) or ALEKS Math Placement >= 56 or CEEB Calculus AB >= 2 or CEEB Calculus BC >= 2 or CEEB Calculus AB Subscore >= 2 or ACT Mathematics >= 22 or SAT MATH SECTION SCORE- M16 >= 540

Chemistry.title: University Chem Recitation I
Chemistry.description: Problem solving session to support University Chemistry I - CH1150. Co-Requisite(s): CH 1150 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1121(C) or MA 1135(C) or ALEKS Math Placement >= 56 or CEEB Calculus AB >= 2 or CEEB Calculus BC >= 2 or CEEB Calculus AB Subscore >= 2 or ACT Mathematics >= 22 or SAT MATH SECTION SCORE- M16 >= 540

Chemistry.title: University Chemistry II
Chemistry.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 60 A continuation of CH 1150. Introduces more complex concepts in chemistry, including kinetics, chemical equilibria, acid-base equilibria, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, and chemical analysis. Additional topics may include chemistry of the metals and non-metals, biochemical systems, and nuclear chemistry. Includes laboratory component that emphasizes lecture concepts. Co-Requisite(s): CH 1161 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

Chemistry.title: University Chemistry Laboratory II
Chemistry.description: Laboratory to accompany CH1160. Co-Requisite(s): CH 1160 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

Chemistry.title: Problem Solving in University Chemistry II - CH1160
Chemistry.description: Problem solving session to support University Chemistry II - CH1160. Co-Requisite(s): CH 1160 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and CH 1151

Chemistry.title: Professional Development for Chemists 2
Chemistry.description: Continuation from CH1130 and provides a more in-depth review of topics related to career planning, such as resume writing, interviewing, selecting research topics, research integrity, reading and writing reports, applying for scholarships and grants, and oral communication skills. Biochem & Molec Biology-Chem, Cheminformatics, Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Medicinal Chemistry,Chemistry (BA), Chemistry Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1130

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Comp Chemistry & Chem Infrmtcs,

Chemistry.title: Quantitative Analysis
Chemistry.description: This course examines the principles of analytical chemistry with emphasis on gravimetric, volumetric, spectrophotometric, and potentiometric analyses for separation, identification and quantification of chemical substances. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 61 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

Chemistry.title: Quantitative Analysis Lab
Chemistry.description: This lab provides practical experience in analytical chemistry with emphasis on gravimetric, volumetric, spectrophotometric, and potentiometric analyses for separation, identification and quantification of chemical substances. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and CH 2210(C)

Chemistry.title: Organic Chemistry I
Chemistry.description: A study of the chemistry of carbon compounds. Review of hybrid orbitals, covalent bonding, and resonance. Introduction to nomenclature, stereochemistry, mass spectrometry and infrared spectroscopy, functional group chemistry based on reaction mechanisms, and multi-step synthesis. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

Chemistry.title: Organic Chemistry Lab I
Chemistry.description: Laboratory to accompany CH2410. Pre-Requisite(s): (CH 2410(C) or CH 2430(C)) and CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

Chemistry.title: Organic Chemistry II
Chemistry.description: Covers more functional group chemistry based on reaction mechanisms; more involved multi-step synthesis; introduction to nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; introduction to carbohydrates, amino acids, proteins, nucleic acids; and topics of specialized interest. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2410

Chemistry.title: Organic Chemistry Lab II
Chemistry.description: Laboratory to accompany CH2420. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2411 and (CH 2420(C) or CH 2440(C))

Chemistry.title: Mechanistic Organic Chemistry
Chemistry.description: This course is an introduction to organic chemistry focusing on providing the understanding of chemical reactivity of various types of organic molecules through a mechanistic perspective. The emphasis is given to mastering substitution, elimination, and addition mechanisms and their relevance to various kinds of Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 62 organic compounds Co-Requisite(s): CH 2411 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1160 and CH 1161

Chemistry.title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry
Chemistry.description: The course focuses on the methods used to identify the structure of organic molecules, advanced principles of organic stereochemistry, and methods used for the synthesis of complex organic compounds with examples of biological and pharmacological applications. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2430

Chemistry.title: Introduction to Computational Chemistry and Chemical Informatics
Chemistry.description: This course will provide an introduction to the concepts of computational chemistry and chemical informatics, and develop basic practical skills for working with computational chemistry software and databases. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1160

Chemistry.title: Exploring Undergraduate Research in Chemistry
Chemistry.description: An elective course for students who want to pursue chemistry research early in their academic career or may be uncertain of their research interests. One credit translates to three hours of commitment per week. Projects may require an additional semester to complete. Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150(C) and CH 1151(C)

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Chemistry.title: Laboratory Teaching Internship
Chemistry.description: Requires teaching a section of undergraduate laboratory under professional supervision. Emphasizes communicating good laboratory practice and technique to beginning students as well as maintaining a safe working environment. Includes safety training and teaching orientation. Freshman, Sophomore

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Chemistry.title: Professional Development for Chemists 3
Chemistry.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 63 Continuation from CH2130 and provides a more in-depth review of topics related to refining written and oral communication skills, including advanced library resources, reading and writing reports, and seminar attendance. Biochem & Molec Biology-Chem, Cheminformatics, Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Medicinal Chemistry, Chemistry (BA), Chemistry Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2130

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Comp Chemistry & Chem Infrmtcs,

Chemistry.title: Chemistry and Biology of Brewing
Chemistry.description: This course is designed to expose science majors to various analytical techniques and instrumental methods used in chemistry and biology. Students will engage in numerous applications of basic chemical and biological concepts in the context of beer brewing, a complex and multifaceted biochemical system. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and CH 1151

Chemistry.title: Physical Chemistry for Environmental and Life Sciences
Chemistry.description: Equilibrium thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, transport properties, gas laws, and phase equilibria with an emphasis on solution behavior and applications to molecules important in the environmental and life sciences. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or CH 1170 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and MA 2160

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemistry, Chemical Engineering

Chemistry.title: Mathematics for Applications in Physical Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Emphasis on practical use of mathematical concepts necessary for Physical Chemistry. Topics include: vectors, single- and multi-variable functions, integrals, power series, ordinary differential equations. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and MA 2160

Chemistry.title: Physical Chemistry I - Thermodynamics, Equilibrium and Kinetics
Chemistry.description: Ideal and non-ideal gas laws, the kinetic theory of gases, equations of state, liquid-vapor equilibrium, the laws of thermodynamics, solid-liquid-vapor equilibria, the chemical potential, chemical equilibrium, electrochemistry, the phase rule, phase diagrams, and chemical kinetics. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 64 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and MA 2160 and (PH 2200(C) or PH 2260(C))

Chemistry.title: Physical Chemistry Lab I
Chemistry.description: Laboratory to supplement CH3510. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510(C)

Chemistry.title: Physical Chemistry II - Molecular Structure
Chemistry.description: Continuation of CH3510. Covers solid-state chemistry, surface chemistry, atomic and molecular spectroscopy and structure, chemical applications of group theory, valence, the periodic table, elements of quantum mechanics, and statistical thermodynamics. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and MA 3160 and PH 2200(C)

Chemistry.title: Physical Chemistry Lab II
Chemistry.description: Laboratory to supplement CH3520. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3520(C)

Chemistry.title: Biophysical Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Examines fundamental physical principles underlying complex biological systems in order to understand the interactions and behaviors found in biological, biochemical, and physical systems. Topics include macromolecules in aqueous environments, spectroscopy and structure determination, kinetics, membranes, and transport phenomena. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1020 or BL 1040 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410) and CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and MA 2160 and PH 2200

Chemistry.title: Biophysical Chemistry Laboratory
Chemistry.description: Examines the physical methods employed in the study of biological systems, including structure determination, spectroscopy, microscopy, imaging, and modeling. The core objective is application of the fundamentals developed in the Biophysical Chemistry course to systems of biological relevance. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3540(C)

Chemistry.title: Medicinal Chemistry: Mechanism of Drug Action
Chemistry.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 65 Focuses on structural and mechanistic approaches to pharmaceuticals and drug action. General principles of absorption, distribution, action, metabolism and toxicity of drugs will be presented followed by action of drug classes such as antibiotics, cardiovascular, and anti-inflammatory drugs. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2410 or CH 2430

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Chemistry.title: Medicinal Chemistry: Drug Design
Chemistry.description: Focuses on the important concepts in the design and synthesis of drugs. Rational basis for drug design including synthetic, computational and biochemical concepts will be discussed. Topics include structure- activity relationships, synthesis and reaction mechanism, and case studies of drugs. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420 or CH 2440

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Chemistry.title: Professional Development for Chemists 4
Chemistry.description: Continuation from CH3130 with emphasis on advanced topics of written and oral communication skills. Chem, Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Medicinal Chemistry, Comp Chemistry & Chem Infrmtcs, Cheminformatics Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3130

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemistry, Biochem & Molec Biology-

Chemistry.title: Introduction to Pharmaceutical Analysis
Chemistry.description: This course will present a systematic introduction to chemical analysis of pharmaceutical raw materials, finished pharmaceutical products, and of drugs in biological fluids, which are carried out in pharmaceutical laboratories worldwide. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2410 or CH 2430

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Chemistry.title: Instrumental Analysis
Chemistry.description: The lecture portion of CH4212; not open to undergraduate chemistry majors. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2212 and CH 2210 and CH 2211 and CH 3510(C) and CH 3511(C) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 66

Chemistry.title: Instrumental Analysis Lab
Chemistry.description: Chemical analysis and instrumentation applies to organic and inorganic analyses. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510(C) and CH 3511(C) and CH 4210(C) and (CH 2210 and CH 2211 or CH 2212)

Chemistry.title: Bioanalytical Chemistry
Chemistry.description: This course provides an overview of modern analytical and instrumental techniques with an emphasis on the approaches relevant to common techniques for biochemistry. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and (CH 3510(C) and CH 3511(C))

Chemistry.title: Bioanalytical Chemistry Lab
Chemistry.description: This lab provides an overview of modern analytical and instrumental techniques with an emphasis on the approaches relevant to common techniques for biochemistry. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161) and (CH 3510(C) and CH 3511(C)) and CH 4220(C)

Chemistry.title: Advanced Mass Spectrometry
Chemistry.description: Advanced instrumentation and methods are the focus of this course. Design of various mass analyzers and their advantages and limitations will be reviewed. Advanced identification methods such as tandem mass spectrometric analysis and exact mass analysis will be discussed. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 4212 or (CH 4210 and CH 4211) or CH 4222 or (CH 4220 and CH 4221)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Chemistry.title: Advanced Mass Spectrometry Laboratory
Chemistry.description: Students will learn how to perform mass spectrometry (MS) experiments to identify and quantify molecules. The experiments will include the following method approaches: electrospray ionization (ESI), matrix associated laser desorption (MALDI) and tandem MA analysis (MS/MS). Co-Requisite(s): CH 4240 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 4212 or (CH 4210 and CH 4211) or CH 4222 or (CH 4220 and CH 4221)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Chemistry.title: Inorganic Chemistry I
Chemistry.description: Descriptive chemistry of the main group elements with some emphasis on the structure and theory of Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 67 bonding with transition metal complexes. Examines bonding, physical and chemical properties, structure, and reactions of the chemical elements and their compounds. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3520

Chemistry.title: Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory
Chemistry.description: Laboratory preparations (selected inorganic and organometallic compounds) that illustrate appropriate experimental techniques for synthesis of molecules; measurement of chemical properties, structures, and phenomena; hands-on experience with modern instrumentation; computational data analysis (by means of single crystal X-ray Diffraction experiments). Pre-Requisite(s): CH 4310(C)

Chemistry.title: Inorganic Chemistry II
Chemistry.description: Continuation of CH4310. Descriptive chemistry of the transition group elements. Transition metal compounds; aspects of bonding, spectra, and reactivity; complexes of p-acceptor ligands; organometallic compounds and their role in catalysis; metals in biological systems; preparative, analytical, and instrumental techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 4310

Chemistry.title: Bioinorganic Chemistry
Chemistry.description: The course focuses on the recent advances in Bioinorganic Chemistry and in particular the role of metals in biochemistry. The course explores the methods for studying of bioinorganic enzymes and will focus on the roles of different main group and transition metals in proteins, enzymes and nucleic acids. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 4710 or BL 3020 or CH 4110

Chemistry.title: Spectroscopy of Organic Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Emphasizes use of spectral data interpretation to determine structures of organic compounds. Discusses proton and carbon nuclear magnetic resonance (including two- dimensional techniques, COSY, HETCOR, etc.), mass spectrometry, infrared spectrophotometry. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420 or CH 2440 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 68

Chemistry.title: Intermediate Organic Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Develop the chemical intuition necessary for advanced work in organic chemistry. Emphasizes reaction mechanisms and why reactions occur. Topics include heteraromatic chemistry, curved-arrow formalism and multi-step reactions, molecular orbitals and symmetry-controlled reactions, Hammett equation and structure- activity relationships, substitution reactions and carbonyl reactions. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420 or CH 2440

Chemistry.title: Molecular Modeling
Chemistry.description: The course focuses on the principles and applications of the methods for molecular modeling of large molecules. The students will learn the principles of molecular mechanics (MM), molecular dynamics (MD), combined quantum mechanics and molecular mechanics (QM/MM) and their applications for understanding molecular and biomolecular systems. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510 and CH 2510

Chemistry.title: Atmospheric Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Study of the photochemical processes governing the composition of the troposphere and stratosphere, with application to air pollution and climate change. Covers radical chain reaction cycles, heterogeneous chemistry, atmospheric radiative transfer, and measurement techniques for atmospheric gases. the following Class(es): Senior Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510 or CH 3520(C) or ENVE 4501 or ENVE 4504 or CEE 4501 or CEE 4504

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate; Must be enrolled in one of

Chemistry.title: Aerosol and Cloud Chemistry
Chemistry.description: This course is focused on the chemistry of atmospheric aerosols and cloud processes. Students will learn about methods for chemical characterization, the chemical composition of aerosol and the chemical reactions pertinent to secondary aerosol and cloud composition. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510 or CH 3520 or ENVE 4501 or ENVE 4504

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Chemistry.title: Physical Chemistry III - Molecular Driving Forces from Fundamentals to Applications
Chemistry.description: Advance course design to bridge concepts in thermodynamics, kinetics, and quantum chemistry through the application of statistical mechanics to understand the molecular driving forces acting in chemical/physical /material/biological systems at both microscopic, and macroscopic level. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 69 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510 and CH 3520

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Chemistry.title: Computational Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Focuses on the theory and method of modern computational techniques applied to the study of molecular properties and reactivity through lecture and computer projects. Covers classical mechanical as well as quantum mechanical approaches. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3520

Chemistry.title: Introduction to Polymer Science
Chemistry.description: Introductory study of the properties of polymers. Includes structure and characterization of polymers in the solid state, in solution, and as melts. Topics include viscoelasticity, rubbery elasticity, rheology and polymer processing. Applications discussed include coatings, adhesives, and composites. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

Chemistry.title: Polymer Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Study of polymer chemistry dealing with the mechanisms of polymerization and copolymerization. Study of the chemistry of polymers, including polymer modification and degradation. Topics include methods for measuring and predicting the path of degradation and stabilization. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420 or CH 2440

Chemistry.title: Synthesis of Nanoparticles
Chemistry.description: This hands-on course teaches methods of preparing different types of nanoparticles, and controlling nanoparticle size, structure, and functionalization. Students will analyze selected papers from professional literature to see emerging trends in nanoparticle design and use. Pre-Requisite(s): (CH 2410 or CH 2430) and CH 2411

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Chemistry.title: Biomolecular Chemistry I
Chemistry.description: Examines chemical concepts underlying biomolecules and bioprocesses and interconnections between biology and chemistry. Bioorganic mechanisms and biophysical concepts in biochemistry are Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 70 emphasized. Topics include biomolecules including proteins and nucleic acids and bioprocesses including catalysis and gene action. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420 or CH 2440

Chemistry.title: Biomolecular Chemistry II
Chemistry.description: Focuses on structural and chemical logic of bioprocesses with emphasis on bioorganic mechanisms and the interconnections between biology and chemistry. Topics include metabolic pathways, membrane biophysics, ion-channels, cell communication, transcriptional control and molecular biology. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3020 or CH 4710

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Chemistry.title: Research Methods in Biomolecular Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Lab course will emphasize the research process in biomolecular chemistry by actively involving students in question formulation, experimental design, data gathering, critical analysis, team work, and communication in an inquiry-based format. Students will employ methods used in modern biochemistry/molecular biology in a series of open-ended experiments that will lead to a student- developed original research project. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 4710 and CH 4222 or (CH 4220 and CH 4221) or CH 4212 or (CH 4220 and CH 4211) and CH 4720

Chemistry.title: Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy: Foundations, Applications, and Advances
Chemistry.description: Principles of fluorescence microscopy, confocal microscope design, practical aspects of confocal microscopy, live cell imaging, high speed imaging, fluorescent stains, quantitative fluorescence, immunofluorescence, fluorescent proteins, biosensors. Confocal applications in biology and health related sciences will be covered. Graduate

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):

Chemistry.title: Current Topics in Undergraduate Chemistry
Chemistry.description: Covers chemistry topics not included in regular courses. Topics may include designing organic syntheses, heterogeneous catalysis, homogeneous catalysis, solid-state chemistry, and heterocyclic chemistry. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 71

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 12

Chemistry.title: Design and Operation of a High School Chemistry Lab
Chemistry.description: Hands-on experience in the operation of a high school chemistry laboratory. Includes the design and preparation of experiments and demonstrations, setting up and maintaining a chemical storeroom, chemical waste disposal, and safety issues. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420 and CH 2411 and CH 3020

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Secondary Education

Chemistry.title: Undergraduate Research in Chemistry
Chemistry.description: An undergraduate research experience in which students select a literature and laboratory research problem and write a report on the work performed. The student typically signs up for 1 to 3 credits per semester; most problems require more than one semester to complete. Requires GPA of 2.50 or better.

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; Repeatable to a Max of 12
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Chemistry.title: Undergrad Research in Biochem
Chemistry.description: Undergraduate research experience in Biochemistry where students work on independent research projects under the direction of biochemistry faculty performing research in areas of biophysics, biochemistry, and molecular biology. Instructor permission required. Chemical Engineering

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; Repeatable to a Max of 12
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Chemical Engineering.title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: Introduces chemical engineering as a profession using the theme of industrial chemical production. Covered concepts include process flow diagrams, unit operations, green engineering, and career opportunities. Guest speakers from industry will provide their perspectives on working as a chemical engineer.

Chemical Engineering.title: Material and Energy Balances
Chemical Engineering.description: Application of material and energy balances to chemical processes. Fundamental concepts covered include: process flow diagrams, engineering charts and tables, vapor-liquid equilibrium, and stoichiometry. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1135 or MA 1121) and (CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 72

Chemical Engineering.title: Intro Minerals and Materials
Chemical Engineering.description: Fundamentals of minerals processing, raw materials production, and extractive metallurgy, including primary metals production.

Chemical Engineering.title: Bioprocessing Laboratory
Chemical Engineering.description: Experience all steps involved in manufacturing a product using microorganisms. Learn and apply molecular biology and microbial characterization techniques, perform microbial cell culture to generate a product, employ downstream separations for product recovery and purification, and analyze product purity and yield. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

Chemical Engineering.title: Transport Phenomena and Unit Operations I
Chemical Engineering.description: Introduce and apply concepts of momentum transfer (fluid mechanics) and heat transfer to unit operations. Presents the basic equations of momentum and heat transfer by conduction and radiation, along with transport equations that can be used in engineering analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 2110 and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560) and MA 3160 and PH 2100

Chemical Engineering.title: Transport Phenomena and Unit Operations II
Chemical Engineering.description: Introduce and apply concepts of convective heat transfer and mass transfer to unit operations. Presents the basic equations of mass and heat transfer, mass transfer analogies, and combines transport equations for use in engineering analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 3110 and CM 3230

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering

Chemical Engineering.title: Chemical Engineering Fundamentals Laboratory
Chemical Engineering.description: This course is an introduction to basic laboratory methods and instrumentation used in chemical engineering including measurement of fluid flow, heat transfer, and mass transfer. Topics include statistical data analysis, experimental design, principles of measurement and instrumentation, and technical communication. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 73 Pre-Requisite(s): CM 3110(C) and UN 1015

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering

Chemical Engineering.title: Thermodynamics for Chemical Engineers
Chemical Engineering.description: First and second law applied to closed and open systems. Topics include energy conservation, heat cycles, entropy and enthalpy calculations on engineering systems; property estimation for pure components and mixture constituents, and multicomponent phase equilibria. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 2110 and MA 2160 and PH 2100

Chemical Engineering.title: Stagewise Separation Processes
Chemical Engineering.description: This course will relate thermodynamic principles to separation processes. Mass balances, energy balances, and other fundamental concepts are applied in selected equilibrium stagewise and rate-based material multiphase separations (distillation, absorption, stripping, extraction, washing, packed bed, membrane-based, and leaching operations). Pre-Requisite(s): CM 3230 and MA 2160

Chemical Engineering.title: Process Control
Chemical Engineering.description: Covers methods of analyzing the transient behavior of chemical processing systems and components, the design and tuning of feedback controllers, and an introduction to industrial automation for batch processes. Laboratory introduces data acquisition and implementation of feedback control. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560) and PH 2200 and CM 2110

Chemical Engineering.title: Computer-Aided Problem Solving in Chemical Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: The use of modern software packages in chemical engineering. Packages include spreadsheet, symbolic manipulator, chemical process calculator, statistical and modeling software. Course develops knowledge and skills in using computer tools that will complement chemical engineering courses and practice. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 2110(C) and MA 2160

Chemical Engineering.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: A study of chemical reaction engineering including design and analysis of chemical reactors, the fundamentals of chemical kinetics, and analysis of reaction rate data. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 2110 and CM 3110 and CM 3230 and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 74 3560)

Chemical Engineering.title: Sampling, Statistics, and Instrumentation
Chemical Engineering.description: Solids sampling theory, practice, and instrumentation for process streams. Statistics/probability as they apply to representative samples from bulk lots. Minimization of errors, proper design of sample collection and size reduction apparatus, and statistical design and analysis will be covered.

Chemical Engineering.title: Mineral Processing and Extraction Laboratory
Chemical Engineering.description: Laboratory course covering the major mineral processing and extractive metallurgy operations, such as crushing, grinding, sampling, particulate separation processes, dewatering, and hydrometallurgical processing. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 2200(C) or CM 2110(C)

Chemical Engineering.title: Alternative Energy Technologies and Processes
Chemical Engineering.description: This course covers a wide range of alternative energy technologies with an emphasis on chemical and biochemical processing. Technologies covered may include biofuels, solar power, fuel cells, etc. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151) and (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121)

Chemical Engineering.title: Sustainable Chemical Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: Fundamentals of global sustainability for chemical engineering and industrial processes. Includes fundamentals of sustainability, environmental issues and regulations, principles of green chemistry/engineering, environmental fate and transport of pollutants, life cycle assessment, and ethical, cultural, and environmental implications of decisions. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 2110 and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560)

Chemical Engineering.title: Chemical Engineering Research
Chemical Engineering.description: An undergraduate research experience on chemical engineering topics. Students work directly with faculty members on a research project. A report (written, poster, or oral) may be required. Graduate

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):

Chemical Engineering.title: Undergraduate Research in Mineral Processing Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: An undergraduate research experience on mineral processing engineering topics. Students work directly with faculty members on a research project. A report (written, poster, or oral) may be required. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 75 Graduate

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
