Chemical Engineering.title: Undergraduate Research in Biological Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: An undergraduate research experience on biological engineering topics, excluding biofuels. Students work directly with faculty members on a research project. A report (written, poster, or oral) may be required. Graduate

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):

Chemical Engineering.title: Undergraduate Research in Polymer Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: An undergraduate research experience on polymer engineering topics. Students work directly with faculty members on a research project. A report (written, poster, or oral) may be required. Graduate

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):

Chemical Engineering.title: Undergraduate Research in BioFuels Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: An undergraduate research experience on bio-fuels engineering topics. Students work directly with faculty members on a research project. A report (written, poster, or oral) may be required. Graduate

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):

Chemical Engineering.title: Unit and Plant Operations Laboratory I
Chemical Engineering.description: A capstone laboratory course that provides a rigorous introduction to experiments focused in the unit operations of fluid mechanics, heat transfer, mass transfer, and chemical reaction engineering, as well as operation of a pilot plant. of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering Pre-Requisite(s): CM 3120 and CM 3215 and (CM 3240 or CM 2120) and CM 3310 and CM 3510 and CM 4320(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate; Must be enrolled in one

Chemical Engineering.title: Unit and Plant Operations Laboratory II
Chemical Engineering.description: A capstone laboratory course that builds upon the skills introduced in CM4110 by operating and analyzing unit and plant scale experiments. Safety, process control, teamwork, and communication skills are stressed. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 76 of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering Pre-Requisite(s): CM 4110

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate; Must be enrolled in one

Chemical Engineering.title: Chemical Process Safety
Chemical Engineering.description: A study of the technical fundamentals of chemical process safety. Includes toxicology, industrial hygiene, source models, fires and explosions, relief systems, hazard identification, and risk assessment. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 3120 and CM 3230 and CM 3510

Chemical Engineering.title: Particle Technology
Chemical Engineering.description: Fundamentals of particle processing, characterization, and separation. Topics include fine particle synthesis, mineral processing, automobile recycling, contaminated soils, recyclable materials such as batteries and tires, and sludges. Covers zeta potential, particulate surface chemistry, flocculation, and dispersion.

Chemical Engineering.title: Interfacial Engineering
Chemical Engineering.description: Examines the physics and chemistry of interfaces, and the relevance of these principles in mineral processing, petroleum, water treatment, and other engineering applications. May include liquid surfaces, electric double layer, surface forces, contact angle phenomena, surfactants, adsorption, surface energy, emulsions. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 3510 or CM 3230

Chemical Engineering.title: Introduction to Polymer Science
Chemical Engineering.description: Introductory study of the properties of polymers. Includes structure and characterization of polymers in the solid state, in solution, and as melts. Topics include viscoelasticity, rubbery elasticity, rheology and polymer processing. Applications discussed include coatings, adhesives, and composites. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

Chemical Engineering.title: Polymer Chemistry
Chemical Engineering.description: Study of polymer chemistry dealing with the mechanisms of polymerization and copolymerization. Study of the chemistry of polymers, including polymer modification and degradation. Topics include methods of measuring and predicting the path of degradation and stabilization. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 77 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2420

Chemical Engineering.title: Polymer Rheology
Chemical Engineering.description: A systematic development of the principles and applications of the science of rheology. Reviews vector and tensor mathematics and Newtonian fluid dynamics. Develops the physical and mathematical nature of stress and deformations in materials. Covers the use of theory and application of rheological equations of state. Pre-Requisite(s): (CM 3110 or MEEM 3210 or ENG 3200 or CEE 3200 or MY 3110 or MSE 3110 or CEE 3600 or BE 3550) and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560)

Chemical Engineering.title: Biochemical Processes
Chemical Engineering.description: Introduction to fundamental and applied industrial biochemical processing. Topics may include basic cell and genetic design, enzymes, metabolism, bioreactor analysis and design, bioseparations and industrial applications. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 2410

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Chemical Engineering.title: Hydrometallurgy/Pyrometallurgy
Chemical Engineering.description: Extraction and refining of metals and industrial chemicals from natural and recycled materials. Includes solution- chemistry processes (hydrometallurgy) and thermochemical processes (pyrometallurgy). Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Chemical Engineering.title: Biomanufacturing and Biosafety
Chemical Engineering.description: This course will give students additional tools to perform as an engineer in a biomanufacturing facility. Focus is on mammalian cell culture derived products. Federal laws and compliance of biosafety in manufacturing facilities. Process design software will be introduced. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3020 or BL 3025 or CH 4710 or CM 4040 or CM 4080 or CM 4710 or (CM 3110(C) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 78 and BL 1400) or (CM 3110(C) and BL 1200)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Chemical Engineering.title: Process Analysis & Design I
Chemical Engineering.description: Capstone technical and economic evaluations of processes and unit operations. Application of cost estimation, energy efficiency, and economic evaluation techniques. Teams analyze an existing facility, identify improvement opportunities, demonstrate the economic consequences, and recommend a course of action. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 3120 and CM 3215 and (CM 3240 or CM 2120) and CM 3510 and CH 2410 and CM 3980(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering

Chemical Engineering.title: Process Analysis & Design II
Chemical Engineering.description: Process and project design principles applied to realistic problems, including project evaluation and management. Problems include safety, environmental, and operability constraints. Emphasizes the profit motive in industry and the role of the chemical engineer. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 4855 and CM 3980

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering

Chemical Engineering.title: Capstone Design Project
Chemical Engineering.description: Team projects to optimize designs for new ventures with realistic constraints. Requires process synthesis, market research, economic evaluation, and risk analysis techniques. Develops skills in problem solving, critical thinking, and communication. Pre-Requisite(s): CM 4860(C) and CM 3980

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Chemical Engineering

Chemical Engineering.title: Interdisciplinary Design 1
Chemical Engineering.description: Focuses on an interdisciplinary chemical engineering design project. (Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites) Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Chemical Engineering.title: Interdisciplinary Design 2
Chemical Engineering.description: Focuses on an interdisciplinary chemical engineering design project. (Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 79 Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Chemical Engineering.title: Special Topics in CM
Chemical Engineering.description: Covers chemical engineering topics not included in regular courses, which may include biochemical engineering, design of biochemical reactions, composite materials, and numerical analysis of transport processes. Construction Management

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 12
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Construction Management.title: Introduction to Construction Management
Construction Management.description: Introduction to the construction management profession, and current issues and trends in residential and commercial construction industries. Focuses on how the construction industry works, along with enhancing verbal, CAD, and print reading skills.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Construction Management.title: Introduction to Building Information Modeling
Construction Management.description: An introduction to Building Information Modeling (BIM) with an emphasis on the Autodesk Revit software.

Construction Management.title: Building Utility Systems
Construction Management.description: Overview of the mechanical, electrical, and plumbing components of building systems. HVAC systems and controls, water supply and drainage, electrical power distribution and lighting, fire detection, alarm, and communications. Includes construction drawing interpretation and design projects. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 1240(C)

Construction Management.title: Statics and Strengths of Materials for Construction
Construction Management.description: Composition and resolution of forces and force systems, principles of equilibrium applied to various bodies, simple structures, friction, centroids, and moments of inertia. Mechanical behavior of materials, including calculation of stresses, strains, and deformations due to axial, torsional, and flexural loading. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 1110 or PH 1140 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 80

Construction Management.title: Building Materials & Methods
Construction Management.description: Materials, structural systems, building codes, and management procedures appropriate for residential and commercial construction. Includes construction drawing interpretation and graphic design project.

Construction Management.title: Construction Quantity Survey
Construction Management.description: An introduction to the interpretation of construction drawings to perform quantity take-offs. Emphasis is on the civil and architectural components of building construction, with some discussion of other elements. Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 1000

Construction Management.title: Site Planning and Development
Construction Management.description: An examination of land development issues including: site analysis, environmental concerns, contouring, earthwork and grading, soils, route alignments, storm water management, sewer systems, zoning, and land planning. Incorporates CAD applications in the lab. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2000

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Structural Analysis and Design
Construction Management.description: Elastic theory analysis and design of steel structural components, including tension, compression, truss frames, flexural beams, and connections. Includes an introduction to reinforced concrete structures and timber. All work is according to current applicable code manuals. Design projects include computer applications. Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 2120 or ENG 2120 or MEEM 2150

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Cost Estimating
Construction Management.description: Advanced study of construction cost estimating topics. Includes conceptual estimating, unit price development, subcontract work, budgets, negotiated contracts, and related items. Extensive use of spreadsheets and estimating. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 81 Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 2265 or CEE 3332

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Design-Build Project Delivery
Construction Management.description: Professional practice, financial, legal, and ethical considerations in construction management are illustrated and discussed in the context of the design-build delivery system. Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 3200(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Equipment Management
Construction Management.description: Study of basic principles used in the construction industry for selecting and managing construction equipment. Focuses on understanding the time value of money, estimating equipment ownership and operating costs, selecting the proper equipment for specific tasks, and estimating equipment production. Pre-Requisite(s): (CMG 3265 or CEE 3332) and EC 3400

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Planning and Scheduling
Construction Management.description: This course will introduce students to the basics of construction scheduling. Topics covered will include: Fundamentals of different scheduling methods such as Critical Path Method and linear scheduling. Resource allocation in schedules, and Schedule monitoring and control methods. Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 3265 or CEE 3332

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Contracts
Construction Management.description: Legal aspects of construction to include a study of construction documents, the project manual, report requirements, agreements, change orders, and other administrative functions in building construction. Pre-Requisite(s): BUS 2200 or CEE 3332

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Project Management
Construction Management.description: Provides students with an understanding of the principles required to deliver a construction project on time, within budget, and with acceptable quality. Topics include construction law, contracts, delivery systems, jobsite layout and control, submittals, record keeping, subcontracting and purchasing, quality management, change orders, claims, and dispute resolution. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 82 Pre-Requisite(s): CMG 4200 or CEE 3332

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Finance and Accounting
Construction Management.description: Focuses on the principles of accounting and financial management needed to make construction projects and companies financially successful. Includes profitability, projecting costs, cash flow and cash requirements, and equipment costs. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000 or EC 3400 or CEE 3332

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Construction Safety Management
Construction Management.description: Provides an awareness and understanding of workplace safety practices. Emphasis on the construction industry, including the OSHA construction regulations.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Sustainable Construction
Construction Management.description: An introduction to the philosophy and practice of sustainable building construction with emphasis on underlying socio-environmental philosophies, sustainable directed building technologies and materials, and case studies of contemporary green buildings to culminate in a simple sustainable design project.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Construction Management.title: Special Topics in Construction Management
Construction Management.description: Selected additional topics of interest in Construction Management based on student and faculty demand and interest. May be a tutorial, seminar, workshop, project, or class study. Construction Management; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Construction Management.title: Independent Study in Construction Management
Construction Management.description: Independent study of an approved topic under the guidance of a Construction Management faculty member. May be either an academic, design or research problem/project. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 83 Construction Management; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior Computer Science

Computer Science.title: Explorations in Computing
Computer Science.description: An introduction to the study of computing: fundamental concepts and skills; opportunities at Michigan Tech; career opportunities; social and ethical issues. Engineering, Computer Science, Computer Systems Science, General Computing, Electrical Engineering; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Computer Engineering, Software

Computer Science.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
Computer Science.description: Special topics in computer science offered on occasion based on student and faculty demand and interest.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Introduction to Programming in C/C++
Computer Science.description: Introductory course in C/++ programming. Topics include top-down analysis of problems, structured programming, control structures, functions, arrays, pointers, and file I/O. Basic concepts of object-oriented programming (classes, objects, function overloading) will also be introduced. Technology, Audio Production & Technology, Computer Network & System Admn, Electrical Eng Tech, Electrical Engineering, Mechatronics; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Robotics Engineering, Industrial

Computer Science.title: Introduction to Programming I
Computer Science.description: Starting point of the computer science programs. A high-level, object-oriented programming language is introduced as a problem-solving tool. Topics include design, coding, documentation, debugging, and testing of programs. Programming assignments are given in both a closed lab setting and as homework. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C)

Computer Science.title: Introduction to Programming II
Computer Science.description: Continuation of CS 1121. Topics include data abstraction, class hierarchies and polymorphism, list, stack, queue and tree data structures, complexity-based algorithm and data structure choices, and Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 84 recursion. Homework programming assignments are given. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 1121

Computer Science.title: Accelerated Introduction to Programming
Computer Science.description: An alternative starting point of the computer science programs for students with some programming experience, combining material from CS1121 and CS1122, offered at an accelerated pace. Homework programming assignments are given. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1121(C)

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Computer Science.title: Programming at the Hardware Software Interface
Computer Science.description: Programming in assembly language and C for students with prior experience in Java. Topics include binary number encodings, instruction set architecture, assembly language programming, and instruction encodings. C programming topics include program structure, preprocessor, arrays, structures, pointers, input/output, dynamic memory management, and linked data structures. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 1122 or CS 1131

Computer Science.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
Computer Science.description: Special topics in computer science offered on occasion based on student and faculty demand and interest.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Discrete Structures
Computer Science.description: Presents fundamental concepts in discrete structures that are used in computer science. Topics include sets, trees, graphs, functions, relations, recurrences, proof techniques, logic, combinatorics, and probability. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 1121 or CS 1131) and (MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121 or MA 2160)

Computer Science.title: Data Structures
Computer Science.description: Presents fundamental concepts in data structures. Topics include abstract data types (priority queues, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 85 dictionaries and graphs) and their implementations, algorithm analysis, sorting, text processing, and object oriented design. A significant programming project is assigned. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 1122 or CS 1131

Computer Science.title: Ethical and Social Aspects of Computing
Computer Science.description: An examination of social and ethical issues associated with computing. Topics include: ethical theories and decision making, intellectual property, freedom of expression, privacy, security, and professional responsibility. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3141

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Computer Science.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
Computer Science.description: Special topics in computer science offered on occasion based on student and faculty demand and interest.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Team Software Project
Computer Science.description: This course introduces software design techniques (e.g., Design-By-Contracts), uses the UML for requirements and design specification, and requires implementation, unit testing and documentation in the context of a significant team project. Focus includes security, teamwork, user interfaces, social and professional responsibility. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 2311 or MA 3210) and CS 2321

Computer Science.title: Formal Models of Computation
Computer Science.description: Introduction to the theory of formal languages and computation. Topics include regular languages and finite automata, context-free languages and push-down automata, Turing-acceptable languages, Turing machines and the halting problem. Proof techniques and applications, such as parsing, are also treated. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 2311 or MA 3210

Computer Science.title: Concurrent Computing
Computer Science.description: Concepts and techniques in concurrent computing. Topics include: processes and threads, mutual exclusion, semaphores, monitors and condition synchronization, deadlock, safety and liveness, message Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 86 passing, and concurrent architectures. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 1142 or (CS 1141 and CS 1040) and (CS 2311 or MA 3210) and CS 2321

Computer Science.title: Systems Programming
Computer Science.description: Development of robust programs that provide efficient services to system software developers. Topics include: file I/O, process creation and management, linking and libraries, interprocess communication, performance measurement, and socket programming. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3421 or EE 3172

Computer Science.title: Computer Organization
Computer Science.description: Introduction to the logical structure of computers, including the fundamentals of logic design, information storage and manipulation, control, and input/output. Topics include a review of current hardware technology, combinational and sequential logic, arithmetic, datapaths, hard-wired control, interrupts, caches, virtual memory, and an introduction to pipelining. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 1141 and CS 1040) or CS 1142

Computer Science.title: Introduction to Database Systems
Computer Science.description: This course provides an introduction to database systems including database design, query, and programming. Topics include goals of database management; data definition; data models; data normalization; data retrieval and manipulation with relational algebra and SQL; data security and integrity; database and Web programming; and languages for representing semi-structured data. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 2311 or MA 3210) and CS 2321

Computer Science.title: Software Quality Assurance
Computer Science.description: Practices for ensuring quality through the software process. Topics include: requirements elicitation, analysis and documentation, testing, and quality assurance management. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3141

Computer Science.title: National Cybersecurity Policy and Law
Computer Science.description: This course introduces the role of government in securing cyberspace. Students examine national cybersecurity policy and law. Topics include federal, state, and local entities involved in cybersecurity, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 87 relevant laws and regulations, concepts of civil liberties, intellectual property, privacy, development/diffusion of standards, and national security.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Computer Science.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
Computer Science.description: Special topics in computer science offered on occasion based on student and faculty demand and interest.

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Directed Study in Computer Science
Computer Science.description: Students study one or more special topics in computer science under the direction of one or more faculty members.

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Programming Languages
Computer Science.description: A discussion of the concepts underlying programming languages. Topics include programming paradigms; language theory and properties (including syntax, semantics, run-time behavior, and implementation issues); data, procedure, functional and control abstraction; functional programming, logic programming, and language security. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 2321 and CS 3311 and (CS 3421 or EE 3172)

Computer Science.title: Compiler Design and Optimization
Computer Science.description: Design, theory, and programming language translators and the theory and implementation of optimizers. Topics include: intermediate representations, advanced code generation, control-and data- flow analysis, advanced compiler optimization, dynamic compilation, global register allocation and instruction scheduling. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 4121

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Computer Science.title: Introduction to Algorithms
Computer Science.description: Fundamental topics in algorithm design, analysis, and implementation. Analysis fundamentals include asymptotic notation, analysis of control structures, solving recurrences, and amortized analysis. Design and implementation topics include sorting, searching, and graph algorithms. Design paradigms include Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 88 greedy algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, and dynamic programming. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 2311 or MA 3210) and CS 2321

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Computer Science.title: Operating Systems
Computer Science.description: Principles of the design and implementation of operating systems. Topics include: process management, process scheduling, memory management, I/O, file systems. Includes a significant implementation component. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3331 and CS 3421

Computer Science.title: Database Management System Design
Computer Science.description: This course covers the design issues concerning the implementation of database management systems, including distributed databases. The topics include data storage, index implementation, query processing and optimization, security, concurrency control, transaction processing, and recovery. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3425

Computer Science.title: Computer Architecture
Computer Science.description: Advanced course in architecture of high-performance computer systems. Topics include instruction-set design, simulation of processor architectures, multiple functional units, pipelining, dynamically scheduled pipelines, speculative execution, multi-core and multi-processor systems, advanced I/O subsystems and analytic models of architectural features of processors. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3421

Computer Science.title: Computer Networks
Computer Science.description: Computer network architectures and protocols; design and implementation of datalink, network, and transport layer functions. Introduction to the Internet protocol suite (TCP, UDP, IP), domain name service and protocols, file sharing protocols, wireless networks, and network security. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3411

Computer Science.title: Computer Security
Computer Science.description: This covers fundamentals of computer security. Topics include practical cryptography, access control, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 89 security design principles, physical protections, malicious logic, program security, intrusion detection, administration, legal and ethical issues. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3411 or CS 4411

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Computer Science.title: Computer Graphics
Computer Science.description: Introduction to interactive computer graphics. Topics include 3D viewing, 3D transformation, interactive techniques, animation, modeling, lighting, texturing, vertex programs, fragment programs, and graphics algorithms. Requires substantial programming homework. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 1141 or CS 1142) and CS 2321 and MA 2330

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Computer Science.title: Model-Driven Software Development
Computer Science.description: Focuses on the use of formal models throughout the software development life cycle. Topics include formal specification of requirements, behavioral modeling, automated analysis, architectural styles and design specification. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3311 and CS 3141(C)

Computer Science.title: Software Processes and Management
Computer Science.description: Focuses on the software development process and related management issues. Topics include software process models, the Capability Maturity Model, process tools, use of standards, software maintenance, configuration management, project planning and tracking, team management, and measurement and estimation. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3141

Computer Science.title: Network Security
Computer Science.description: Learn fundamental of cryptography and its application to network security. Understand network security threats, security services, and countermeasures. Acquire background knowledge on well known network security protocols. Address open research issues in network security. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4272 or CS 4461 or SAT 4812 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 90

Computer Science.title: Development of Trusted Software
Computer Science.description: This course exposes students to the concepts of secure software development. Students will learn how to develop high-quality software that is resistant against cyber-attacks, by minimizing the number of vulnerabilities that can be exploited by an attacker. Topics include access control, race conditions, buffer overflows, and code injection. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 4471

Computer Science.title: Senior Project in Trusted Software Development
Computer Science.description: A capstone course in development of trusted software. Students design, implement, or test software that is required to resist cybersecurity attacks. of the following Class(es): Senior Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3411 and CS 3712 and SAT 3812

tags.Credits: 2.0; Repeatable to a Max of 4
tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cybersecurity; Must be enrolled in one

Computer Science.title: Teaching Methods in Computer Science
Computer Science.description: Provides teaching methods, models, and experiences for teaching computer science in secondary schools. Topics discussed include teaching methods, learning, security and maintenance of equipment, professional journals, ethics, legal issues, diversity, and problem solving. Requires admission to the Teacher Education Program. Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior Pre-Requisite(s): ED 4700

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; May not be enrolled in one of the following

Computer Science.title: User Interface Design and Implementation
Computer Science.description: Principles of user interfaces (UI) design and implementation. Topics include: UI theory, design principles, evaluation, and tools. Requires completion of a group project implementing and evaluating a UI. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3141

Computer Science.title: Senior Software Engineering Project I
Computer Science.description: A capstone project course. Using software engineering principles and techniques, students work as part of a team responsible for developing a quality software project. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 91 Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3712 and CS 4760

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Senior Software Engineering Project II
Computer Science.description: A continuation of the capstone project experience, intended for Software Engineering majors. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 4791

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Computer Science.title: Artificial Intelligence
Computer Science.description: Fundamental ideas and techniques that are used in the construction of problem solvers that use Artificial Intelligence technology. Topics include knowledge representation and reasoning, problem solving, heuristics, search heuristics, inference mechanisms, and machine learning. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 2311 and CS 2321 and (CS 3411 or CS 3421 or CS 3425 or CS 3331) and MA 3720

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Computer Science.title: Data Mining
Computer Science.description: Data mining focuses on extracting knowledge from large data sources. The course covers data mining concepts, methodology (measurement, evaluation, visualization), algorithms (classification/regression, clustering, association rules) and applications (web mining, recommender systems, bioinformatics). Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 3425 or MIS 3100) and (MA 2330 or MA 2320 or MA 2321) and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710) Data Science

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Data Science.title: Data Science Programming I
Data Science.description: The course introduces data science topics and programming in Python using real-world examples and datasets. Topics include tools for the data science discipline such as use of Linux computers, use of the command line, etc. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C)

Data Science.title: Data Science Programming II
Data Science.description: The course introduces data science topics including inferential and computational thinking. Topics Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 92 include table operations, functions, control structures, sampling, visualization, testing and debugging. Pre-Requisite(s): DATA 1201 and (CS 1121 or CS 1131 or CS 1111)

Data Science.title: Foundations of Data Science
Data Science.description: Introduces data science technologies and methods that provide a foundation for subsequent Data Science classes. topics covered include working with data and applied linear algebra in standard numerical computing libraries. Pre-Requisite(s): DATA 1202 and (CS 1122 or CS 1131) and (MA 2320 or MA 2330 or MA 2321) Economics

Economics.title: Principles of Economics
Economics.description: An introduction to economics. The microeconomics portion covers consumer choice, the firm, value and price theory, and distribution theory. The macroeconomics portion covers national income analysis, fiscal policy, money and monetary policy, the commercial banking system, and the Federal Reserve System. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1020 or MA 1031 or MA 1032 or MA 1120 or MA 1135(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1121(C)

Economics.title: Microeconomic Theory
Economics.description: The study of consumer and producer choices, market demand and supply, and market structures. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and (MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Macroeconomic Theory
Economics.description: Analysis of the determinants of the level of output, employment, prices, and economic growth with an emphasis on fiscal policy and monetary policy. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and (MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1121 or MA 1161) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: International Economics
Economics.description: Introduction to international economics, including balance of payments, accounting, foreign exchange markets, international trade theory, barriers to trade, trade and development, regional economic Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 93 integration, and current U.S. international economic issues. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Industrial Organization
Economics.description: Economic analysis of market power and industry structure. Topics include the goals of public policy toward business, antitrust policy, economic regulation, public enterprise, and social regulation of health, safety, and the environment. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Economic Decision Analysis
Economics.description: Studies economic decision-making for actions occurring over time. Covers decision tools for comparing alternatives, public project evaluation, risk and uncertainty, mutually exclusive decisions, multiple objective decisions, interest rate calculations, cash flow analysis, depreciation and taxes, cost of capital, capital budgeting. Marketing, Management, Management Information Systems, Accounting, Finance; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Engineering Management,

Economics.title: Senior Seminar in Economics
Economics.description: A senior capstone seminar in which students discuss and conduct research under the guidance of several faculty members. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Economics, Economics; May not be

Economics.title: Game Theory/Strategic Behavior
Economics.description: The study of strategic situations involving the interactions of individuals. Modeling techniques are applied to game situations faced in business, entertainment, politics, and the daily routine of life. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 94 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Economics.title: Mathematical Economics
Economics.description: Application of the principal mathematical techniques used in economic theory and modeling. Topics include optimization, marginal analysis, comparative statics, and other applications. Pre-Requisite(s): (EC 3002 or EC 3003) and (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121 or MA 1135)

Economics.title: Econometrics
Economics.description: Introduces techniques and procedures to estimate and test economic and financial relationships developed in business, economics, social and physical sciences. Pre-Requisite(s): (EC 2001 or EC 3002 or EC 3003) and (BUS 2100 or MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710) and (MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121)

Economics.title: Banking and Financial Institutions
Economics.description: Analysis of asset and liability management of financial institutions and the role of financial institutions in the U.S. and international economy. Pre-Requisite(s): (EC 3003 or FIN 3000) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Public Sector Economics
Economics.description: Economic analysis of how democratic governments generate revenue (primarily taxation) and make expenditure decisions and how such decisions impact the welfare of individuals. Topics include market failures, voting processes, income redistribution programs, efficiency and incidence of taxation. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Energy Economics
Economics.description: Introduction to the institutional, technical, and economic issues of the production and use of energy resources, including petroleum, natural gas, coal, nuclear, electric utilities, and alternative energy. Coursework applies economic analysis to supply, distribution, and use of energy resources, including environmental and social consequences. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 95

Economics.title: Mineral Industry Economics
Economics.description: Studies the role of minerals and metals in society and the economics of their use. Applies economic principles to examine the supply, demand, markets, and foreign trade for important minerals and metals. Examines the effect of government policies on the minerals industries. Requires a technical report. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Natural Resource Economics
Economics.description: Studies the economics of nonrenewable resources (energy and minerals) and renewable resources (water, fisheries, forests and species). Discusses the economics of land use change, macroeconomic topics such as economic growth, sustainability and green accounting. Pre-Requisite(s): (EC 2001 or EC 3002 or FW 4080) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Market Failure and the Environment
Economics.description: Considers the efficient and equitable use of environmental resources, including air, water, land, wilderness and parks, wildlife and other ecological systems. Measures the benefits and costs of decreasing pollution, cleaner environment, and protecting scarce ecological resources. Addresses market failures and the economic valuation of environmental amenities. Pre-Requisite(s): (EC 2001 or EC 3002) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Labor/Human Resource Economics
Economics.description: Economic analysis of labor markets and human resources. Topics include the supply and demand for labor, wage determination, human capital theory, returns to education and training, causes of wage differentials, and economic effects of discrimination. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Economics.title: Research
Economics.description: Under the general guidance of a faculty member, students read, conduct research, and prepare reports and papers as required. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 96 Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Economics.title: Special Topics in Economics
Economics.description: Economic topics of interest to students and faculty. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 2001 Education

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Unknown (ED).title: Graduate Teaching Assistant Training
Unknown (ED).description: Half semester course for training graduate teaching assistants (GTAs). Covers course preparation, educational testing and evaluation, instructional strategies (discussions, lecturing, collaborative learning, cases/simulations, etc.), using instructional technologies, motivating students, and institutional resources. Graduate Electrical & Computer Engrg

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Electric Circuits I
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: This course will cover basic electrical concepts, resistive circuits, nodal and loop analysis techniques, superposition, Thevenin and Norton equivalents, maximum power transfer, capacitance and inductance, AC steady-state analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Electric Circuits II and Lab
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: This course will cover second order transient circuits, magnetically coupled networks, AC steady-state analysis, polyphase circuits, variable frequency network performance, and two port networks. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2111 and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Digital Logic and Lab
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduces analysis, design, and application of digital logic. Includes Boolean algebra, binary numbers, logic gates, combinational and sequential logic, storage elements and hardware-description-language based synthesis. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 97 Pre-Requisite(s): CS 1121 or CS 1131 or CS 1111

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Robotics and Lab
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduces the following topics: robotic actuators, inverse and forward kinematics, control methods, applied statistics, environment mapping, and path finding. Topics will be further explored during hands on and practical lab experiments. Pre-Requisite(s): (EE 3010(C) or EE 2111(C)) and (MA 2320(C) or MA 2321(C) or MA 2330(C))

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Photonics
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Topics include basic geometrical and wave optics, fiber optics, lasers, detectors, and optical communication systems. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 3521 and PH 2200(C)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Printed Circuit Seminar Series
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Seminars and lectures relating to the design, layout, fabrication, and assembly of printed circuits will be presented by instructor as well as industry experts. Co-Requisite(s): EE 2231 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and CH 1151

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Printed Circuit Fabrication
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Printed circuit board fabrication techniques are presented and explored utilizing wet-chemical process techniques. Single and multi-layer boards using internal layers for power and ground planes as well as plated feed-trough via structures, solder masks and silk screens will be discussed. While hands on fabrication will be the main focus, students will be introduced to software design packages specific to circuit layout and design. Final testing and evaluation of the fabricated boards will be performed. Co-Requisite(s): EE 2230

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Circuits and Instrumentation for Cyber Physical Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Designed for nonmajors. Covers the principles of electrical and electronic measurements, including dc, ac, semiconductor devices, amplifiers, and filtering. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 98 Engineering Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1121 or MA 1160 or MA 1161

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Electrical Engineering, Computer

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Electric Energy Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: An overview of the generation and utilization of electrical energy. Covers three-phase circuits, transformers, photovoltaics, batteries, electromechanical energy conversion, and an overview of electric power systems, including economic issues. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2110 or EE 3010 or (EE 2111 and EE 2112(C))

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Electronics
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers the fundamentals of electronic devices and circuits; operational amplifiers, bipolar junction transistors, diodes, and MOSFETs. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2112 or EE 3010

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Electromagnetics
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers basic principles of engineering electromagnetics with an emphasis on Maxwell's equations. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 2200 and MA 3160 and (EE 2110 or EE 2112)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Signals and Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduces the mathematical analysis of signals, systems, and control. Topics include differential equations, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, LaPlace transforms, frequency response, Bode plots, state models, and an introduction to control systems. Pre-Requisite(s): (EE 3010 or EE 2112) and (MA 2320 or MA 2321 or MA 2330) and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Microcontroller Applications for Cyber Physical Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduces the concepts of microcontroller-based systems. Describes basic characteristics of microcontrollers, then goes into significant detail in the applications of a specific microcontroller. Topics include C and assembly language programming, instruction set interface, ASICs, and polled, interrupt, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 99 and DMA input/output. Pre-Requisite(s): (EE 2241 or CS 1121 or CS 1111) and (EE 2174 or EE 2173)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Computer Engineering

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Fundamentals of Computer Organization
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduction to the fundamental structure and organization of computing systems. Topics include control logic, datapaths, instruction processing, caches, and pipelines. Includes a significant processor implementation project. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2174 and CS 1142

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Hardware/Software System Integration
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers the integration of hardware and software into a complete working system. Includes design and construction of I/O devices for microprocessor or microcontroller-based systems, communication and bus protocols, programming in assembler language and in "C", system integration and testing. Also covers the use of FPGAs and HDL design tools. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2174 and (CS 1111 or CS 1142) and (CS 3421 or EE 3172) and (MA 3710 or EE 3180)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Computer Engineering

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Probability and Random Signal Analysis
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Probability density and distribution functions, expected value, correlation, and random vectors. Wide sense stationary random signals. The correlation function and spectral density. Random signals and noise in linear systems. An introduction to hypothesis testing and parameter estimation. Engineering applications. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3160

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Optical Sensing and Imaging
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Optical sensing techniques, including imaging and non-imaging systems. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 100

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Control Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Mathematical formulation of control problems (both transfer function and state-variable descriptions); analysis of feedback control systems (stability, transient performance, steady-state error, sensitivity, etc.); analog and digital simulation; and experiments with physical systems. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3160

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Robot Operating Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: An introduction to the robotics middleware enabling robot platforms used in autonomous vehicles and advanced manufacturing. Students will learn the basics of distributed robotics software architecture, hardware considerations and associated simulation tools. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2180 and SAT 2711

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Photonic Material, Devices, and Applications
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Light wave propagation in optical crystals and fibers, detection, and the creation of light in semiconductors. Physics, Physics (BA), Biomedical Engineering, Materials Science and Engrg; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3140 or PH 2400 or EE 2190

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Electrical Engineering, Physics, Applied

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Programmable Controllers
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: The design of discreet sequential controls using programmable logic controllers (PLCs). Relay logic is used to introduce ladder logic and ladder logic is used to program the PLC. Introduces a structured approach to sequential control design. Data acquisition is introduced using BridgeVIEW software Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2112 or EE 3010

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Robotics Engineering

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Design Fundamentals
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: The design process; includes team design activities and studies project management, ethics, and professionalism. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 101 Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2112 or (EE 2180 and EE 3010) and UN 1015

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Undergraduate Research
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: An undergraduate research experience during the senior year in electrical or computer engineering. Students work on an active research project/grant with a faculty member. A report will be published in the department and archived. Junior, Senior

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Computer System Engineering and Performance
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers the principles and practices of modern computer architecture. Emphasizes quantitative performance evaluation of: memory hierarchies, from cache through virtual memory; pipelined processors with advanced hazard management; and combined processor/memory systems. Introduces RAID, superscalars, parallel processing, cache coherence, performance simulation software. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3173

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Computer Engineering

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Electric Machinery and Drives
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Provides a thorough understanding of how electric machines can be used to drive loads with control of speed, torque and position. Topics include basic electro-mechanics, rotating machinery, dc machines, ac machines, power electronics and load modeling. Applications include industrial systems, hybrid/electric vehicles and electric power systems. Pre-Requisite(s): (EE 2112 or EE 3010) and EE 3120

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Electric Machinery and Drives Laboratory
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Provides a hands on understanding of how electric machines can be used to drive loads with control of speed, torque, and position. Topics include basic electro-mechanics, rotating machineer, dc machines, ac machines, power electronics, and load modeling. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4219(C)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Power System Analysis 1
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers power transmission line parameters and applications, symmetrical components, transformer and load representations, systems faults and protection, and the per unit system. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 102 Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3120 and (EE 2112 or EE 3010)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Power System Analysis 2
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Topics covered include symmetrical components; symmetrical faults; unbalanced faults; generating the bus impedance matrix and using it in fault studies; power system protection; power system operation; power system stability. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4221

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Power Engineering Laboratory
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: A laboratory based course highlighting single phase and three phase power concepts, including: power factor, single and three phase transformer configurations, non-ideal transformers, synchronous machines, renewable energy, power flow and fault simulations, relay settings and relay testing and calibration. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4221 and EE 4222(C)

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Power Electronics
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Fundamentals of circuits for electrical energy processing. Covers switching converter principles for dc- dc, ac- dc, and dc-ac power conversion. Other topics include harmonics, pulse-width modulation, feedback control, magnetic components and power semiconductors. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3120 and (EE 3130(C) or EE 3131)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Power Electronics Lab
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Fundamentals of design, construction and control of circuits for electrical energy processing. Covers switching converter principles for dc-dc, ac-dc, and dc-ac power conversion. Other topics include harmonics, pulse- width modulation, feedback control, magnetic components and power semiconductors. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4227(C)

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Physical Electronics
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 103 Device physics and physical models of the most basic solid-state device structures. Major topics include the terminal characteristics and their physical origin, device design, and device applications. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3130 or EE 3131

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Electronic Applications
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Study of electronic circuits under small- and large-signal conditions. Typical topics include analysis and design of power and RF amplifiers, feedback circuits, oscillators, timing circuits, and wave-shaping circuits. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3130 or EE 3131

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Sensing and Processing in Robotic Applications
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Sensing and signal processing for robotics applications in manufacturing and autonomous navigation. Heavy emphasis on developing, testing, and evaluating algorithms. MATLAB programming required. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 2180 and ENG 1101

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to MEMS
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Fundamentals of micromachining and microfabrication techniques, including planar thin-film process technologies, photolithographic techniques, deposition and etching techniques, and the other technologies that are central to MEMS fabrication.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Modern Communication Systems
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduces the mathematical theory of communication science. Topics include baseband and digital signaling, bandpass signaling, AM and FM systems, bandpass digital systems, and case studies of communication systems. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3160 and EE 3131 and EE 3180

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Digital Signal Processing and its Applications
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Digital signal processing techniques with emphasis on applications. Includes sampling, the Z-transform, digital filters and discrete Fourier transforms. Emphasizes techniques for design and analysis of digital Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 104 filters. Special topics may include the FFT, windowing techniques, quantization effects, physical limitations, image processing basics, image enhancement, image restoration and image coding. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3160

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Real Time Signal Processing
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Practical implementation of digital signal processing concepts as developed in EE4252. Emphasis on applications of DSP to communications, filter design, speech processing, and radar. Laboratory provides practical experience in the design and implementation of DSP solutions. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4252

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Digital and Non-linear Control
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Introduction to state space analysis and design (state feedback, observers, and observer feedback); digital control system design and analysis (Z-transforms, difference equations, the discrete-time state model, and digital implementation of controllers); introduction to nonlinear systems (equilibrium states, linearization, phase plane analysis, and describing function analysis); and experiments with physical systems. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3261

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: VLSI Design
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Design of VLSI circuits using CAD tools. Analysis of physical factors affecting performance. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3131 and EE 2174

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Computer Networks
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Computer network architectures and protocols; design and implementation of datalink, network, and transport layer functions. Introduction to the Internet protocol suite (TCP, UDP, IP), domain name service and protocols, file sharing protocols, wireless networks, and network security. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 3411

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Introduction to Propulsion Systems for Hybrid Electric Vehicles
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Hybrid electric drive vehicle analysis will be developed and applied to examine the operation, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 105 integration, and design of powertrain components. Model based simulation and design is applied to determine vehicle performance measures in comparison to vehicle technical specifications. Power flows, losses, energy usage, and drive quality are examined over drive-cycles via application of these tools. Computing; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): MEEM 2700 or EE 2112

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of Engineering, College of

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Experimental Studies in Hybrid Electric Vehicles
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Hands-on course examines hybrid electric vehicles from an energy perspective. Topics include powertrain architecture, vehicle testing, fuel consumption, aerodynamics and rolling resistance, engines, batteries, electric machines and power electronics. Course culminates with study of system interactions with emphasis on idle reduction and regenerative braking. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of Engineering; May not be

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Internet of Things Applications and Design
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: This course consists of the application areas, revolution, and fundamental building blocks (data collection, connectivity, and analysis) in Internet of Things. A hands-on, multi-discipline project-oriented course. Computing; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4272

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of Engineering, College of

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Autonomous Vehicle Design
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Design of autonomous systems focusing on safety. Covers localization, sensor fusion, and motion planning. Emphasizes autonomy capability level, functional safety, and hazard analysis. Students will use autonomous vehicle data sets to develop sensing, perception, and path-planning strategies on simulated autonomous vehicles. Pre-Requisite(s): (EE 3261 or MEEM 3750) and EE 3280

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Engineering Electromagnetics
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: A mathematically rigorous study of dynamic electromagnetic fields, beginning with Maxwell's equations. Topics include scalar and vector potentials, waves, and radiation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 106 Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3140

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Laser Systems and Applications
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Survey of laser types and analysis of common physical and engineering principles, including energy states, inversion, gain, and broadening mechanism from a quantum mechanical perspective. Laser applications and laser properties are explored in the laboratory portion. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 3140

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Network Security
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Learn fundamental of cryptography and its application to network security. Understand network security threats, security services, and countermeasures. Acquire background knowledge on well known network security protocols. Address open research issues in network security. Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4272 or CS 4461 or SAT 4812

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Embedded System Interfacing
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers the use of low-power microcontrollers and hardware- dependent C for embedded sensing and control systems. Emphasizes direct interfacing with analog and digital sensors and actuators of several different modalities, to implement end-to-end embedded systems for applications including robotics and wireless sensor nets. Pre-Requisite(s): (CS 1111 or CS 1142) and (EE 3171 or EE 3173)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Electrical and Computer Engineering.title: Distributed Additive Manufacturing Using Open-Source 3-D Printing
Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: This course provides an overview of open-source hardware in theory and practice for an introduction to distributed additive manufacturing using open-source 3-D printing. Each student will build a customized RepRap and will learn all hardware and software for maintaining it. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: Covers specific topics in electrical engineering. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 107

Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: A project in electrical engineering. An individual student or a group of students complete a mutually- agreed- upon project in consultation with a faculty member.

Electrical and Computer Engineering.description: The first semester of a program of study in which a group of students work on an engineering design project in consultation with a faculty member. (Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites) Pre-Requisite(s): EE 4901 Electrical Engrg Technology

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Circuits I
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Fundamental theory of lumped-element DC and AC electrical circuits. Voltage, current, resistance, energy, and power. DC network analysis and network theorems. Inductance and capacitance. First-order transient analysis for RL and RC circuits. Sinusoidal steady-state analysis of simple AC circuits. Co-Requisite(s): EET 1122 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031 or MA 1032 or MA 1120 or MA 1121(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1135(C)

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Circuits I Lab
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Laboratory exercises designed to complement the theory in a first course in lumped-element DC and AC electrical circuits. Electrical laboratory safety. Breadboard construction of electrical circuits. Electronic instrumentation, measurement techniques, and data analysis. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 108 Co-Requisite(s): EET 1121 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031 or MA 1032 or MA 1120 or MA 1121(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1135(C)

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Basic Electronics
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Introduction to basic electrical principles and devices including DC and AC circuits, diodes, transistors, operational amplifier ICs, power supply regulation, and elements of communication systems. Network & System Admn, Mechanical Engineering Tech, Cybersecurity, Theatre & Entertain Tech (BS) Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031 or MA 1032 or MA 1120 or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1135(C) or MA 1121(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Surveying Engineering, Computer

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Circuits II
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Advanced treatment of passive linear electrical circuits. Superposition, Thevenin, Norton, and maximum power transfer theorems. Analysis of AC networks with attention to frequency response, attenuation, resonance, bandwidth, and terminal impedance. Single phase and balanced three-phase networks, bridge circuits, and filters. Co-Requisite(s): EET 2122 Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1120 or (EET 1121 and EET 1122) and (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121 or MA 1135)

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Circuits II Lab
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Laboratory exercises designed to complement the theroy in an advanced course on passive linear DC and AC electrical circuits. Electrical laboratory safety. Measurement of frequency response, attenuation, resonance, bandwidth, and terminal impedance. Measurement accuracy considerations. Circuit simulation tools. Co-Requisite(s): EET 2121 Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1121 or EET 1122 and (MA 1121 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1135)

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Digital Design and Modeling
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Emphasizes the language concepts of digital systems design using VHDL with emphasis on good design practices and writing verification testbenches. Students will gain valuable hands-on experience writing efficient hardware design code and performing simulations using ModelSim. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 109 Pre-Requisite(s): EET 2411

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Applied Mathematics for Engineering Technology
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Mathematical theory, mathematical modeling, numerical methods, and algorithms with applications drawn from engineering technology, including electrical, mechanical, mechatronic, and manufacturing engineering technology. Topics covered include complex arithmetic, phasors and complex exponentials, linear algebra, elementary differential equations, and probability and statistics. MATLAB programming is introduced to solve problems encountered in engineering technology with emphasis on modeling of electrical and mechanical systems. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121) and MA 2160(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Electrical Machinery
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Fundamental steady-state analysis of DC, AC polyphase and AC single-phase electrical machines as well as transformers. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1411 or EET 2121(C)

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: C++ and Matlab Programming
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Introduction to C++ programming and MATLAB for use in solving problems encountered in engineering technology. C++ topics include the basics of syntax and program structure. Focuses on the basic capabilities of MATLAB and its programming environment. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Electrical Eng Tech

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Digital Electronics
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of the digital electronics that make up microprocessors. Topics include number systems and codes, Boolean algebra, combinational and sequential logic circuits, arithmetic circuits, and digital memory. Network & System Admn, Cybersecurity, Mechatronics Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1411 and (MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1135(C) or MA 1121(C))

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Electrical Eng Tech, Computer

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Data Communications
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 110 Introduction to the fundamentals of basic data communication methods. Topics include data transmission, signal encoding techniques, digital data communication techniques, transmission media, and frequency domain analysis. Electrical Eng Tech, Cybersecurity Pre-Requisite(s): (EET 1411 or EET 1121) and EET 2411

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Computer Network & System Admn,

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Sensors and Instrumentation
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Sensors and instrumentation used in a wide variety of industrial applications. Instrument static characteristics, measurement errors, and calibration. Signal conditioning circuits including instrumentation amplifiers, DC bridges, and filters. Sensors for measuring motion, force, pressure, flow, and temperature, including physical principles and required electronic circuits. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1411 or EET 2121 or PH 2230 or EE 2111 or EE 3010

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Introduction to Industrial Robotics
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: This course introduces concepts of industrial robotics. Topics on mechanics, electronics, controls, forward and inverse kinematics, classification of end-effectors, programming, and the application of industrial robots are covered. FANUC Roboguide simulation software is used to program and simulate industrial production scenarios.

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Analog Electronic Circuits
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: An advanced course in the study of linear integrated circuits. Includes op amps, comparators, wave form generators, timers and regulators. Emphasizes practical applications, including the interface of time- continuous measures to the discrete digital world. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 2121

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Electrical Project Development and Troubleshooting
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Covers soldering, component layout, printed circuit board artwork, troubleshooting, electrical and environmental factors in design as well as an overview of the practical methods used by industry to process projects. The student designs and fabricates a circuit board and assembles a project. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 111 Pre-Requisite(s): EET 2121 and EET 3225

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Introduction to Programmable Controllers
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: The design of discreet sequential controls using programmable logic controllers (PLCs). Relay logic is used to introduce ladder logic and ladder logic is used to program the PLC. Introduces a structured approach to sequential control design. Data acquisition is introduced using BridgeVIEW software. Computer Network & System Admn, Data Acquisition & Indust Cont, System and Network Security, Mechatronics Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1411 or EET 2121 or PH 2230 or EE 2111 or EE 3010 or EET 2411 or EE 2174
