Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Power Systems
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: A study of the transmission of electrical power from generators to loads, system components and system performance. Covers basics of power systems and their analysis, the per-unit concept, faults on power circuit interrupting, system instrumentation, and automatic protection system. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 2233

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Real-Time Robotics Systems
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Covers the components of a robot system, safety, concepts of a work-cell system, geometry, path control, automation sensors, programming techniques, hardware, and software. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1411 or EET 2121 or PH 2230 or EE 2111 or EE 3010

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Industrial Robotic Vision Systems and Advanced Teach Pendant Programming
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Procedures for setting up, teaching, testing, and modifying robot vision systems widely used in industrial automation. Introduces advanced Teach Pendant Programming to develop complex scenarios for integrating robots into industrial cells. Final project must demonstrate proficiency in setting up and programming an advanced robotic vision scenario. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 4144

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Data Acquisition and Signal Processing
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Data acquisition hardware and interfaces with different industrial sensors. Software development for data acquisition, signal processing, and real-time actuator control. Hands-on experience through laboratory experiments using commercial hardware and software platforms. Fundamentals of data acquisition Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 112 systems (DASs), analog-to-digital convertors (ADCs), signal conditioning circuit design, actuators and drivers, and DAS design and integration. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 3131

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Control Systems
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Topics include: Fourier and Laplace transforms, signal comparison techniques and transfer functions. Control techniques addressed will include feedback, cascade, feedforward, multivariable and model based methods. Pre-Requisite(s): EET 1121

Electrical Engineering Technology.title: Advanced Programmable Controllers
Electrical Engineering Technology.description: Using Allen Bradley Contr Logix and SLC500 programmable controllers, course covers structured programming, Sequential Function Charts, networking, proportional integral differential control, data acquisition and interfacing. The labs will require students to write and troubleshoot complex PLC programs. Engineering Fundamentals.title: Introduction to 3-D Spatial Visualization
Engineering Fundamentals.description: Intended for first-year engineering students with a demonstrated need for the development of 3-D spatial visualization skills. Topics include isometric sketching, orthographic projection, object transformations, 3-D coordinate systems, patterns folding to 3-D objects, and cross sections of solids.

Engineering Fundamentals.title: Engineering Analysis and Problem Solving
Engineering Fundamentals.description: An introduction to the engineering profession and to its various disciplines. Focuses on developing problem- solving skills, computational skills, and communication skills. Through active, collaborative work, students work on teams to apply the engineering problem-solving method to "real-world" problems. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1121(C) or MA 2160(C) or MA 3160(C)) and (Spatial Visualization Score >= 19 or ENG 1002(C))

Engineering Fundamentals.description: This course will focus on a cross disciplinary subset of systems drawn from engineering, business, and natural science. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 118 Pre-Requisite(s): ENG 2505

Engineering Fundamentals.description: Introduction to sustainable development, resilience, and global grand challenges with emphasis on socio- technical systems. Key topics include earth systems literacy, policy development, corporate social responsibility, ecological economics, sustainability indicators, and industrial/societal applications (e.g. agricultural, mining sustainability, etc,).

Engineering Fundamentals.description: Introduction to engineering design, including modeling, simulation, economic decision making, and reliability. Enterprise.description: Project definition, developing a work breakdown structure, responsibility assignment and milestone development. tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Enterprise.description: Automotive systems engineering and fundamental operating principles including powertrain/propulsion, on- board energy usage, chassis systems, manufacturing, and future application. Course will explore fundamental engineering decisions behind specific automotive, on/off road, and heavy duty vehicles and components.

Enterprise.title: Design for Manufacturing
Enterprise.description: This course supplements courses that address "design for function." Products "designed for manufacturing" are lower cost, higher quality, and have a shorter time to market. The course describes how the capabilities and limitations of common manufacturing processes translate into qualitative design guidelines. Topics include design for casting, forging, sheet metal forming, machining, plastics and assembly. Pre-Requisite(s): ENG 1102

Enterprise.description: A continuous improvement culture is based on humility and respect for people. Problem solving in this environment is highly participative, focuses on the issue not the person, and seeks to empower the employees closest to the work being performed.

Finance.title: Financial Literacy
Finance.description: Developing fluency with consumer financial decisions. Topics include goal setting, budgeting, financial disclosures, interest rate mathematics, funding major purchases, credit and loan matters, savings and investment opportunities, taxation, retirement plans and insurance protection, with an emphasis on evaluating financial alternatives.

Finance.title: Principles of Finance
Finance.description: Introduction to the principles of finance. Topics include financial mathematics, the capital investment decision, financial assets valuation, and the risk-return relationship Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000 and (MA 1020 or MA 1030 or MA 1031 or MA 1032 or MA 1120 or MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121 or MA 2160 or ALEKS Math Placement >= 61 or CEEB Calculus AB >= 2 or CEEB Calculus BC >= 2 or ACT Mathematics >= 22 or SAT MATH SECTION SCORE- M16 >= 540)

Finance.title: Investment Analysis
Finance.description: Overview of financial products. Operations of the stock market, bond market, and other financial markets. Focus on portfolio theory and basic stock and bond valuation techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 3400 or FIN 3000 and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710)

Finance.title: Advanced Financial Management
Finance.description: Advanced topics in managerial finance: Advanced capital budgeting, project analysis, capital acquisition, capital structure and dividend policy, and other topics. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 127 Pre-Requisite(s): EC 3400 or FIN 3000

Finance.title: Derivatives and Financial Engineering
Finance.description: Covers the pricing and use of options, financial futures, swaps, and other derivative securities. Pre-Requisite(s): EC 3400 or FIN 3000 and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710)

Finance.title: Personal Financial Planning
Finance.description: Overview of personal financial issues and services and instruments offered by economic and financial institutions. Topics include the personal financial environment, personal investments and asset management, tax planning, the development of an adequate but cost-effective insurance program, and retirement planning. Pre-Requisite(s): BA 3400 or EC 3400 or FIN 3000

Finance.description: Detailed analysis of equity valuation, including applications and processes, estimation of valuation assumptions, absolute valuation models (dividend discounting, free cash flow and residual income) and relative valuation models (market-based), with a focus on practice-based techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): FIN 3000 or EC 3400

Finance.title: Risk Management
Finance.description: Understand risk and tools for analyzing risk in business. Includes topics such as capital management, bankruptcy, insurance and hedging strategies. Pre-Requisite(s): (FIN 3000 or EC 3400) and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710 or MA 3720)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Finance.description: FinTech is technology that provides financial markets products and services using bleeding-edge technology. Topics include digital banking, currency, and payment systems; algorithmic trading and roboadvising, and techs specializing in API, credit, insurance, investment intelligence, lending, and regulation. Pre-Requisite(s): BA 3400 or EC 3400 or FIN 3000

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Exploring College of Forest Resources and Environmental Science Opportunities
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An exploration of the majors, minors, and other opportunities available in the College of Forest Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 129 Resources and Environmental Science and Michigan Tech. Students will develop a plan to reach their academic and career goals.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wood Anatomy and Properties
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An introduction to the anatomical and physical nature of woody materials and how these characteristics are related to its applications as a sustainable raw material.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: The Natural Resource Professional
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Seminar introduces students to the various careers within forestry, conservation, ecology, and wildlife that represent specialties within natural resources. Students explore natural resource issues around the world, and practice effective written and communication skills.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Vegetation of North America
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Identification and life history of trees, shrubs, and common understory plants of the major forested vegetation types of North America. Including plant morphology, taxonomy, life history traits, and community ecology on trees and forests.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of For Res & Env Sci

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Conservation of Nature
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course explores the history and evolution of conservation in thought and practice, with an emphasis on the writings and legacy of conservation pioneers such as Aldo Leopold.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Field Techniques
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Equipment and techniques used in forestry, wildlife, ecology, and recreation management. Topics include field safety, land measurement and navigation, establishment of sample locations, measurement of attributes of individuals and groups of trees, vegetation and other organisms. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 130

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Fundamentals of Environmental Sustainability
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The four scientific principles of sustainability (reliance on solar energy, biodiversity, nutrient cycling, population control) are the foundation of the course. The course applies basic principles of physics, chemistry, and biology and a systems approach to provide students with a fundamental understanding of how the environment functions and strategies for sustaining natural resources.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Introduction to Bird Watching
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of identifying common birds of Michigan by sight and sound. Students will learn how to use binoculars, how to use field marks, habitat cues, and vocalizations to identify sparrows, warblers, ducks, herons, and up to 200 bird species that are common throughout Eastern North America.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Introduction to Circular Economy
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The circular economy is an emerging cross disciplinary field of study that maps a transition from current linear and unsustainable practices, role of consumers, policy, business models, bioeconomy, design, innovation and technological accelerators.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Introduction to Biochemistry
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course provides a basic knowledge of biochemical processes underlying cellular mechanism in living organisms. It examines the chemical nature of cellular components in plants and animals by relating the structure and function of macromolecules to their effects on the whole system level. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Current Issues in Natural Resources
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Covers timely issues in natural resources research, planning, or management as specified by section title.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Practice of Silviculture
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Methods of controlling the establishment, growth, composition, health and quality of forests and woodlands to meet the diverse needs and values of landowners and society on a sustainable basis. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 131 App Ecol & Environ Sci Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2010 and FW 2051

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Forestry, Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt,

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Survey of Silviculture
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An introduction to the practice of silviculture including ecological principles which form the basis for forest management. The course emphasizes proper use of silviculture terminology and includes field examples of management practices. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Resources Management, Wildlife Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Forestry Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2010 and FW 2051

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Natural

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest Ecology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Environmental factors and plant and animal characteristics which control composition, structure, and function of forest ecosystems. Emphasis on how ecosystems change across space and time and knowledge needed to sustainably manage forest ecosystems for social, economic, and ecological benefits. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2051(C)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Introduction to Biotechnology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The course covers basic concepts and practical applications in biotechnology. Topics include the use of biotechnology in agriculture, healthcare, and environmental remediation. Advances in gene containment, regulatory, societal and environmental issues associated with commercialization of biotechnological products will be discussed.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Mechanics of Solid Wood and Wood Composites
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An overview of the mechanical properties of wood that are related to engineering and structural applications of lumber, timber, and wood composite panels. of Engineering; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of For Res & Env Sci, College

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest Biomaterials
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Examines the nature and use of forest biomaterials and their role in the larger economy. Local and global advantages and challenges for using forest biomaterials will be addressed within the context of Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 132 sustainability, covering topics such as economics, material and product engineering, policy, life cycle analysis, and supply chain management.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Adding Value to Forest Biomaterials
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Examines how forest biomaterials are converted from raw forms into intermediary or final products that can support a sustainable future. Manufacturing sites in the upper Midwest are visited during the week prior to the start of fall semester. Lecture topics include the forest bioeconomy, emerging and export markets, and industry challenges. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 1035

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Natural Resource Policy
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Covers concepts related to social systems and natural resources. Explores natural resource policy foundations and partners, rights and responsibilities, and approaches and practices within and between state, tribal, and federal levels of policy making, policy processes, implementation, and evaluation.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wild Foods: Northern Forests
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This class engages students online and in the field in learning practical skills utilizing vegetation of the northern forest for food, medicines, and utilitarian purposes. The course provides a basic overview of cultural and historical importance of the interactions between people and plants.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Human Dimensions of Wildlife Conservation
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Integration of competing stakeholder objectives affects wildlife conservation and management outcomes. Federal law including the Endangered Species Act (ESA), domestic and international treaties, and Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) are introduced. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 1050

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Ethnobotany
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The development and variety of plant use across cultures, the transition to commercialization of plants, how current uses are tied to traditional uses, and methods of ethnobotanical research. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 133 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Timber Harvesting
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Methods and techniques used in lake states timber harvesting systems. Introduces best management practices, aesthetic and ecological impacts, logging cost analysis, timber appraisal, and timber sale preparation and administration. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2051

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Forestry

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Land Measurements and GPS
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Introduces field measurements and computations involved in determining direction, distance, and area. Covers the hand compass, pacing, and use of GPS, including differential correction. Integration of GPS data with GIS is emphasized. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Resources Management, Wildlife Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Forestry Co-Requisite(s): FW 3190 Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3540

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Natural

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Geomorphology, Landscapes and Ecosystems
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Provides basic understanding of the geologic and glacial processes that shaped the landscape of the Upper Midwest influencing the distribution and productivity of modern-day plant communities. Topics include geology of Michigan, glacial geomorphology, soil development, landscape and community ecology, and forestry. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Natural Resources Management; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Wildlife

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Multi-resource Assessment
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Develops a basic proficiency in the application of multiple-resource measurement techniques. Gain familiarity with the application of individual tree and landscape measurements as well as estimation of growth, sampling techniques, computational procedures, and mapping procedures commonly used in forest and land management. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 134 Resources Management, Wildlife Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Forestry Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2051 and FW 3020 and FW 3200 and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Natural

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Biometrics and Data Analysis
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Sampling design, implementation and analysis for inventory and monitoring of attributes of stands, forests and landscapes. Includes computing skills for data entry, storage and analysis and application of statistical techniques to answer questions about ecological data. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2051 and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Sustainability Science
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Foundational scientific concepts (dynamic systems and catastrophe theory) as applied to socioecological systems. Use of indicators and indices to track progress towards sustainability goals. Review of local, national, and global sustainability policies to avoid catastrophes and guide sustainable development. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Fundamentals of Forest Genetics and Genomics
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course will teach fundamental and applied genetic principles that are essential for management of forest and other ecosystems to maintain their long-term health and sustainability. The class will cover the following topics: structure and function of DNA, inheritance, molecular evolution, population and quantitative genetics, gene conservation, genomics and biotechnology. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1400 or BL 2160

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Soil Science
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Introduction to the chemical, physical, and biological properties of soil. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112(C) or (CH 1150(C) and CH 1151(C))

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest & Environmental Resource Management (The FERM) I
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Application of forest and environmental management practices by teams of students with the assistance of faculty, staff and local and regional partners. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 135 Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2010 and FW 2051

tags.Credits: 2.0; May be repeated

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest & Environmental Resource Management (The FERM) II
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Application of forest and environmental management practices by teams of students with the assistance of faculty, staff, and local and regional partners. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2010 and FW 2051

tags.Credits: 3.0; May be repeated

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Conservation Science
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Introduction to biological, social, political, and economic facets of conservation science. Evaluating how best to maintain and restore species, populations, and ecosystems. Topics include human impacts on ecosystems, how science informs strategies, conservation challenges, policy, planning, structured decision making.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Outdoor Recreation and Tourism
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Covers background on Americans and leisure; overview of primary providers of recreation in the US; management of outdoor recreation, measuring and valuing outdoor recreation and tourism; recreation and tourism in the Great Lakes region. Requires participation in field trips/workshops.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: An Introduction to Geographic Information Systems for Natural Resource Management
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The fundamentals of GIS and its application to natural resource management. Spatial data, its uses and limitations are evaluated. Students work extensively with the ARCGIS software package. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2710(C) or MA 2720(C) or MA 3710(C) or ENVE 3502 or CEE 3502(C)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wildlife Habitat
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Understand the ecological basis for management of forest wildlife and how forest management influences wildlife populations. Laboratory introduces techniques in wildlife research and management, especially methods of habitat analysis. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Resources Management, Wildlife Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Forestry; May not be Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 136 enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Natural

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wildlife Research Techniques
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Techniques used by managers and researchers when working with wildlife. Scientific method, scientific writing, and principles of study design are introduced. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 2051(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Ornithology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An ecological and evolutionary approach to the study of birds. Topics include behavioral, anatomical, and physiological adaptations to flight, life history, mating systems, migration, communication and conservation. Laboratory emphasizes identification and experimental use of birds as model organisms. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1040 or BL 1020 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Field Ornithology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An introduction to field techniques and identification. Weekend trip to Whitefish Point Bird Observatory during spring migration and field note taking.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Human Dimensions in Natural Resources Stewardship
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Uses sociological concepts to enhance understanding of shared natural resource stewardship regimes, including human-environment relationships, beliefs and values, rights and responsibilities associated with sovereignty; and the diversity of knowledge systems and expertise related to natural resource practices and policies. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Maple Syrup Management and Culture
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Overviews cultural and historical importance of syrup production. Topics include methods of collecting and processing sap, syrup, sugar, and business marketing of maple products. Course includes lab experience at Nara Family Maple Center. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Insect Ecology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 137 Insects are widespread and diverse components of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. This course will consider aspects of insect ecology, including biodiversity and conservation of insects, the effects of biotic and abiotic factors on insect populations, and the trophic diversity of insects. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Natural Resources Management

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Wildlife

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest Health
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Drawing on examples from the Great Lakes region, and other parts of North America, this course will consider which type of insects and pathogens attack our trees and forests, how they interact with each other, and what tools we can use to effectively reduce their negative impacts of forest pests. Course held at Ford Center, Alberta, MI. Resources Management, Wildlife Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Forestry Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3020

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Natural

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Animal Behavior
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Examines how animal behavior is shaped by developmental and evolutionary processes. Explores the effects of inheritance, environment, and intra-and inter-species interactions on animal behavior. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1040 or (BL 1400 and BL 1410) or BL 1010 or (BL 1100 and BL 1110) and (BL 1020 or BL 1200 and BL 1210)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Professional Experience Program
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Students create oral/written reports and reflection based on paid or volunteered work or field experience in natural resources.

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 4
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Bioproducts Internship
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Provides a directed work experience related to sustainable bioproducts. Requires a detailed proposal and written summary product. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 138 College of For Res & Env Sci; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Sustainable Bioproducts; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 3; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s):

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Public Health and the Environment
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Explores how the environment impacts the health of individuals and entire populations. Topics will include exposure to environmental hazards and natural disasters, access to green and blue space and the built environment.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Deterioration and Preservation of Sustainable Biomaterials
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Biological factors causing degradation of wood and the technologies for preservation and protection of wood-based materials.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Ge-izhi-mawanji’idiyang dazhindamang gidakiiminaan (the way we meet to talk
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: about our earth) This course invites Ojibwa community guests to share cultural, ecological, and governance knowledge with students who will develop a better understanding of our shared environment, career and higher education opportunities, and will be better prepared for engaging with and as natural resource and environmental science professionals.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest Economics & Finance
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Financial analysis and economic theory applied to forestry project analysis and selection, focusing on prices. Covers risk, capital markets, taxation, auctions, and non-market valuation.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Gene Expression Data Analysis
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course is designed for students majoring in molecular biology, computer science, data science and related majors to develop fundamental but essential skills for manipulating, preprocessing, and analyzing high throughput gene expression data for pattern extraction and knowledge discovery. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 139 Pre-Requisite(s): FW 4099 or CS 1121 or CS 1122 or CS 1131 or CS 1141 or CS 2321

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Programming Skills for Bioinformatics
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Students will learn computer programming skills in Perl for processing genomic sequences and gene expression data and become familiar with various bioinformatics resources. Pre-Requisite(s): CS 1121

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Indigenous Natural Resource Management
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: In this course, students gain knowledge in indigenous history, culture, and policy to enhance understanding of the rights and privileges associated with treaties, government-to-government relationship, and diversity of people, practices and values. Students engage in multidisciplinary scholarship with relevance for today's shared management regime. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Tree Seedling Production and Greenhouse Management
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Covers how plants are grown from seed and vegetative propagules like cuttings. Topics include principles and techniques involved in raising plants for garden, horticulture, and forestry uses. Traditional and modern techniques will be covered. Students gain hands-on experience in greenhouse management.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Tree Physiology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: A study of tree structure, growth, development and function, and how these are related to the environment. We will focus on the cycling of water, carbon, and nutrients within the context of global change.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Conservation Genetics
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course will explore molecular methods as they apply to conservation, management, ecology, and evolution of wildlife. We will emphasize laboratory techniques and the application of genetic theory. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 140 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1040 or BL 1020 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Stand & Forest Modeling
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Use of models that simulate tree, stand, and forest development. Emphasis on critical evaluation of model designs, outputs, uses in silvicultural decision-making, and forest to landscape management and planning. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3010 or FW 3012 and FW 3540(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest and Natural Resource Management
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Focuses on forest and natural resources management planning and decision making. Emphasizes structured problem solving frameworks and decision support tools/models. Three field trips to meet with natural resources professionals and discuss site-specific management issues and approaches. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3010 or FW 3012

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Advanced Timber Harvesting
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Quantitative methods for evaluation of harvesting systems, equipment, and transportation. Emphasizes detailed logging cost analysis, machine rates, depreciation, productivity, and optimization. Includes use of software, GIS and systems of equations. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3150

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Forestry

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Consulting Forestry
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: For students who are considering consulting forestry as a career. Covers issues specific to working with private landowners, stewardship plan writing, choosing a business entity, marketing, taxes, income/expenses, insurance, timber sale administration, and resolving landowner disputes.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Ethics of Conservation and Sustainability
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Discusses relationship between ecological science and environmental ethics as it relates to natural resource management, conversation and sustainability. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 141

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wetlands
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Study of the physical, chemical, and biological characteristics of wetlands. Describes functions and values of individual wetland types. Presents management of wetlands and laws governing wetlands. Labs concentrate on field techniques used to assess specific plant, animal, soil, and hydrological characteristics of wetlands. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1100 or BL 1400 or BL 2160 or BL 3080

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Mammalogy
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Study of mammals, emphasizing their evolution, taxonomic relationships, structural and physiological adaptations and life histories through discussion, laboratory and field work, emphasizes the identification conservation and management of mammals, especially species found in western Great Lakes. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1020 or BL 1040 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: The Wolves and Moose of Isle Royale
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Wolves and moose have been studied for 50 years on Isle Royale, a wilderness island in Lake Superior. The instructor leads this research and uses the research to explain predation, population dynamics, conservation genetics, and other ecological principles.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Population Ecology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Covers the principles of population ecology. Topics include measures of populations, population dynamics, and models used to describe the theories related to population dynamics.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wildland Fire
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Overview of wildland fire based on an understanding of fire history, fuel properties, fire weather, fire behavior, ecological effects and management. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3020 and (FW 3010 or FW 3012) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 142

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Forest and Landscape Hydrology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The course will use a process-based approach to present the physical hydrology, geomorphology and water quality of forested watersheds. Course focuses on the interaction between watershed processes and forest management.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Snow Hydrology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course will cover snow formation in the atmosphere, snow accumulation and distribution, snow metamorphism, avalance dynamics, snowmelt and runoff, remote sensing of snow properties, and the impact of forests and under-snow biogeochemical processes. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2710 or MA 2720

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Landscape Ecology and Planning
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Basic principles of landscape ecology, including pattern, process, and scale. Students will learn how to use quantitative tools to study landscape-scale patterns and processes, and how to apply these principles and tools to conservation, resource management, and planning issues. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2720 or CEE 3502

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Urban Forestry
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Urban forestry is the science and art of managing natural resources in communities. It focuses on maximizing the wide range of economic, environmental, and social benefits associated with trees and urban greenspaces while minimizing maintenance costs and reducing tree-related risks.

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Urban Forestry Lab
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The urban forestry field lab is a two-day tour held in Chicago for students to interact with and learn from professionals in the green industry, arboriculture, and urban forestry. It coincides with the Midwest Urban Tree Care Forum in mid-April. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 143 Pre-Requisite(s): FW 4400(C)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Independent Study
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Guided study or research on an approved forest resource or other natural resource topic with a chosen faculty member.

tags.Credits: variable to 7.0; Repeatable to a Max of 7
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Remote Sensing of the Environment
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Remote sensing principles and concepts. Topics include camera and digital sensor arrays, types of imagery, digital data structures, spectral reflectance curves, applications, and introductory digital image processing.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Map Design with GIS
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Principles of making maps, from traditional to advanced visualization techniques, that convey information which is useful in decision making at many levels. Focus will be on creating maps using GIS software and digital data. A working knowledge of ArcGIS is required. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3540 or FW 5550

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: GPS Field Techniques
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This course will provide hands-on experience with various types of GPS units and different applications of the technology. These applications include planning, data collection, data processing, and data management. Emphasis will be on practical applications of Global Positioning System technology. be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Wildlife Ecology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Covers the ecological basis for management of wildlife, including biological and sociological factors that influence management. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 3400(C) or FW 3020(C) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 144

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Herpetology
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: The biology of amphibians and reptiles, including evolution, zoogeography, ecology, behavior and physiology. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1040 or BL 1020 or (BL 1200 and BL 1210) or (BL 1400 and BL 1410)

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Environmental Biogeochemistry
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Impacts of decisions regarding landuse, land management, and energy and mineral exploration on natural resources (i.e., air, water, land, and biodiversity) are discussed using the framework of the biogeochemical cycles of the elements. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Communication for Natural Resource Professionals
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: This class completes the development of oral and written communication skills for students as they prepare to graduate and gain employment in the field of natural resources. Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3190

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Integrated Resource Assessment Data Collection
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Students will collect field data needed for writing their Integrated Resource Assessment management plans. Field skills and ability to summarize and display data will be assessed. Students will develop appropriate sampling designs, collect needed field data with acceptable error limits, and summarize the data. Resources Management, Wildlife Ecology & Cons, App Ecol & Environ Sci, Forestry Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3190

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Wildlife Ecology & Mgmt, Natural

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Integrated Natural Resource Assessment
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Course provides a capstone experience by integrating techniques from many of the forestry, applied ecology, wildlife ecology, and natural resources management core courses. Culminates in the development of management plans for various natural resource alternatives. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 145 Pre-Requisite(s): FW 4811

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Senior Research Thesis
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: An independent study or research project on an approved topic in Forestry, Applied Ecology and Environmental Sciences, Wildlife Ecology, or Natural Resource Management, under the guidance of a faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year. Senior Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3190

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.title: Environmental Science and Sustainability Capstone
Forest Resources and Environmental Scien.description: Provides a capstone experience by integrating knowledge and skills from the major core courses. Culminates in the development of a synthesis of literature and/or data related to an environmental science issue relevant to climate change, natural resource policy and geospatial sciences. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior Pre-Requisite(s): FW 3020 and FW 3110 and FW 3540 Geolog. & Mining Engrg & Sci.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Environ Sci & Sustainability; Must be

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Geological Engineering and Sciences Orientation
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to geosciences as a profession, including discussions of career opportunities and geoscience programs. Earth materials and the earth's processes are also introduced. Includes frequent field trips. Intended for freshman or sophomore students in geological engineering, geology, applied geophysics, hydrology, geotechnics, earth science teaching, or any other geoscience program. Sciences and Arts, General Engineering, Mining Engineering, Applied Geophysics, Geology; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Geological Engineering, General

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Introduction to Data Science for Earth Resource Applications
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Computational tools used in mining and geological engineering are introduced in earth resource contexts. Approaches for setting up, testing, and applying tools to solve practical problems are demonstrated and practiced. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 146 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1121(C)

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Understanding the Earth
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to materials and processes that shape the earth we live on. Lecture and laboratories acquaint students with minerals, rocks, earth resources, weathering, geologic time, landslides, groundwater, streams, shorelines, deserts, glaciers, geologic structures, earthquakes, plate tectonics, and the dynamics of the earth's crust, mantle, and core.

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course covers basics in geospatial science from theoretical concepts, data, models, analytical techniques, to practical usage, and applications. Topics will include: fundamental concepts of cartography and mapping systems, characteristics and structure of GIS data, database construction, introduction to GIS data sources, principles and methods in spatial analysis, spatial interpolation, mapping of spatial and applications of GIS. Course will have lab using industry standard software tools. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Introduction to Mining Engineering and Mining Methods
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Learn how various mining components, from prospecting to financing to reclamation, fit together. Includes advantages and drawbacks of different mining methods and their selection. Introduces ethics and professional development. Use of basic computer and mine design software.

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Environmental Geology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction and study of current environmental issues related to the earth sciences. Covers major topics such as volcanism, earthquakes, shoreline erosion, and pollution of groundwater as multi-week modules with associated labs, lectures, and field projects.

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Mineral Science
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Chemical composition, crystal structure, physical properties, and identification of minerals. Environmental controls on their formation. Formation processes, characterization of and exploration of ore deposits. Laboratory focuses on hand specimen identification and introduction to X-ray diffraction and SEM mineral analysis techniques. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 147 Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1000 or CH 1112 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Introduction to Petrology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Identification, physical properties, chemical composition, occurrence, and origin of the important types of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks. Laboratory includes hand specimen description and identification of rocks. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2300

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Mining Methods and Systems
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course presents a study of the surface and underground mining methods practiced in coal, metal, and aggregate mine operations, classification of mining methods, support design and equipment selection, general mine planning requirements, mine development sequence, cycle of operations, and method application. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2020

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Atmospheric Observations and Meteorology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to fundamentals of atmospheric science and meteorology through direct observations of the atmosphere.

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Introduction to Field Methods
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to geology field methods including maps, cross sections, navigation, GPS, field mineral and rock ID, and measurements of geologic features. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2300 and GE 2310 and GE 3050

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Fundamentals of Applied and Environmental Geophysics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: An introduction to geophysical used in applied and environmental geophysics concentrating on the fundamentals of data reduction and interpretation. This course is not only pertinent for the practicing geoscientist but also for environmental engineers, civil engineers, and others interested in learning how physics can be used to investigate Earth's substance. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 2200 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 148

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Structural Geology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Rock structures and regional settings resulting from the application of deforming forces, including the geometry, origin, and mechanics of folds, foliations, lineations, faults ad joints, and structures in orogenic belts. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Depositional Systems
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to sedimentary processes and their products. Investigates the physical processes controlling sedimentation along with principles of correlation and interpretation of strata. Focuses on interpreting sedimentary rocks as a record of climate, sea-level and tectonic change. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000 and GE 2310

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Geochemistry
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to elements of modern geochemistry including aqueous solutions, isotopes, age dating, etc. Emphasizes concepts and quantitative methods. Teaches principles of thermodynamics and phase equilibria from an introductory perspective as they pertain to geologic systems. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and CH 1151

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Computational Geosciences
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to quantitative analysis and display of geologic data using R/Matlab, covering basic R/Matlab syntax and programming, and analysis of one-dimensional (e.g. time series) and two- dimensional datasets (i.e. spatial data). Techniques are applied to geological datasets. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Earth History
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course covers the history of the Earth from 4.5 billion years to the present. Plate tectonics is the organizing theme with emphasis on recognizing and evaluating the evidence for the major reorganizations of the Earth's crust. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 149 Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000 or GE 2100

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Drilling, Blasting, and Mine Safety Engineering
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Rock penetration and fragmentation methods and boring, cutting, drilling, and blasting techniques. Design of surface and underground blasting rounds. Formulation of design criteria to minimize the adverse effects of blasting. Field demonstration in the design, monitoring, and evaluation of blasts. Principles of health/safety in mine practice. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2020 and PH 2100 and MA 2160

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Geohydrology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Geologic and hydrologic factors controlling the occurrence, movement, and development of subsurface water. Quantitative methods for analyzing groundwater systems are introduced.

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Resource & Reserve Estimation
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course covers the classification of resource and reserve; resource estimation algorithms; linear, nonlinear, and indicator kriging; stochastic simulation; variogram modeling; block-variance relationship; recoverable reserve; and introduction to resource estimation software. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2020 and MA 3710

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Mine Planning and Design
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Course provides the basics of mine planning, feasibility study, block modeling, economic analysis, cost estimation and price forecasting, mining method selection algorithms. Introduction and hands-on experience with mine planning and design software including Surpac, Vulcan, and Whittle. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2320 and GE 3400 and GE 3870

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Engineering Geology and Rock Mechanics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Course will cover collection, analysis, and interpretation of geological data and information required for the safe development of civil works. Course will include laboratory experiments to determine the physical and mechanical properties of rocks, including hardness, tensile, and compressive strength. Pre-Requisite(s): (GE 2000 or GE 2100) and (GE 3050 or ENG 2120 or MEEM 2150)

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Field Geophysics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 150 Introduction to field geophysical techniques including basic land surveying. Emphasizes the recording, reduction, presentation, and interpretation of gravity, magnetic, electrical, seismic, and electromagnetic data as well as the proper use, care, and calibration of equipment used to collect the data. Requires report writing. Students must provide their own transportation. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 3040 and GE 3010

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Field Geology with Engineering Applications
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to methods and problems of field geology, interpretation of field relationships, and engineering site investigation. Field areas are located in northern Michigan. Requires geological and/or engineering report and memo writing. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000 and GE 2310 and GE 3050 and GE 3010

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Environmental Geophysics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Students will learn the geophysical methods including seismic (refraction, topography, and surface wave methods), ground penetrating radar (GPR), electromagnetic (EM), electrical resistivity, and gravity to address near surface environmental and geotechnical issues. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 3040(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Natural Hazards
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course focuses on current mitigation agencies and warning systems, case studies of successes and failures in hazard mitigation, and technical tools for hazard study and mitigation such as satellite remote sensing and GIS. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000 or GE 2100

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Volcanology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Volcanoes and how they work. Volcanic eruption styles and products, their recognition, and significance. Volcanic hazards, volcano monitoring and impacts of volcanism on the environment, climate and society. Applies chemistry, physics, and fluid mechanics in a volcanological context. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 151 Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000 and (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Magma Reservoir Dynamics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Introduction to topics in advanced igneous petrology emphasizing processes that occur in magma reservoirs. Includes the application and integration of geochemistry, petrology, and geochronology to investigate magma dynamics and their influence on frequency, style, and magnitude of eruptions. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2300 and GE 2310

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Mining Systems and The Environment
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Develops the scientific basis for environmental management in ecosystems impacted by mining activities. Considers the origin, behavior, and fate of pollutants generated during the life of a mine. Introduces engineered approaches for mitigation, remediation and reclamation of environmental impacts. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Fundamentals of Remote Sensing
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course focuses on the basic physics behind above- surface remote sensing and remote sensing systems. Topics covered include: properties of the atmosphere, absorption and scattering of electromagnetic radiation, instrument design, data acquisition and processing, validation, and basic applications. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 2200 and MA 2160

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Mine Ventilation Engineering
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Course deals with an introduction to mine ventilation, properties of air, gases, and dust, mine fans and its applications, flow distribution in mine network, computer analysis of ventilation network, mine health and safety overview, health and safety culture and practice. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2020 and GE 2320 and (ENG 3200 or CEE 3200) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 152

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Bulk Materials Dynamics & Engineering
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Surface and underground materials handling methods. Selection and performance analysis of materials handling equipment. Computer applications. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 2100 and GE 2320 and ENG 2120

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Planetary Geology & Geophysics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Geological, geophysical, and geochemical processes in the Solar System are examined. Topics include the formation and evolution of the Solar System, planetary surface processes and water distribution, impact structures, composition, structure, and dynamics of planetary interiors, geophysical exploration of planets. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2000 and PH 2200 and MA 2160

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Earthquake Seismology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Course covers fundamentals of the physics of earthquakes and seismic energy propagation, and seismic methods to determine Earth structure. Emphasis is placed on natural source techniques, with extension to exploration applications. Weekly labs apply techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 3050 and PH 2100

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Reflection Seismology
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Principles of reflection seismic techniques, including theoretical background and application, and hands-on computer projects. Included are acquisition, data processing, and 2D/3D data interpretation. Students conduct projects using actual commercial-quality seismic data. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 3040

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Formation Evaluation and Petroleum Engineering
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Principles and practice of formation evaluation, primarily through analysis of well logs and the principles and practice of petroleum engineering. Emphasizes reservoir engineering and simulation. Students conduct projects using actual field data. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 153

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Operation Research for Mining Engineers
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: This course introduces the statistical analysis of mining data, statistical decision making of mining projects, random number generation, Monte Carlo methods, simulation methods, linear and integer programming, queueing theory, stochastic-process, PERT and CPM, applications of operations research (OR) in mining and mineral industry. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 2020 or GE 2320

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Groundwater Engineering
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Application of geohydrology principles to design water-well supplies, site investigations, and subsurface remediation systems. Pre-Requisite(s): GE 3850 or CEE 3810

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Computer Methods in Geomechanics
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Computer methods for the design problems encountered in encountered in geo-engineering projects. Applications to be selected from landslide stability analysis, slope stabilization and design, earth support systems, seepage, settlement, bearing capacity, and consolidation. Students will be introduced to limit equilibrium and finite element analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): CEE 3810 or GE 3890

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Capstone I
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Capston engineering design course focusing on a realistic, complex, open-ended engineering problem. Project includes technical design, economic analysis, environmental impacts, and regulations. Report writing required. (Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites).

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.title: Capstone II
Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Capstone engineering design course focusing on a realistic, complex, open-ended engineering problem. Project includes technical design, economic analysis, environmental impacts, and regulations. Report writing required. (Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites). Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 154 Pre-Requisite(s): GE 4900

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Geological and Mining Engineering and Sc.description: Study and discussion of geological engineering topics.

Human Factors.title: Introduction to the Human Factors Major
Human Factors.description: Human Factors majors examine the field of human factors and major degree requirements resulting in an undergraduate plan of study focused on graduate school admission or career preparation. Students will be introduced to department research and other opportunities. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 155

Human Factors.title: Introduction to Engineering Psychology
Human Factors.description: This class will examine the capabilities and limitations of human perception and cognition and the application of theories and principles of human performance to the design.

Human Factors.title: Human Factors
Human Factors.description: This class will focus on when, why, and how to apply the various human factors methods for creating more effective human-technological systems. Pre-Requisite(s): (PSY 2000 or HF 2000) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Human Factors.title: Human Factors Third Year Seminar
Human Factors.description: A practical, task-based course to help you synthesize your post-bachelor's degree plans and goals. Involves work on applying to an advanced educational program or conducting a job search. in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Human Factors.description: Introduction to this cognitive-systems engineering method that unpacks complex work through systematic interviews with experts. Students will collect data to address engineering, business, or socio- technical challenges. Pre-Requisite(s): (PSY 2000 or HF 2000) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Human Factors.title: Human Factors in Healthcare
Human Factors.description: Course will explore the current human factors concepts and methods in health and medical applications.

Human Factors.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 156 Explore the concept of usability and how this is assessed and applied to various products, interfaces, systems, and information with a focus on heuristic evaluation, cognitive walkthroughs, card sorting, tree testing, surveys, interviews, and ISO standards.

Honors, Pavlis.title: Creating Your Path
Honors, Pavlis.description: This course guides students in using life-design methods to create achievement paths for education, career, and life goals. Using activities, discussion, and reflection, students develop a framework for success through principles of design thinking, problem solving, creativity, and communication. Freshman, Sophomore

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Honors, Pavlis.title: Pavlis Seminar I
Honors, Pavlis.description: First seminar in the Pavlis Honors Pathway, this course introduces the theory and concepts of adult development, motivation, critical reflection, and leadership through active and reflective learning. Students apply design thinking to develop Pathway components, focusing on the immersion experience.

Honors, Pavlis.title: Entering Research I
Honors, Pavlis.description: This course introduces students new to research to best practices and skills related to university-level research and scholarship. Topics include developing a mentoring relationship, engaging with scholarly literature, documenting research, and ensuring research integrity in proposals and in communication findings. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 157

The Honors Abilities of communicating empathetically and balancing confidence and humility are addressed. Honors, Pavlis.description: This course introduces students to the processes and tools associated with human-centered design (HCD). HCS is a key process used in identifying needs/opportunities and innovative solutions.

Honors, Pavlis.title: Leadership Practicum
Honors, Pavlis.description: This course is designed for the Leadership Minor. It allows for non-international leadership experience and practical application of leadership knowledge, skills and behaviors. The practicum experience will be designed and implemented by the student, with guidance from the instructor. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 158 Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 3100 or AF 3001

Honors, Pavlis.title: Pavlis Seminar III
Honors, Pavlis.description: In this final Pavlis Honors Pathway seminar, students use a self-authorship framework to develop their own voice while engaging with other perspectives through learning partnerships. Difficult dialogues, decision making, critical thinking, and the synthesis and sharing of experiences are expected. Pre-Requisite(s): HON 3150 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Honors, Pavlis.title: Experiential Learning in Cross-Cultural Immersions
Honors, Pavlis.description: This course allows student having combined classroom training and at least 50 hours of field experience with cross-cultural and community partners to reflect on connections and puzzles between personal experience and scholarly writing on social change, culture, and social problems.

Honors, Pavlis.title: Introduction to the Fundamentals of Social Innovation and Social Entrepreneurship
Honors, Pavlis.description: In this course, students will be exposed to key concepts and practices around social innovation and entrepreneurship. They will learn different approaches to social entrepreneurship, and the strengths and weaknesses of various models and strategies.

Scientific & Tech Comm (BA), Communication, Culture & Media, English Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 159

Humanities.description: Introduction to the study of global Hispanic, Francophone, and Germanic cultures as expressed in film, literature, and language. Emphasis on cultural awareness and understanding of cultural differences. Taught in English.

Humanities.title: Transitional Level I Spanish Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Intensive review of basic Spanish grammar, vocabulary, and culture. Designed to prepare students with minimum essentials of oral and written Spanish for intermediate and advanced level work. Students completing this course may apply for placement credit. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2291 or Language Placement Spanish >= 201

Humanities.title: Introduction to Film
Humanities.description: Focuses on critical engagement with cinematic form and its relationship to cultural, historical, and/or theoretical contexts.

Humanities.title: Ways of Reading
Humanities.description: This course introduces students to reading strategies, critical vocabularies, and critical writing practices. Individual sections will center on a unifying question or problem, emphasizing attentive reading, critical thinking, and qualitative interpretation of literary texts.

Humanities.title: American Experience in Literature
Humanities.description: A survey of major works in American Literature from origins to the present. Focuses on historical trends in the development of literature and culture in the Americas with particular emphasis on the United States.

Humanities.title: Introduction to Literature
Humanities.description: Survey of transnational or transatlantic literary traditions, highlighting select historical periods such as Romanticism, and/or movements, such as the Harlem Renaissance.

Humanities.title: Humanities, Science, and Technology
Humanities.description: Uses approaches from humanities disciplines to contextualize and examine scientific and technological Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 162 developments as well as representations of science and technology. May include the study of literary texts, narrative history, documentary evidence, film, music, popular culture, and cross-cultural references.

Humanities.title: Intro to Creative Writing
Humanities.description: An introduction to creative writing with readings in contemporary and emerging literatures. Genres covered may include fiction, nonfiction, poetry, and screenplay. This course stresses individual production through process-oriented writing exercises, small group workshops, individual conferences, and creative theory.

Humanities.title: British Experience in Literature
Humanities.description: A survey of selected works of British literature from its origins to the present. Focuses on historical trends in the development of the English language and the cultures of Great Britain.

Humanities.title: Young Adult Literature
Humanities.description: Reading, reflecting on, and responding to age-appropriate adolescent literature. Works include authors from different races, cultures, historical periods, and genders. Discussion may be supplemented with films. Appropriate for students who plan to be parents, community volunteers, and teachers.

Humanities.title: Introduction to the Field of Scientific and Technical Communication
