Humanities.description: An introduction to the history, theory, and practice of scientific and technical communication as preparation for future study. Scientific & Tech Comm (BA)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Scientific & Tech Comm (BS),

Humanities.title: Fundamentals of Digital Photography
Humanities.description: Explores the history, aesthetics, theory, and practice of photography in the digital environment. Students learn in-depth digital camera and imaging production techniques. Students provide their own digital camera, preferably a digital SLR. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 163

Humanities.title: Fundamentals of Digital Imaging
Humanities.description: Explores the history, aesthetic, theory, and practice of digital imaging. Students learn to find, make, and analyze images.

Humanities.title: Introduction to Digital Media
Humanities.description: Basic principles, practices and implications of digital media communication and production. Provides foundation in tools, techniques and processes through hands-on production, readings, discussion and analysis of contemporary issues related to digital media.

Humanities.title: Graphic and Information Design
Humanities.description: A computer-intensive introduction to the principles for creating clear, effective graphic communication. Students critique the work of other designers in terms of the work's audience and intended effect, and they construct and critique their own design projects as well.

Humanities.title: Introduction to Philosophy
Humanities.description: A study of thought representing various traditions such as classical and contemporary philosophy, Eastern and Western religion, and issues in recent science. Some basic concepts of logic are also examined. Emphasizes moral philosophy, including ethical relativism, utilitarianism, and Kantian ethics.

Humanities.title: Logic and Critical Thinking
Humanities.description: Introduction to everyday reasoning and formal logic. Important goal is to develop skills of argument identification, analysis, and evaluation. Students learn how to symbolize ordinary language statements and arguments and to determine their validity or invalidity using proof and truth-table methods.

Humanities.title: Ethical Theory and Moral Problems
Humanities.description: An introduction to the major concepts and theories of normative ethics and metaethics and an examination of a variety of issues in applied ethics including poverty and economic justice, lying and truth-telling, euthanasia, sexual conduct, and issues in communication ethics. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 164

Humanities.title: Research and Writing in Communication
Humanities.description: Prepare students to evaluate, design, and conduct research in communication. Develops research- related writing strategies and proficiency. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015(C)

Humanities.title: Communication and Culture
Humanities.description: Introduction to the ways that communication creates and maintains culture. Considers a variety of perspectives on the significance of communication. Explores the importance of communication for understanding culture

Humanities.title: Public Speaking & Multimedia
Humanities.description: Introduces the fundamentals of public speaking and multimedia applications. Emphasis on speaking/listening competencies in face-to-face and digital environments using online and digital tools.

Humanities.title: Interpersonal Communication and Technology
Humanities.description: Examines practices and issues of relational communication and encourages critical awareness of common assumptions. Topics include computer-mediated communication, communicating with machine verbal and nonverbal cues, conflict models, friendship, intimacy, and the interpersonal significance of race, gender, class, and disability.

Humanities.title: Language and Mind
Humanities.description: Linguistic study of structural and cognitive aspects of language. Examines language design: how sounds, words, sentences, and conversation create meaning; the relationship of language, brain, mind, and thought; the ability of humans, animals, and machines to acquire language.

Humanities.title: Language and Society
Humanities.description: Examines how societies use and organize themselves with respect to language. Considers attitudes towards language standardization and dialectal variations within the US based on geography, class, ethnicity, gender, age, etc., and speakers' choices of how they present themselves linguistically. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 165

Humanities.title: Advanced Composition
Humanities.description: Advanced instruction in composing substantive arguments based on primary and secondary research. Multidisciplinary inquiry-based projects ask students to write for both academic and lay audiences in print and digital forms. Specific research methods, writing technologies, and topics vary by section. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Technical and Professional Communication
Humanities.description: A study of written and oral communication in technical and scientific environments; emphasizes audience, writing processes, genres of scientific and technical discourse, visual communication, collaboration, professional responsibility, clear and correct expression. Students write and revise several documents and give oral report(s). Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Humanities.title: Technical Communication for Humanities Majors
Humanities.description: Technical communication from the perspective of a technical writer who works in the private or public sector. Students learn and practice various genres of technical communication, including proposals, reports, instructions, procedures, and policies. Scientific & Tech Comm (BA), Communication, Culture & Media, English; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Scientific & Tech Comm (BS),

Humanities.title: Rhetoric of Science and Technology
Humanities.description: A study of contemporary theories of rhetoric and their application to interpreting and critiquing various forms of persuasive discourse, especially in science and technology. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Topics in Literacy Studies
Humanities.description: A study of how and why different groups of people use reading and writing differently in varying situations and in varying textual media. Topics may include the various ways texts function and reading is used; the authority of written texts; access to reading and writing and to various textual media. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 166 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: The Rhetoric of Everyday Texts
Humanities.description: The examination and production of social media in terms of its theoretical, historical, cultural, and technological contexts. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Level II-A Chinese Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Review and continued study of listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Chinese. Students learn how to communicate in Chinese societies. Includes study of various aspects of the Chinese culture. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2202 or Language Placement Chinese >= 201

Humanities.title: Level II-B Chinese Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Further study of Chinese language. Includes study of vocabulary, idioms, and sentences structure to improve conversational, reading, and writing abilities. Includes discussion of various aspects of Chinese culture. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3201 or Language Placement Chinese >= 301

Humanities.title: Level III Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
Humanities.description: Study of various genres of Chinese literature and of various aspects of Chinese society, emphasizing, historical and cultural backgrounds. Conducted primarily in Chinese. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3202 or Language Placement Chinese >= 401

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Level II A Less Commonly Taught Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Review and continued study of listening, speaking, reading, and writing in less commonly taught language. Students learn how to communicate in target culture. Includes study of various aspects of the culture in which the language is used. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2242

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0

Humanities.title: Level II B Less Commonly Taught Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 167 Further study of less commonly taught language. Includes study of vocabulary, idioms, and sentence structure to improve conversational reading and writing abilities and discussions of various aspects of culture in which the language is used. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3241

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0

Humanities.title: World Literatures & Cultures
Humanities.description: Comparative approach to world literatures and cultures. May include literary works, critical essays, films, music, and other representations of world culture. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Topics in Communicating Across Cultures
Humanities.description: Examines communication practices and styles across selected cultures and multicultural groups, drawing on an interdisciplinary range of research fields. May address social issues, language and cultural differences, gender, race, ethnicity, class, disabilities, age, religion, family and national identity. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Topics in Francophone Cultures
Humanities.description: An introduction to Francophone cultures (in English) in a comparative perspective. Includes a survey of French history and its influence on Francophone societies. Includes study of film and other media and a critical examination of cross-cultural differences between French, Francophone, and U.S. cultures. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Topics in German-Speaking Cultures
Humanities.description: An introduction to German-speaking culture (in English) in a comparative perspective. Includes a survey of Central-European history and its influence on modern-day German-speaking societies through movies, media, and recent technologies, and a critical examination of cross-cultural differences between German and North- American cultures. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Topics in Spanish-Speaking Cultures
Humanities.description: An introduction to Spanish-speaking cultures (in English) in comparative historical perspectives. Includes a survey and a critical cross-cultural examination of Latin-American cultures and Spanish-speaking societies Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 168 (European, Caribbean, and North, Central and South American) through literature, music, film, art, and other media. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Topics in East Asian Cultures
Humanities.description: Introduction to the contemporary and traditional cultures of China, Korea, and Japan taught through readings, films, lectures, and discussions. Taught in English.

Humanities.title: International Language Study in Spanish, German, or French
Humanities.description: International study in Spanish, German, or French. Taught in the target language. Used for study abroad only.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Level II-A French Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Review and continued study of grammar, vocabulary, speaking, listening, reading, and writing in French. Includes written compositions and oral presentations. Cultural focus on several Francophone regions of the world. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2272 or HU 2273 or Language Placement French >= 331

Humanities.title: Level II-B French Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Continued study of grammar, vocabulary, speaking, listening, reading, and writing in French. Includes written compositions, oral presentations, and reading of brief literary texts. Cultural focus on several Francophone regions of the world. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3271 or Language Placement French >= 421

Humanities.title: Level II-C French Composition and Conversation
Humanities.description: Extensive work in the active, creative use of written and oral French. Includes development of communicative strategies, written compositions, and oral presentations in the context of contemporary French-speaking cultures. May include study of film and other media. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3272 or Language Placement French >= 501 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 169

Humanities.title: Level III Topics in French Literature and Culture
Humanities.description: Topics in French literature and its historical and cultural contexts. May include selections from Francophone literature. Conducted in French. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3272 or HU 3273 or Language Placement French >= 501 or CEEB French Language >= 3 or CEEB French Literature >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Level III French for Special Purposes
Humanities.description: Study of business, technical, and/or scientific discourses in the context of French language and Francophone cultures. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3272 or HU 3273 or Language Placement French >= 501 or CEEB French Language >= 3 or CEEB French Literature >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Level II-A German Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Concluding study and review of the basics of the German language. Includes study of vocabulary, idioms, and sentence structure to improve conversational and reading abilities, and discussion of various aspects of contemporary German culture. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2282 or Language Placement German >= 321

Humanities.title: Level II-B German Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Review of the basics of the German language. Includes study of vocabulary, idioms, and sentence structure to improve conversational and reading abilities, and writing of compositions in German. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3281 or Language Placement German >= 441

Humanities.title: German Composition and Conversation
Humanities.description: Review of the basics of the German language. Includes study of vocabulary, idioms, and sentence structure to improve conversational and reading abilities and writing of compositions in German. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3282 or Language Placement German >= 561

Humanities.title: Level III in German Literature and Culture
Humanities.description: Study of German literature and cultures. Topics may include postwar German literature, Germany since WWII, or emphasis on a major contemporary writer. Readings, discussion and writing in German. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 170 Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3282 or HU 3283 or Language Placement German >= 561 or CEEB German Language >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Level III German: Film and Media
Humanities.description: Study of German film, news and media. Topics may include feature films, documentaries, and other audio-visual and digital texts. Readings, discussion, and writing in German. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3282 or HU 3283 or Language Placement German >= 561 or CEEB German Language >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Level III German Special Topics
Humanities.description: Advanced German language study. Topics may include advanced grammar, translation, or German for specific contexts such as engineering and other sciences, healthcare, business, or legal professions. Readings, discussion, and writing in German. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3282 or HU 3283 or Language Placement German >= 561 or CEEB German Language >= 3

Humanities.title: Level II Spanish Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Review and continued study of grammar, vocabulary, speaking, listening, reading, and writing in Spanish. Includes written compositions and oral presentations. Cultural focus on several Spanish- speaking regions. Students completing this course may apply for placement credit. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2292 or HU 2293 or Language Placement Spanish >= 321

Humanities.title: Level II-B Spanish Language and Culture
Humanities.description: Continued study of grammar, vocabulary, speaking, listening, reading, and writing in Spanish. Includes written compositions, oral presentations, and readings of short literary and documentary texts. Strong cultural focus on several Spanish-speaking regions. Students completing this course may apply for placement credit. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3291 or Language Placement Spanish >= 401

Humanities.title: Level IIC Spanish Composition and Conversation
Humanities.description: Advanced grammar, composition, and conversation practice. Readings may include texts from literary, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 171 social, economic, scientific, engineering, or business discourses in the context of Hispanic cultures. Students completing this course may apply for placement credit. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3292 or Language Placement Spanish >= 480

Humanities.title: Topics in Hispanic Literatures and Cultures
Humanities.description: Study of selected works of literature, culture, and civilization from selected regions of the Spanish- speaking world. May incorporate study of literary genres and historical periods as related to Spain and/or Latin American cultures. Students completing this course may apply for placement credits. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3293 or Language Placement Spanish >= 631 or CEEB Spanish Language >= 3 or CEEB Spanish Literature >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Humanities.title: Level III Advanced Spanish for Literacies
Humanities.description: Spanish for Special Purposes is designed for students who anticipate careers in which they will need to interact with Hispanic communities in the U.S. or abroad and who wish to continue study of Spanish language and culture for specific professional purposes. Topics include Spanish for engineering and other sciences, healthcare, business, and legal professions. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3293 or Language Placement Spanish >= 631 or CEEB Spanish Language >= 3 or CEEB Spanish Literature >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Humanities.title: Survey of Hispanic Literatures and Cultures
Humanities.description: Overview of Iberian and/or Latin American literatures and cultures from colonial through contemporary periods, including the arts and popular movements, from a multidisciplinary perspective. Course is repeatable up to six credits. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3293 or Language Placement Spanish >= 631 or CEEB Spanish Language >= 3 or CEEB Spanish Literature >= 3

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Topics in World Cinema
Humanities.description: This course focuses on mainstream and/or independent films in their historical and sociocultural contexts from selected regions such as Latin America, Africa, the Middle East, Asia, and Europe. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 172 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Film Style and Genre
Humanities.description: Focus on film style and genre with an emphasis on study of directors, movements, and aesthetics and their technological, theoretical, and socio-cultural contexts. Includes small lab projects. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Topics in Diversity Studies
Humanities.description: This course provides students with a better understanding of underrepresented populations within the United States by examining the culture and experience of African American; American Indian; Asian American; Latina/Latino American; Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transsexual; or Post-Colonial peoples. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Humanities.title: Gender and Culture
Humanities.description: Interrelations of gender and culture, including comparative analysis of constructions of gender. May examine different societies and/or different historical periods. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Introduction to Diversity Studies in the United States
Humanities.description: This course provides students with a better understanding of underrepresented populations within the United States by examining the social, cultural, and personal consequences of gender, race, ethnicity, class, sexual orientation, (dis)ability, and other significant identities. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Mythology
Humanities.description: Survey of the major mythological systems of the world with particular attention to those areas of commonality among various civilizations. Films may provide contextual background. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Special Topics: Literature and Culture
Humanities.description: Examines an important theme of topic in the Humanities, such as theory, language, literature and culture. May be repeated for up to nine credits if topic differs. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 173 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Humanities.title: Studies in the Novel
Humanities.description: Examination of the novel in world literature with special attention to the historical, cultural, and personal contexts within which the author is writing. Film versions may be examined. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Studies in Literary Forms
Humanities.description: This course examines one or more literary forms, genres, and modes such as tragedy, satire, romance, science fiction, fantasy, comedy, epics, novels, short stories, poetry, and/or creative nonfiction. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Major Authors
Humanities.description: An intensive study of the life and works of one or more significant literary figures. This course will also focus on the social and historical contexts that shaped the author's reputation and standing in the literary, theatrical, or cinematic canon. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Cultural Traditions in Literature
Humanities.description: An advanced study of a specific transnational or trans-Atlantic historical period or aesthetic movement that illustrates the development of literary and/or cinematic traditions. Courses will include relevant theory and criticism. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Literature and the Environment
Humanities.description: In this course students examine the interdisciplinary relationship between literature and environmental and ecological studies. Topics to be explored include eco-criticism, eco-feminism, environmental (in) justice, indigeneity, sustainability, and animal studies. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 174 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Studies in Drama
Humanities.description: Examines post-Shakespearean drama and the cultural history of theatre. Courses will focus on a selection of plays each semester, and address a range of topics, including theatre history and performance theory. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Shakespeare
Humanities.description: In-depth study of a limited number of Shakespearean plays with special attention to dramatic structure, character development, theme presentation, and theatre history. Includes extensive study of Renaissance influences, possibly film versions of selected plays, and examination of current critical theories. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Workshop in Creative Nonfiction
Humanities.description: Advanced work in creative nonfiction writing; workshop format. Readings will include short memoirs, personal essays, lyric essays, and other sub-genres of contemporary creative nonfiction. Emphasis on individual production through process-oriented writing exercises, small group workshops, individual conferences, and revision/development. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2510 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Workshop in Poetry
Humanities.description: Advanced work in poetry writing; workshop format. Students will study contemporary and emerging works in order to enrich and stimulate their own poetic practice. Emphasis on individual production through process- oriented writing exercises, small group workshops, individual conferences, and revision/development. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2510 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Workshop in Fiction
Humanities.description: Advanced work in fiction writing; workshop format. Readings will include 'canonical', contemporary, and emerging examples of short-form fiction. Emphasis on individual production through process-oriented writing exercises, small group workshops, individual conferences, and revision/development. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 175 Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2510 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Literary Theory and Criticism
Humanities.description: A consideration of a variety of theoretical and critical approaches and methods of literary research in the study of British and American literature. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Workshop in Science Fiction Writing
Humanities.description: This course focuses on the craft of writing science fiction. Reading stories from classic to contemporary sci-fi and examining key features of the genre. Writing assignments will include reading responses, short creative exercises, peer review, and a research-driven work of fiction. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Workshop in Nature Writing
Humanities.description: This course focuses on the craft of environmental and nature writing. In conjunction with creative writing exercise and peer review, students will analyze a variety of exemplary texts within the genre, culminating in the production of a research-driven manuscript in either poetry, fiction, or nonfiction. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Literature Across Borders
Humanities.description: Study of literary genres, themes, and movements, with emphasis on comparing and contrasting perspectives reflected in literatures from Western and non-Western cultures. Topics may focus on historical, social, aesthetic, and cultural factors as they influence these literatures. Films may be used. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Science Fiction
Humanities.description: Close study of significant works in science fiction and fantasy. Examines genre features and usage and attends to a writer's style and methods. Regularly focuses on historical fiction and fantasy using film to help establish literary context. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 176 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Literature and Science
Humanities.description: Focuses on depictions of science in literature and literary features of scientific texts from a range of historical periods, genres, and nationalities. May include the influence of scientific methods on literature and vice versa (for instance, narrative medicine). Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Professional Development in the Humanities
Humanities.description: Addresses conventions and expectations for professional development through projects such as portfolio development and research into contemporary professional and workplace issues. Explores career and graduate school opportunities. Scientific & Tech Comm (BS), English, Liberal Arts, Scientific & Tech Comm (BA), Humanities, Comm and Culture Studies; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Communication, Culture & Media,

Humanities.title: Grammar and Usage in Society
Humanities.description: Description and analysis of current standards of grammar and usage in the U.S. Students acquire an understanding of the structures of American English as well as an understanding of the social forces underlying standardization and the processes of language change.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Editing
Humanities.description: Examination of the responsibilities of an editor and grounding in basic editorial skills. Topics include situations of editing, levels of editing, readability, correctness, style, relations with authors, and social and political implications of editing. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Humanities.title: Introduction to Journalism
Humanities.description: Introduction to the history and practice of journalism. Includes critical analysis of journalistic coverage, journalistic style and editing, and ethical issues in journalism. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 177 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Publications and Information Management
Humanities.description: Principles of information selection, editing, layout, and graphics essential to the scheduling, budgeting, and production of various print and digital publications. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2642 and HU 2633 or HU 2645

Humanities.title: Science Writing
Humanities.description: Introduces writing, research, and editing that contribute to a public understanding of science. Possible topics: health, environment, medicine, public policy. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Grant Writing
Humanities.description: Introduces fundamentals of grant proposal writing and research. Possible topics: writing for nonprofits, grant writing in various disciplines, researching funding resources. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Digital Writing and Rhetoric
Humanities.description: Writing for digital content creation with special attention to production and content strategy, investigating historical, ethical, and social implications of digital platforms. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2642 or HU 2130 or HU 3120

Humanities.title: Philosophy of Science
Humanities.description: Examination of problems involved in scientific methodology such as theory structure, concept formation, scientific explanation, hypothetico-deductive model, role of experimentation, function of paradigms and analogies, distinction between science and pseudoscience, extent to which science is value-free or value- laden, social responsibility of scientists, and aims of science. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 178

Humanities.title: Philosophy of Technology
Humanities.description: A study of philosophical analyses of technology. Topics may include: the essence and nature of technology, technology and human existence; the notion that we live in a technological age; and ethical issues surrounding the use, abuse, and ubiquity of technology. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Philosophy of Religion
Humanities.description: An examination of some philosophical questions in diverse religious traditions including the existence of God, the problem of evil, and the nature of religious experience. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Environmental Philosophy
Humanities.description: This course explores different ways of reflecting on our relationships to our natural environments, inquiring into the meaning of environment, ecology, resources, and management. It analyzes the social and ethical dimensions; examining how different understandings of 'environment' affect policy, ethics, law, and technology. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Engineering Ethics
Humanities.description: A study of ethical questions confronting individual engineers and the engineering profession. Among the issues to be explored are the meaning of professionalism, the social responsibilities of engineers, engineer- employer and engineer-client relationships, whistle-blowing, conflicts of interest, and competitive bidding. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Biomedical Ethics
Humanities.description: A study of several important ethical and philosophical issues that arise in medical practice and in biomedical science. Issues may include euthanasia, abortion, the physician-patient relationship, experimentation involving human subjects, and allocation of scarce biomedical resources. General ethical theories and concepts are used to shed light on those issues. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 179 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Media and Society
Humanities.description: Examines contemporary forms of mediated communication. Emphasis on understanding media economics and impacts of media on attitudes, values, behavior, and identity. Topics may include propaganda, advertising, political communication, journalism, media violence, social media, surveillance, and media policy. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Media and Globalization
Humanities.description: Examines the development of modern international communication systems, the rise of transnational media industries and technologies, and debates about their global impacts. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Technology and Culture
Humanities.description: Considers interrelationships between technology and culture. Includes understanding the context within which technologies are developed and used, and how assumptions about technology shape knowledge, practice, and creative action. Issues such as progress, determinism, ethics, gender, race, class, globalization, and "humanness". Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Environmental Communication
Humanities.description: Critical and cultural approach to key issues, concepts, and controversies in the field of environmental communication. May include topics such as environmental journalism, rhetoric of sustainability, risk communication, politics of climate representation, advocacy, consumerism, eco-tourism, greening, public policy, environmental justice. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Creativity, Culture, and Change
Humanities.description: Examines the sources of creativity and the ways that it has been used to change cultural values, feelings, beliefs, and practices. A project-based course that cultivates and applies creative action toward cultural change. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 180 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Advanced Digital Presentation
Humanities.description: Students will use digital delivery modes to design and deliver presentations for a variety of social and professional purposes. Students will explore the ethical, social, and political implications of digital delivery for civic life and public discourse. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Organizational Communication
Humanities.description: An approach to understanding organizations in their socio-historical contexts from a variety of theoretical perspectives in communication. Explores meanings, roles, relations, interactions, and structures from a communication perspective. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Human-Machine Communication
Humanities.description: Surveys the area of Human-Machine Communication. Considers a variety of communicative machines, contexts, and perspectives. Examines issues of agency, media representations, co-construction, culture, privacy, and other ideas in relation to the communicative interplay of human and machines. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Cultural Studies
Humanities.description: Examines the way that culture communicates values, feelings, beliefs; structures differential relations of power and possibility; creates difference and hierarchy. Considers the struggles over meaning that open up possibilities for diversity and change. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Surveillance, Media, and Film
Humanities.description: Considers surveillance practices and the surveillance imaginary through films that take surveillance as their principal feature. Covers perspectives such as those of the watchers and the watched; kinds and purposes of surveillance; and the relationship between filmic surveillance and our sense and practices of freedom versus control. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 181 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Power, Activism, and Technology
Humanities.description: How social, cultural, and political power arrangements create the contexts of activism and the impact of technology on acts of resistance. We will foster critical thinking around notions of power, violence, discourse, technology, and the media environment. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Cultural Theory and Popular Culture
Humanities.description: Introduces fundamentals of cultural theory and media criticism. Considers historical, social, political, and economic contexts of popular culture from a media studies perspective. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Media Theory
Humanities.description: Examines relationships among changing communication technologies and communication theories. Emphasizes issues involving emerging technologies and emerging theory. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Color, Visuality, and Culture
Humanities.description: Engages with color as an aesthetic, theoretical, historical, cultural, and political concept. Explores what color is made of, how color shapes meaning, and how color functions in various expressive and interpretative contexts including politics, science, and industry. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Media Industries
Humanities.description: Examines economic, political, and cultural aspects of media industries (cinema, broadcasting, music, gaming, telecommunications, and advertising) from historical and contemporary contexts. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Documentary
Humanities.description: Considers technical, theoretical, aesthetic and ethical dimensions of documentary media through analysis Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 182 and production. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Language and Globalization
Humanities.description: Considers the historical rise of the English language and other dominant languages, and present effects on minority and endangered languages within the US and abroad; World Englishes and dialectal variation; and the interaction of forces of globalization/standardization with localization/identity. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Language and Identity
Humanities.description: Examines how individuals create and perform their social identities through and in response to language, considering social variables such as race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, disability, geography, power, ideology, etc. Explores how these variables may intersect, clash, and be resolved. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Special Topics
Humanities.description: Tutorial, seminar, workshop, or class study of special interest and importance in the humanities. Students should register by section number for the appropriate instructor and topic.

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Humanities.title: Humanities Workshop
Humanities.description: Special workshop projects in the humanities such as tutorials, editing, Shakespeare Faire drama workshop, writer's workshop, or study-abroad tours. Approved credit varies by degree program.

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Humanities.title: Writing Center Practicum
Humanities.description: Reflective practicum in which theories of learning, literacy, and cultural differences are applied in the Writing Center setting under the supervision of a writing center professional. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 183 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Humanities.title: Lode Practicum for Student Journalists
Humanities.description: Reflective practicum in which the theory and practice of journalism is applied as a student writer for the Michigan Tech Lode. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Humanities.title: Modern Language Seminar I-French
Humanities.description: Language and power. Critical study of the representation of politics, economics, and social institutions in literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in French and English translations. Course offered third year beginning 2009-2010. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3274 or HU 3275

Humanities.title: Modern Language Seminar II-French
Humanities.description: Individual and society. Critical study of the relationship between the individual and social institutions in literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in French and in English translation. Course offered third year beginning 2010-2011. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3274 or HU 3275

Humanities.title: Modern Language Seminar III-French
Humanities.description: Technology in literature and film. Critical study of the representation of modern technology in literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in French and in English translation. Course offered every third year beginning 2008-2009. Pre-Requisite(s): (HU 3274 or HU 3275) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Modern Language Seminar I-German
Humanities.description: Language and power. Critical study of the representation of politics, economies, and social institutions in literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in German and in English translation. Course offered every third year beginning 2008- 2009. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 184 Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3284 or HU 3285

Humanities.title: Modern Language Seminar II-German
Humanities.description: Individual and society. Critical study of the relationship between the individual and social institutions in literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in German and in English translation. Course offered every third year beginning 2009-2010. Pre-Requisite(s): (HU 3284 or HU 3285) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Modern Language Seminar III-German
Humanities.description: Technology in literature and film. Critical study of the relationship between modern technology and literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in German and in English translation. Course offered every third year beginning 2010-2011. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3284 or HU 3285

Humanities.title: Level IV Modern Language Seminar I-Spanish
Humanities.description: Language and power. Critical study of the representation of politics, economies, and social institutions in literature, film, and authentic texts in French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in Spanish and English translation. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3294 or HU 3295 or HU 3296

Humanities.title: Level IV Modern Language Seminar II-Spanish
Humanities.description: Individual and society. Critical study of the relationship between the individual and social institutions in literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German and Hispanic speaking communities. Students read texts in Spanish and in English translation. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3294 or HU 3295 or HU 3296

Humanities.title: Level IV Modern Language Seminar III-Spanish
Humanities.description: Technology in literature and film. Critical study of the relationship between modern technology and literature, film, and authentic documents from French, German, and Hispanic language communities. Students read texts in Spanish and in English translation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 185 Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3294 or HU 3295 or HU 3296

Humanities.title: Multimedia Storytelling
Humanities.description: Production-intensive focus on how media producers use audio, video, and digital platforms to tell a story, realize a creative vision, and engage an audience. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2324

Humanities.title: Senior Seminar in English
Humanities.description: A course especially designed for English majors. In depth exploration of various topics with special emphasis on theory and production. Students will be required to engage relevant secondary sources and theory in a longer, final seminar paper.

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Humanities.title: BA Thesis
Humanities.description: Students will be required to engage relevant secondary sources and theory in a longer, final seminar paper or creative project. Produce a cultural final project that demonstrates advanced critical and creative analysis. Proposals must be approved in the prior semester.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Humanities.title: Humanities Internship
Humanities.description: Provides internship experience directly related to student's course of study. Students conduct work at internship site in addition to academic assignments that encourage them to connect their professional and academic experience. Requires approval of department internship coordinator.

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Humanities.title: Risk Communication
Humanities.description: Examines models for communicating risks associated with environmental, safety, and health hazards. Considers the diverse roles assumed by the public under each of these models and means of ensuring that risks are communicated fairly, honestly, and accurately. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Humanities.title: International Technical Communication
Humanities.description: Focuses on international workplace communication. Introduces theories of globalization. Topics may include localization, contrastive rhetoric, technical translation, and international usability. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 186 Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2600

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Usability Evaluation and User Experience Design
Humanities.description: Theories and practices of usability evaluation and user experience design relevant to technical communication contexts. Individual and team projects with emphasis on the development of instructions and procedures. Pre-Requisite(s): (HU 3120 or HU 3121) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Advanced Practicum in Scientific and Technical Communication
Humanities.description: Provides technical communication majors with opportunities to design and produce various communication products expected in their working careers. The course will also require students to complete, with advice from the instructor, one major client-involved project. Scientific & Tech Comm (BA) Pre-Requisite(s): (HU 3120 or HU 3121) and HU 2600

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Scientific & Tech Comm (BS),

Humanities.title: Advanced Topics in Media
Humanities.description: Critical and/or applied topics in advanced media, theory and development. Topics may include game design, mobile media, color, photography, film, or graphic design. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2633 or HU 2645

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Humanities.title: Special Topics in Technical and Professional Communication
Humanities.description: In-depth examination of selected topics in scientific and technical communication, or on professional and workplace writing in selected genres such as reports, proposals, or whitepapers.

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Topics in Philosophy
Humanities.description: The topics will ordinarily be in-depth examinations of a particular philosopher or philosophical problem, tradition, or historical period. Examples include the philosophy of Kant, the existence of God, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 187 American pragmatism, death and dying, and ancient Greek philosophy. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Humanities.title: Political Philosophy
Humanities.description: Issues in political philosophy, such as the moral foundations of political systems, the proper relation between the individual and the state, and the justification of social institutions. Philosophers studied may include Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Marx, de Tocqueville, Mill, Dewey, and Rawls. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Sports Medicine and Ethics
Humanities.description: Examines ethical issues in sports medicine. Topics include the ethical responsibilities and conflicts of interest for team physicians, research on athletes, sport-related concussions, and doping. Philosophical ethical foundations, and professional ethical codes for sports medicine will be studied.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Humanities.title: Biomedical Research Ethics
Humanities.description: Examination of bioethical issues in biomedical research. Topics include research on human subjects, on vulnerable populations, and animals, principles of ethical research, and societal expectations for researchers. Pre-Requisite(s): HU 3711

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Humanities.title: Existentialism and Phenomenology
Humanities.description: Introduction to the philosophical traditions of existentialism and phenomenology. Topics might inlude: the nature of human existence and of freedom; the importance of world, self, anxiety, death, and authenticity; and the foundations of knowledge, experience and meaning. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Humanities.title: Communication, Culture, and Media Senior Seminar
Humanities.description: Senior seminar course extending students' knowledge and skills in a chosen specialty of communication, cultural studies, and media through independent research, project design, media Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 188 development, or other culminating activity. Major(s): Communication, Culture & Media; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior Pre-Requisite(s): HU 2810 and HU 2820 and HU 2830

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; Must be enrolled in one of the following

Humanities.title: Topics in Communication
Humanities.description: In-depth examination of selected issues or problems in the study of communication, such as gender and communication, the environment and communication, sound and communication, violence and communication. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher) Kinesiology & Integrative Phys

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Introduction to Exercise Science
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Introduction to the fields and career opportunities in the exercise sciences.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Introduction to Sports and Fitness Management
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Introduction to the fields and career opportunities in sports and fitness management.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Foundations of Kinesiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Introduces academic subdisciplines of kinesiology - anatomy, motor behavior, biomechanics, physiology, exercise and the environment, sport nutrition and the mind and brain in exercise. Provides the conceptual framework within which the scientific bases for movement during exercise, sport performance, and other forms of physical activity are studied.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Student Athlete 101
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Read, discuss, and practice study skills, cognitive strategies, goal development, and address contemporary issues problematic in today's college environment. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 189

tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Professionalism in Kinesiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course will assist students in gaining skills for entering into career-focused roles with professional competency, learning to apply these skills through shadowing experiences, and preparing to transition from a college student to a professional in kinesiology. Exercise Science

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Sports and Fitness Management,

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Introduction to Athletic Training
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Covers first aid, adult CPR, child CPR, and other sport training issues. Students receive appropriate certification cards.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Health Promotion
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course emphasizes methods in planning, designing, implementing, and improving health/wellness promotion programs. Client motivation, behavior change, and physical activity for special populations will be addressed. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 1500

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports and Fitness Leadership
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Course is designed to help students succeed in leadership principles, effective communication, team work, and introspection. Students will lead, teach, and collaborate with their peers through different assignments and active participation in class.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Principles of Sports Officiating
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Theory and practice of officiating various sports common in the community and school setting.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Lifeguard First Aid
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Lecture, demonstration, and practice of first aid knowledge and skills. Adult, child, and infant CPR skills will be covered as well as AED. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 190 Co-Requisite(s): PE 1470

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Athletic Training Practicum
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: An experiential learning course in which students assist certified athletic trainers in preventive and post- injury care of collegiate athletes. Topics include professionalism, acute injury prevention techniques, and post-injury management and care. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 2100

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Introduction to Public Health
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: An overview of public health including the history of public health and major issues facing the U.S. and global populations. Topics include societal conditions that lead to health disparities, role of government, and the basic sciences supporting public health.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Outdoor Emergency Care Training (Ski Patrol)
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Second of two-course sequence required for Alpine and Nordic Ski Patrol candidates. Ninety hours of instruction includes three weekends. Requires payment of dues to become member of National Ski Patrol. Certification in National Ski Patrol Outdoor Emergency Care is available upon completion. Pre-Requisite(s): PE 2028

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Essential Biochemistry
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course will provide a broad understanding of chemical and biological events happening in living systems. It covers the topics including the structure and functional relationship of biological molecules, the metabolic pathways central to biological function, and biochemistry of certain inherited genetic diseases. Senior Pre-Requisite(s): BL 1200 or BL 1400 or CH 1150

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior,

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Special Topics in Kinesiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Examination of current topics in the field of kinesiology. Literature and research topics are addressed. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 191 Exercise Science

tags.Credits: variable to 9.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Sports and Fitness Management,

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports Psychology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Overview of psychological principles and their applications to individuals and groups in sport, exercise and/or therapy. For the laboratory portion, students observe and analyze behaviors in a setting of their choice. Pre-Requisite(s): PSY 2000

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Exercise Assessment and Prescription
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Theory and practical aspects of exercise testing and prescription; topics include testing of strength, endurance, cardiovascular endurance, flexibility, body composition, muscle power, and balance with special considerations for arthritis, osteoporosis, dyslipidemia, immunology, and metabolic syndrome. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Functional Anatomy
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Students will acquire detailed knowledge of joint movements and muscle actions involved in exercise, activities of daily living and workplace tasks. This course delivers necessary theoretical background in functional anatomy, highlighting its close link with biomechanics, thus enhancing understanding of movement processes and injury risk. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2010 and BL 2011

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Personal Training
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: A pragmatic course of both theory and application in setting up a personal training program for individuals. Includes assessment, techniques, planning, safety and legal issues. Leads toward final preparation to earn certification as a personal trainer. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021 and KIP 3100

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Foundations of Coaching
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Practical and relevant information appropriate for beginning and experienced interscholastic coaches. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 192

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Coaching Methods and Principles
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Designed to provide students with basic information about coaching. Planning and organizing practice and competition, selecting appropriate drills, teaching and analyzing fundamental skills, evaluating performance, understanding basic strategies.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports Administration
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Students will learn skills and competencies of sports management including ethics, marketing, law, finance, information, collegiate, olympic, professional, youth, campus recreation programs, parks, career opportunities, foundations, and future directions.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Facilities & Events Management
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Students will learn about managing sports facilities including risk management, administration of personnel, organization, and administrative efficiency.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports Medicine Practicum
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course allows students to experience current topics in sports medicine along with learning up-to-date orthopedic injury assessment, treatment, and rehabilitation. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 2500

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Motor Development
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Designed for upper level undergraduates or graduates, this course will focus on the changes in motor behavior across a life span, and examine the study and practice of fundamental patterns within the context of development theory. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 1500 and BL 2020

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Lifetime Fitness
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: To gain a thorough understanding in all areas of personal fitness through functional anatomy, exercise Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 193 physiology, health and physical fitness, screening and evaluation, nutrition, weight management, exercise prescription and programming considerations, training instruction, and consideration for special populations.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports Nutrition Seminar
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Human nutrition as it specifically applies to athletes. Specific needs for proteins, carbohydrates, fats, electrolytes and micronutrients. Use of ergogenic aids is covered. Students will research, write and present orally their findings on nutrition topics. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2940

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Exercise Physiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Focuses on the functional changes brought by acute and chronic exercise sessions. Topics include muscle structure and function, bioenergetics, cardiovascular and respiratory adaptations, exercise training for sport, sport nutrition, ergogenic aids, and other health and fitness topics. Co-Requisite(s): KIP 4110 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Exercise Physiology Laboratory
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Hands-on experience in making physiological measurements as related to exercise. Cardiovascular and respiratory changes during exercise will be monitored. A virtual lab is used to simulate changes in physiological measurements that cannot be performed on live subjects. A student designed laboratory project is required. Co-Requisite(s): KIP 4100

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Molecular Exercise Physiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Introduces cellular and molecular mechanisms by which exercise causes adaption. Topics include how gene variations affect human performance, signal transduction pathways involved in regulation of metabolism, and mechanism of exercise in prevention and treatment of chronic diseases. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 194 Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 2700 and KIP 4100

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Biomechanics of Human Movement
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: An in-depth view of the biomechanical properties of the musculoskeletal system. The course provides detailed analyses of the kinetics of human movement, material properties of the component tissues, and dynamic processes of adaptation to stress and strain of the system. Co-Requisite(s): KIP 4210 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and KIP 1500 and PH 1110 and PH 1111

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Biomechanics of Human Movement Laboratory
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Hands-on experience, including data collection, analysis, and interpretation using various equipment in biomechanics. equipment in biomechanics. Co-Requisite(s): KIP 4200 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and KIP 1500 and PH 1110 and PH 1111

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Ergonomics
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Introduction to ergonomics and work measurement with an emphasis on people in built and occupational environments. Discussion of methods for ergonomic assessment, evolution, and work measurement, with major topics including productivity and performance, manual materials handling, work-related musculoskeletal disorders, safety, training, legal issues, and adapting environments for special populations.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Motor Learning and Control
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course will provide the current theories and concepts involved in the processes of motor skill acquisition and performance from a behavioral perspective. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 1500 and BL 2020

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Neural-Endocrine Physiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course will focus on understanding how the neural and the endocrinal system are regulated under physiological condition and pathophysiological states. The major objective of this course is to prepare students to develop critical thinking and problem solving skills related to the function Neural/Endocrine system. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 195 Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Strength and Conditioning
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Theory and practice in development and administration of comprehensive strength and conditioning programs for both the athlete and individual of any level. Includes knowledge, safety concerns and skill techniques necessary for teaching and administering at any strength and conditioning facility. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Athletic Training Capstone
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Experiential learning that engages students with mentorship and assisting certified athletic trainers through a complete season with one team. This course allows students to engage with injuries from onset through complete rehabilitation and return to play. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 3500

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports and Fitness Promotions
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Development and implementation of marketing plans for sports and fitness businesses. Topics include marketing of sporting events and fitness programs, use of traditional media for promotion, web-based advertising (new media), and business branding. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Legal Issues in Sports and Fitness Management
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Review of legal issues that apply to sport and fitness organizations such as liability, risk management, facility concerns, and labor laws. Basic components of the U.S. legal system and guidelines, and rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will be covered.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports Media
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: This course examines the impact sports and the media have on each other and the sports consumer. Students will gain a greater understanding of the operation of sports media and communications at all levels of sports (amateur, collegiate, professional) and the role of sports media in American society. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 196 Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Financial Aspects of Sports
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: The course is designed to provide the student with an understanding of the basic concepts that underlie financial management, and an ability to apply these concepts to the analysis of financial issues within the sport industry. Pre-Requisite(s): ACC 2000

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Coaching Practicum
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Students seeking coaching endorsement assist with a sport of their choice. Subject to approval of endorsement advisor, students may assist a head coach in season during student teaching; assist MTU head coach in season; assist head coach in season at public/private school or summer camp. Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 3000 and KIP 3300

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: EKG Interpretation
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Course is designed for students who are going to pursue future career related to cardiac rehabilitation, physical therapy and students in the Pre-Med program. Students will learn cardiac electrophysiology, the pathophysiology, the diagnosis, and treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, and related cardiovascular diseases. Class will build bridge between basic sciences and human health. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Sports Medicine and Ethics
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Examines ethical issues in sports medicine. Topics might include the ethical responsibilities and conflicts of interest for team physicians, research on athletes, sport-related concussions, and doping. Philosophical ethical foundations, and professional ethical codes for sports medicine will be studied.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Exercise Pharmacology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 197 Course will bridge between basic sciences and human health. The course focuses on understanding the fundamental concept of exercise pharmacology and pharmacological treatment of diseases of various systems including cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, neuronal, hormonal, and renal systems. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Physical Therapy Seminar
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Seminar for students who are interested in physical therapy profession. Course will include self- directed learning and group work. Topics may include evidence based medicine, literature review writing and evaluation, healthcare reimbursement, clinical decision making, health screenings, and other current topics. Pre-Requisite(s): BL 2020 and BL 2021

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Epidemiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: An introduction to the principles and methods of epidemiology to understand the distribution and determinants of health in a population. Topics include basic epidemiological statistics, study design, and sources/impact of bias and error.

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Special Topics in Kinesiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Examination of current topics in the field of exercise science. Literature and research topics are addressed. Sports and Fitness Management, Exercise Science; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

tags.Credits: variable to 9.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s):

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Internship in Exercise Science
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Practical and didactic training in Exercise Science in an approved internship site. Provides experience in a variety of exercise science or medical settings. Internships must be approved by the department internship coordinator and work 42 hours for each credit earned. Exercise Science; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 2000 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 198

tags.Credits: variable to 9.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s):

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Internship in Sports and Fitness Management
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: Empirical experiences in an approved internship site. Provides practical experience in one or more work settings, assisting the upper level student in making an appropriate career choice. Internships must be approved by the department internship coordinator and work 42 hours for each credit earned. Sports and Fitness Management; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): KIP 2000

tags.Credits: variable to 12.0; Repeatable to a Max of 12
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s):

Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.title: Research in Kinesiology
Kinesiology and Integrative Physiology.description: A literature and laboratory research experience in kinesiology that culminates in a written report or oral presentation of the work performed. Mathematical Sciences

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Mathematical Sciences.title: College Mathematics Prep Lab
Mathematical Sciences.description: A study of basic mathematics skills used in entry level mathematics courses. Students who do not meet the prerequisites for MA1030 College Algebra I, but wish to eventually take that course should register for MA0050 to improve their foundational mathematics skills.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Mathematical Sciences.title: Quantitative Literacy
Mathematical Sciences.description: Stresses the role of contemporary mathematical thinking and the connection between mathematics and our daily lives.
