tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Mechanical Engineering Tech

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Practical Applications in Parametric Modeling
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Intermediate course intended to expand the student's knowledge of computer modeling techniques, introducing advanced assemblies and GD&T concepts. Investigates advanced concepts available to the designer. Pre-Requisite(s): ENG 1101 or ENG 1102

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Mechanical Engineering Tech

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Statics and Dynamics
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This class includes from statics, the study of forces, analysis of simple structures, equilibrium, moment of inertia, and friction. From dynamics, it covers rigid plane body kinematics and kinetics, inertia force, work- energy- power, and impulse-momentum methods. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121) and (PH 1110 or PH 1140 or PH 2100)

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Machine Design I
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: An introduction to mechanical design for technology students. The coursework applies principles of statics, dynamics and mechanics of materials to the design of simple mechanical components and systems. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2160 and (MET 2150 or MEEM 2150) and (MET 2130(C) or MEEM 2700(C)) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 227

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Applied Fluid Mechanics
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course provides an introduction to the principles of fluid mechanics and their application to natural and engineering problems. Students are expected to have a good understanding of statics and dynamics. Development of engineering problem-solving skills will be emphasized. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 2130 or MEEM 2700

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Machine Design II
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course extends the study of mechanical design begun in MET3242, Machine Design I and looks at more complex components and systems. Design projects are given special emphasis. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 3242

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Manufacturing Processes
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Focuses on practical aspects of design and manufacturing. Covers fundamentals of manufacturing processes and includes a weekly lab to provide hands-on experience with manufacturing issues that influence component design. Pre-Requisite(s): MSE 2100 and MET 2153

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Applied Thermodynamics
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Engineering thermodynamics principles including work, heat and temperature, pure substances, closed and open systems, first and second laws of thermodynamics, and power and refrigeration cycles. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 3400

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Applied Quality Techniques
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Basic knowledge required to improve processes in the workplace. Includes the design of simple experiments, statistical process control, lean methodologies, and corrective and preventative action. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2720(C) or MA 3710(C) or MA 2710(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Applied Heat Transfer
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Heat transfer principles including conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer mechanisms. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 228 Practical applications include thermal insulation, heat sink and heat exchanger design. Pre-Requisite(s): (MET 3700 or MEEM 2201) and (MET 3400 or CEE 3200)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Principles and Application of Heating, Ventilating, and Air Conditioning Systems
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course is designed to provide an introduction to heating, ventilating, and air conditioning systems that combines design principles with real-world applications. Students will conduct heating and cooling load calculations, learn psychrometrics, and have the opportunity to work on a realistic design project.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Industrial Systems Simulation
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Creating simulation models of various industrial systems in order to analyze and experiment with characteristics of real life systems for the purpose of engineering process improvement and production design.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Thermal-Fluids Laboratory
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course provides hands-on experience with selected thermal-fluid laboratory experiments. Site/plant visits will be included for exposure to some of the practical aspects of the thermal-fluids area. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 3400 and (MET 3700 or MEEM 2201) and MET 4300(C) and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710)

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Applied Fluid Power
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: An introduction to fluid power components and systems. The course includes component selection, circuit design, electrical interfaces, and system troubleshooting and maintenance. A laboratory exposes students to system hardware and circuit simulation techniques for mobile and industrial applications. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 3400 or MEEM 3201 or MET 3130

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Advanced Hydraulics: Electro-hydraulic Components & Systems
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course covers electro-hydraulic components including solenoid operated valves, proportional valves, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 229 and servo valves. Also covered are hydraulic systems including open-loop and closed-loop. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 4377

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Internal Combustion Engines
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: An introduction to the basic principles and applications of internal combustion engines. The course covers design, development and testing of engine components and systems. A laboratory exposes students to current industry methods. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 4300 or (MET 3700 and MET 4360(C))

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Product Design and Development
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: A treatment of design and development issues such as design for manufacturing, prototyping, industrial design, and customer needs. Presents integrated methodologies that examine marketing, manufacturing, and cross-functional teams. Includes concurrent engineering and projects utilizing CAD systems. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 3451(C) and MET 3500(C)

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Lean Manufacturing and Production Planning
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course provides fundamental knowledge of continuous improvement methodologies as practiced in today's competitive manufacturing and business environments. It covers the basic concepts and key techniques involved in a lean implementation through hands-on activities, reading assignments, case studies, and discussions.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Computer Aided Manufacturing
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Course is designed to apply techniques used in parametric modeling (CAD) and convert this information to all phases of production planning, machining, scheduling and quality control. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 2153 and MET 2400

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Senior Project I
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 230 Research and beginning design projects using computer-aided engineering methods, physical models, and/or prototypes. Evaluation and design optimization methods for efficient and cost-effective designs. Senior Pre-Requisite(s): MET 4460

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Facilities Layout and Safety Design
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Examines the optimization concepts and safety topics necessary to design a low risk, high efficiency manufacturing facility layout. The focus will be on quantitative tools, flow analysis techniques, hazard recognition and resource selection.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: CAE and FEA Methods
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Comprehensive use of both computer derived solutions and experimental validation of analytical and finite element solutions using methods such as strain gage testing. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 2400 and MET 3242(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Senior Project II
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Completion and evaluation of design projects using computer-aided engineering methods, physical models, and/or prototypes. Evaluation and design optimization methods for efficient and cost-effective designs. Senior Pre-Requisite(s): MET 4575

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Advanced Manufacturing
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: An introduction to advanced manufacturing processes, both traditional and nontraditional. Study of both theory and practice will be tied to laboratory experiments utilizing a spectrum of unique materials and methods. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 231 Pre-Requisite(s): MET 3500

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Dynamics and Kinematics of Robotics Platforms
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course covers the dynamics and kinematics of rigid bodies as the foundation for analyzing the motion of robots. Robotic kinematics is reviewed by analyzing the motion of the robot. The dynamics is reviewed by analyzing the relation between the joint actuator torques and resulting motion. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 2130 or MET 3130

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Controls of Dynamic Systems
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course covers the modeling, analysis, and control of dynamic systems. It covers the use of controlling equations for the control of mechanical and electrical systems. Theory is verified with simulation and lab testing. Included is a major project with a report and presentation on the subject. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 4800 or MET 5800

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Vibrations of Mechanical Systems
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: This course deals with the modeling and analysis of mixed physical systems. Introduction to modeling and oscillatory response analysis for discrete and continuous mechanical and structural systems. Time and frequency domain analysis of linear system vibrations. Vibration of multi-degree-of-freedom systems. Free vibration eigenvalue problems. Pre-Requisite(s): MET 2130

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering Technology
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Selected additional topics of interest in Mechanical Engineering Technology based on student and faculty demand and interest. May be a tutorial, seminar, workshop, project, or class study. Mechanical Engineering Tech; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s):

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Independent Study in Mechanical Engineering Technology
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Independent study of an approved topic under the guidance of a Mechanical Engineering Technology faculty member. May be either an academic, design, or research problem/project. Mechanical Engineering Tech; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 232

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s):

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Undergraduate Research in Mechanical Engineering Technology
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: An undergraduate research experience in Mechanical Engineering Technology. Under the guidance of a Mechanical Engineering Technology faculty member, students work on a selected/approved research problem or work directly with faculty on active research projects/grants. May require more than one semester to complete. Mechanical Engineering Tech; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s):

Mechanical Engineering Technology.title: Professional Practice Seminar
Mechanical Engineering Technology.description: Course designed to review and evaluate the program objectives linked with industrial partners and accreditation body. Focus given to preparing the student to take the certification exam. Management

tags.Credits: 1.0; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Management.title: Team Dynamics and Decision Making
Management.description: Develops individual and group problem-solving skills using active, hands-on learning. Emphasizes problem identification and problem solution under conditions of ambiguity and uncertainty. Stresses creativity, interpersonal skills and skill assessment, communication, group process and teamwork, and action planning.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management.title: Organizational Behavior
Management.description: Covers concepts of human relations and organizational behavior through the study of people's behavior at work. Develop understanding, attitudes, and skills leading to increased personal effectiveness.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management.title: Leadership Development
Management.description: Assesses students' current knowledge, abilities and values relevant to leadership and guides students in developing and implementing plans for new leadership abilities. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 233

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management.title: Intellectual Property Management
Management.description: Covers principles of intellectual property laws, addressing managerial and policy issues in copyright, trademark, trade secret, and patents. Readings and discussions also cover how these property and legal systems impact the balance between property exclusivity, technological innovation and public access. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management.title: Innovation & Entrepreneurship
Management.description: Develops an entrepreneurial mindset and a personal toolkit of methods and practices that enables students to create and evaluate entrepreneurial opportunities, marshal resources, and engage in entrepreneurial teams driven by creativity, leadership, smart action, and innovation.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management.title: Strategic Management
Management.description: A capstone course focusing on managing from a strategic perspective for gaining advantages in competitive and dynamic environments, emphasizing understanding of industry, business models, growth strategies, and managing business portfolios. Integrates knowledge from finance, marketing, and organizational behavior. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000 and FIN 3000 and OSM 3000 and MGT 3000 and MKT 3000 and BUS 2300

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of Business; Must be

Management.title: International Management
Management.description: Addresses the complexities and challenges faced by companies operating in an increasingly globalized world. Focuses on political, legal, ethical, cultural, economic issues, and on the entry, growth and knowledge management strategies of developed and developing country firms.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management.title: Entrepreneurial Management
Management.description: Draws upon the fundamental concepts of entrepreneurship covered in MGT3800 (Entrepreneurship) and enhances the understanding of these concepts from a strategic and entrepreneurial management point of view. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 234 Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 3800

Management.title: Developing Entrepreneurial Ventures
Management.description: The concepts, skills, and attitudes critical for identifying and evaluating business opportunities and developing these opportunities into entrepreneurial ventures. Topics emphasize understanding of the discipline of innovation and method of launching new ventures. Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 3800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management.title: Managing Change in Organizations
Management.description: Studies organizational theory with an emphasis on managing change in organizations. Examines forces for change in the external environment, methods for managing change (design and implementation), the impact of change on people, and leaders as agents of change. Case studies and student projects prepare the student to manage change in organizations. Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 3000 or BA 5700

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management.title: Management of Technology and Innovation
Management.description: Introduces disruptive innovation concepts and provides occasions for their application to timely and relevant cases. Provides an understanding of technology management and innovation processes as they occur inside and outside of organizations.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management.title: Commercialization of Advanced Technologies
Management.description: Frameworks, tools, and methods for commercializing novel technologies from lab bench to marketplace. Topics include opportunity evaluation, discovery-driven planning, legal and ethical implications. Provides a hands-on approach for students to commercialize technologies developed at research units. Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 4600 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 235

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management.title: Human Resource Management
Management.description: Examines methods that organizations use to meet organizational goals through influencing worker attitudes, behaviors, and performance. Topics include recruitment, selection, training, performance appraisal, and compensation. Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 3000

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management.title: Special Topics in Management
Management.description: Examines additional management topics and issues in greater depth. A single offering of this course will concentrate on one or two topics which vary. Pre-Requisite(s): MGT 3000 Management Information Systems

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Management Information Systems.title: IS/IT Management
Management Information Systems.description: Focuses on the theory and application of the information-systems discipline within an organizational context, and identifies the roles of management, users, and information systems professionals. Covers the use of information systems and implications for decision support to improve business processes, and addresses the ethical, legal, and social issues of IT.

Management Information Systems.title: Introduction to Business Programming
Management Information Systems.description: Develops business problem solving skills through the application of commonly used high-level business programming languages. Topics include foundational programming concepts practices and debugging and testing techniques. Introduces concepts for programming business analytics systems.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management Information Systems.title: Web Programming
Management Information Systems.description: Covers technologies, tools, and environments related to the development of mobile and web-enabled business solutions. Topics include the development environment for mobile and web-based solutions, key development technologies, desirable development practices, and design, programming, debugging and testing methods. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 236 Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2100 or CS 1122 or CS 1131

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Management Information Systems.title: Business Process Analysis
Management Information Systems.description: Studies business decision management discipline using business rules, process models (e.g. flowcharts, unified modeling language, swim lanes), and information systems to improve efficiency and effectiveness. Emphasis on industry standards and business process management used to increase productivity. Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000

Management Information Systems.title: Business Database Management
Management Information Systems.description: Emphasizes database principles that are constant across different database software products through concrete examples using a relational database management system. Provides a well- rounded business perspective about developing, utilizing, and managing organizational databases. Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000(C) or MIS 2100 or CS 1122 or CS 1131

Management Information Systems.title: Systems Analysis and Design
Management Information Systems.description: Provides an understanding of the IS development and modification process and the evaluation choices of a system development methodology. Emphasizes effective communication with users and team members and others associated with the development and maintenance of the information system. Stresses analysis and logical design of departmental-level information system. Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000(C) or MIS 2100(C) or CS 1122 or CS 1131

Management Information Systems.title: User-Centered Design
Management Information Systems.description: Studies user-centered design in development of effective interface solutions for business needs. Content may include input/output devices, user modeling, help and documentation, social issues, and usability evaluation. Emphasis on how interface design addresses human capabilities and capacities. Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000 or MIS 2100 or CS 1122 or CS 1131

Management Information Systems.title: Emerging Technologies
Management Information Systems.description: Focuses on understanding IT for competitive advantage and as an agent of transformation. Topics include managing IT infrastructure and architecture, facilitating information distribution throughout the enterprise, business applications for machine learning and artificial intelligence, and other emerging Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 237 trends and technologies. Pre-Requisite(s): (MIS 2100 and MIS 3200(C)) or (CS 2321 and CS 3141)

Management Information Systems.title: Information Systems Projects
Management Information Systems.description: MIS capstone course. Applies IS practices and artifacts as solutions to business problems using student-led project teams under faculty supervision. Students develop a working prototype of a business solution using good design and management practices. Pre-Requisite(s): (MIS 2100 and MIS 3100 and MIS 3200) or (CS 2321 and CS 3141 and CS 3425) or (MIS 2100 and MIS 3100 and MA 3720)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Management Information Systems.title: Management of Cyber Security
Management Information Systems.description: Review of information systems security concepts and industry best practices. The subject matter is organized to provide students a foundation about cybersecurity principles, the business value of cybersecurity, and national and international policy and legal considerations related to cybersecurity. Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000 or MIS 2100 or CS 1111 or CS 1122 or CS 1131

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Management Information Systems.title: Business Intelligence and Analytics
Management Information Systems.description: Focuses on generation and interpretation of business analytics relative to organizational decision making. Includes core skills necessary for constructing data retrieval queries in a relational database environment and processing data using appropriate programming languages. Introduces concepts related to data pipelining. Pre-Requisite(s): (MIS 2100 or CS 1122 or CS 1131) and (MIS 3100 or CS 3425)

Management Information Systems.title: Systems Design for Innovation and Entrepreneurship
Management Information Systems.description: This course is designed to support students who desire to design an IT software solution to commercialize. The course provides support for student entrepreneurs and innovators during various stages of the systems development life cycle, such as planning, requirements gathering, design and implementation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 238 Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000(C) or MIS 2100(C) or CS 1111(C) or CS 1122(C) or CS 1131(C) or SAT 1200(C)

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Management Information Systems.title: Special Topics in Management Information Systems
Management Information Systems.description: Examines current IS/IT topics and issues in greater depth from a managerial perspective. A single offering of this course will concentrate on one or two topics, which will vary. Pre-Requisite(s): MIS 2000 or MIS 2100 or CS 1122 or CS 1131 Marketing

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Marketing.title: Principles of Marketing
Marketing.description: Emphasizes decisions made in developing both strategic and tactical marketing plans. Uses computer simulations, experiential learning assignments, and marketing plan development to demonstrate principles of market segmentation, product development, pricing, distribution planning, and promotion.

Marketing.title: Consumer Behavior & Culture
Marketing.description: Introduces students to models, theories, practices, and sociocultural issues pertinent to consumers' decision making and lifestyle choices. Discussions will be based on a variety of disciplines: psychology, sociology, economics, and anthropology. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

Marketing.title: Integrated Marketing Communications
Marketing.description: Discusses how a variety of marketing communication methods, such as advertising, public relations, sales promotion, point-of-purchase, and direct marketing are developed, implemented, and evaluated in an integrative manner. Pre-Requisite(s): BA 3800 or MKT 3000

Marketing.title: Marketing Data Analytics
Marketing.description: Focuses on data-driven consumer insights for marketing decision-making. Topics include scientific research methodology, survey research, social media data-analysis, multivariate data analysis, information visualization, and report writing and presentations. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 239 Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710 or BUS 2100) and MKT 3000

Marketing.title: Sales and Sales Technology
Marketing.description: Focuses on sales force management and experience. Topics include the buying-selling process, sales data analysis, cutting-edge sales technologies, sales simulation and forecasting, negotiation, and sales strategies and tactics. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

Marketing.title: B2B Marketing in a Digital Age
Marketing.description: Emphasis is on B2B (Business to Business) marketing strategy. Topics include business marketing programs, buying center management, product offering using 3D printer, B2B case study, market trend analysis, and inter-firm relationship strategies. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

Marketing.title: Global Marketing
Marketing.description: Discusses the critical elements of international marketing strategy: socio-politico-economic environment, global consumer culture, entry strategy, and global marketing mix. Utilizes cases and examples in order for students to better understand the globalized marketplace. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

Marketing.title: Digital Media Marketing
Marketing.description: Introduces fundamentals of social media and e-commerce. Discussion also include search engine optimization, user-generated content, mobile applications, content strategies, social media campaigns, new media strategies, and future trends in digital marketing. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000

Marketing.title: Marketing Strategy
Marketing.description: Marketing capstone course. Discusses various aspects of creative and value-enhancing marketing strategies. Topics include branding, innovation, marketing research, marketing communication, services, consumer culture, corporate social responsibility, digital media marketing, and globalization. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3200 and MKT 3600 and MKT 4300(C) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 240

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Level(s): Graduate

Marketing.title: Special Topics in Marketing
Marketing.description: Examines current issues in marketing. Topics are selected based on the interest to faculty and students. Pre-Requisite(s): MKT 3000 Materials Sci. & Engineering

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Introduction to the structure, processing, properties, and performance of engineering materials, including metals, polymers, glasses, ceramics, and composites. Presents case studies covering selection of materials, component design, and analysis of component failures. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1112 or CH 1122 or (CH 1150 and CH 1151) or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering II
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Course is designed to address core competencies in the materials discipline. Materials processing methods are used as a vehicle to master concepts such as crystallography, imperfections, phase diagrams, microstructure, and development of mathematical skills and introduction to computational tools. Pre-Requisite(s): (MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800) and (ENG 1100 or ENG 1101)

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Project Work
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Students will participate on student teams working on industry-sponsored projects related to materials.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Processing I
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Classical chemical thermodynamics as applied to single and multicomponent materials systems. Topics include heat and mass balance, enthalpy, entropy, free energy, chemical reactions and equilibria, mass action, solution thermodynamics, phase diagram, stability/Pourbaix diagrams and electrochemistry. Pre-Requisite(s): (MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800) and MA 2160

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Processing II
Materials Science and Engineering.description: A continuation of Materials Processing I, which introduces the fundamental theories and equations governing transport phenomena. Topics include fluid flow, heat flow, diffusion, and chemical kinetics. Discusses the relationships between these subjects and the thermodynamic concepts covered in Materials Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 241 Processing I. Pre-Requisite(s): (MY 2110 or MSE 2110) and (MY 3100 or MSE 3100) and (MA 3520 or MA 3521 or MA 3530 or MA 3560)

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Characterization I
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Fundamentals of microstructural and chemical characterization of materials. Examines the physical principles controlling the various basic characterization techniques. Topics include crystallography, optics, optical and electron microscopy, and diffraction. Laboratory focuses on proper operational principles of characterization equipment, which includes optical and other microscopy methods and various diffraction techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2110 or MSE 2110

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Characterization II
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Fundamentals and application of instrumental analysis in characterization of bulk materials and powders, and their internal phases and external surfaces. Demonstrates spectroscopic and surface analysis techniques in identification of ceramics and polymers and their phases. Discusses the limitations and capabilities of elemental, chemical and structural characterization methods combined with statistical analysis of data. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Design of Microstructure
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Relates thermodynamic and kinetic principles to phase transformations and microstructural evolution. Topics include nucleation, solidification, precipitation, recrystallization, grain growth, and sintering. Applications of these concepts (e.g., heat treatment of steel, casting, powder processing, etc.) are presented to provide a bridge between phase transformation theory and industrial/laboratory practice. Pre-Requisite(s): MSE 2110 and MSE 3100 and MSE 3120 or (MSE 3121(C) and MSE 3122(C))

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Introduction to Semiconductor Materials & Devices
Materials Science and Engineering.description: An introduction to materials science and engineering of semiconductors. Topics include: semiconductor material electronic, thermal, and optical properties; how these properties are modified, how elementary devices made from these materials operate, and how devices function in electrical circuits depends on material selection and processing. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 242 Pre-Requisite(s): PH 2200 and MA 2160

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Material Design
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Integration of contemporary engineering design-modeling methodology with foundational structure- property-processing paradigm for materials design. Statistical analysis of laboratory measurements, formulating and testing of hypotheses, thermodynamic and kinetic modeling for material and process optimization, design of experiments. Pre-Requisite(s): MSE 3100 and MSE 3110(C) and MSE 3120(C) or (MSE 3121(C) and MSE 3122(C)) and MSE 3130(C) or (MSE 3131(C) and MSE 3132(C)) and MSE 3140(C) and ENG 1102

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Project Work
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Students participate on student teams working on industry-sponsored projects related to materials.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Special Topics - Materials Science & Engineering
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Special topics in Materials and Engineering. required

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Mechanical Behavior of Materials
Materials Science and Engineering.description: An introduction to the deformation and fracture behavior of materials. Topics include multiaxial stress and strain, elastic and plastic deformation, hardening mechanisms, viscoelasticity, fracture, fatigue, creep, and microstructure/property relationships. Pre-Requisite(s): (MY 2110 or MSE 2110) and (MEEM 2150 or ENG 2120)

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Introduction to Polymer Engineering
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Introductory study of polymeric materials and polymer engineering. Basics in polymer science including molecular characteristics, synthesis, structure and properties of polymers, with strong emphasis on thermodynamics of polymers. Various processing techniques and mechanical/ structural applications of polymers. Pre-Requisite(s): (MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800) and CH 1160

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Material and Process Selection in Design
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 243 The principles of materials selection for engineering design. Topics include selection based on strength, stiffness, thermal properties, high temperature behavior, corrosion resistance, formability, joinability, manufacturability, recyclability, etc. Considers ethics and economics. Presents numerous case studies and examples. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Science & Engineering Senior Design Project I
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Conducted in teams of students working with industrial partners. Open to all engineering majors interested in interdisciplinary senior design projects. Non-MSE majors must be senior project ready as defined by their major program and obtain permission of the MSE department. Pre-Requisite(s): MSE 3110 and MSE 3120 or (MSE 3121(C) and MSE 3122(C)) and MSE 3130 or (MSE 3131 and MSE 3132) and MSE 3140 and (MY 4940 or MSE 3190)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Capstone Professional Skills 1
Materials Science and Engineering.description: This course will include practical application of contemporary engineering design methodology within the structure-processing-properties paradigm for material design project management, experimental design, written and oral communication. Co-Requisite(s): ENT 4950 Pre-Requisite(s): MSE 3190 or MY 4940

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Materials Science and Engrg

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Science & Engineering Senior Design Project II
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Senior design project conducted in teams of students working with an industrial partner. Open to all engineering majors interested in interdisciplinary senior design projects. Senior project ready as defined by major substitutes for prerequisites. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 4920 or MSE 4130

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Capstone Professional Skills 2
Materials Science and Engineering.description: This course includes practical application of contemporary engineering design methodology within the structure- processing-properties paradigm for material design, project management, experimental design, written and oral communication. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 244 Co-Requisite(s): ENT 4960 Pre-Requisite(s): MSE 4131

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Materials Science and Engrg

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Introduction to MEMS
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Fundamentals of micromachining and microfabrication techniques, including planar thin-film process technologies, photolithographic techniques, deposition and etching techniques, and the other technologies that are central to MEMS fabrication.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Light and Photonic Materials
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Material properties controlling light wave propagation in optical crystals and optical wave guides. Photonic crystals and photonic devices based on electrical, magnetic, and strain effects. Engineering, Materials Science and Engrg; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior,Senior. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 2200 or EE 2190 or EE 3140

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Physics, Applied Physics, Electrical

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Principles of Metal Casting
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Principles of metal casting, including melting practice, casting design, mold design, heat transfer and solidification, fluid flow and gating design. Introduction to computer simulation techniques for mold filling, solidification, and development of residual stress. Structure-property relations in cast metals. Recycling and environmental issues of the cast metals industry. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Corrosion and Environmental Effects
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Mechanisms of corrosion processes, electrochemical and oxidation kinetics, and fundamentals of corrosion engineering. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 245

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Fundamentals of Corrosion
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Basic mechanisms of electrochemical processes and corrosion. Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1150 and CH 1151

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Advanced Physical Metallurgy
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Advanced physical metallurgy principles are utilized to rationalize the structure-process-properties- performance relationships of the engineering alloys. Alloy systems covered include steels, cast irons, aluminum, magnesium, titanium and nickel alloys. Internationally accepted alloy designations, heat treatment standards, and characterization protocols are also presented. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 3300 or MSE 3140

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore, Junior

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Science of Ceramic Materials
Materials Science and Engineering.description: The structure, defect chemistry, and properties of crystalline and amorphous ceramics. Utilization of these materials in a variety of applications such as electrolytes in fuel cells and as bioceramics are examined. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Composite Materials
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Mechanistic aspects of property development in metal, ceramic, and polymeric composites. The role of composite architecture, processing, and microstructure on properties. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Contact Mechanics and Nanoindentation
Materials Science and Engineering.description: The application of elastic and plastic contact mechanics in relation to nanoindentation with emphasis on the application of instrumentation, models and experimental techniques used to examine the small- scale mechanical behavior of metals, ceramics, polymers, composites, biomaterials, hydrogels, and structured devices. Pre-Requisite(s): (MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800) and (MA 3521 or MA 3520 or MA 3530) and Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 246 MEEM 2150

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Materials Forensics
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Probes fundamental physical principles important to various characterization techniques used to understand crystal structure, microstructure, and substructure in materials. Application of x-ray, electrons, and light to unravel the structural mystery of materials and apply techniques to material failure analysis. Pre-Requisite(s): MY 2100 or MSE 2100 or BE 2800

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Scanning Electron Microscopy and X-ray Microanalysis
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Topics include electron beam and image formation, beam- specimen interactions, and x-ray microanalysis. Course content is relevant to students of the physical sciences, engineering, and related disciplines. Includes a laboratory experience that provides hands-on practical training sufficient to enable independent use of the SEM.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Computational Materials Science: Theory, Modeling, Simulation, and Practice
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Theories of materials science from first principles to constitutive laws. Materials modeling and computer simulation at multiple length and time scales. Laboratory practice of various computational methods.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Hydrometallurgy/Pyrometallurgy
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Extraction and refining of metals and industrial chemicals from natural and recycled materials. Includes solution- chemistry processes (hydrometallurgy) and thermochemical processes (pyrometallurgy). Pre-Requisite(s): CH 1122 or (CH 1160 and CH 1161)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Environmental Engineering for Materials Processing Industries
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Assessment and analysis of environmental impacts from materials processing industries. Regulations, permits, and industrial practices for monitoring and solving air, water, and solid environmental issues. Pollution prevention. Life cycle analysis. Material flow analysis. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 247

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Distributed Additive Manufacturing Using Open-Source 3-D Printing
Materials Science and Engineering.description: This course provides an overview of open-source hardware in theory and practice for an introduction to distributed additive manufacturing using open-source 3-D printing. Each student will build a customized RepRap and will learn all hardware and software for maintaining it. enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of Engineering; Must be

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Special Topics - Materials Science & Engineering
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Special topics in materials science and engineering.

tags.Credits: variable to 4.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Materials Science and Engineering.title: Undergraduate Research
Materials Science and Engineering.description: Undergraduate research in materials science and engineering. Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Music

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Music Appreciation
Music.description: Overview of key composers, works, styles, and aesthetics in classical music, from Middle Ages plainchant to John Cage's experimental works in the 1940s-60s. Students will find compelling connections between music of the past and today's pop music.

Music.title: Western Music Fundamentals: Skill Acquisition in Music Reading, Sight- Singing, and
Music.description: Ear-Training This course provides the means for gaining a foundational knowledge of Western musical theory principles. The course includes study in improvisation, aural skills, composition using industry standard notation software and functional harmony within the framework of Western tonal music.

Music.title: Huskies Pep Band
Music.description: The Huskies Pep Band provides enthusiastic support for a number of athletic programs at MTU and participates in important events in the community. The HPB is one of the most visible programs in the University. We are known as one of the country's most spirited college pep bands anywhere. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 248

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Music.title: Campus Concert Band
Music.description: Concert band is for students wishing to perform in a concert wind band. The ensemble performs good music with moderate technical demands. Prior experience in a band or orchestra required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Music.title: Workshop Big Band
Music.description: This course is an ensemble that learns and performs classic jazz big band repertoire and New Orleans brass band music. The band learns anywhere from half to all of the music by ear without sheet music.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Private Music Instruction
Music.description: Professional private music instruction on brass, woodwind, string, percussion, piano, organ, guitar, voice, harp, and composition.

tags.Credits: 0.5; May be repeated; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Music.title: Group Voice
Music.description: The fundamentals of speech and singing including information about the vocal instrument, the vocal process, vocal technique, and how to learn and perform simple solo songs.

Music.title: History of Classical Music
Music.description: Developments in western classical music from the 1770s to 1970s in Europe, Russia, and America. Concentrates on music, style, aesthetics, culture, and biographies of major composers from the Classical, Romantic, and Twentieth-Century periods.

Music.title: Film Music
Music.description: This course surveys the development of film music. Students will learn how music functions to support the aesthetic/narrative elements of the story. Students will learn skills to identify how music manipulates the listener and how composers shape that manipulation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 249

Music.title: History of Rock
Music.description: This course acquaints students with the musical, historical, cultural, and sociological elements of Rock music. It covers the major stylistic eras from the 1920s to the 1990s, and the major artists and their contributions. Emphasis is placed on students developing critical listening skills.

Music.title: History of Jazz
Music.description: Covers the musical, historical, and sociological elements of America's only original musical art form, jazz. Focuses on the major stylistic eras from 1900 to the present in addition to the major artists and their contributions. Emphasizes developing interactive, aural, and critical skills.

Music.title: Music and Tradition
Music.description: This course introduces the student to the diversity of traditional music from around the globe. Students will explore the universal importance of music, its place within a global community, and effects of technology on the cross pollination of musical styles.

Music.title: The Broadway Musical
Music.description: A multimedia examination of important works of American musical theatre, how these works have mirrored or shaped our culture, and how New York City has shaped or been shaped by this vibrant art form.

Music.title: Western Music Theory I
Music.description: This course includes study in improvisation, part writing, counterpoint, aural skills, composition using industry standard notation software and functional harmony within the framework of Western tonal music. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2501 or MUS 1100

Music.title: Western Music Theory II
Music.description: This course includes study in improvisation, counterpoint, aural skills, and harmony within the framework of Western tonal music and musical style, form and composition in music from diverse musical traditions. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 250 Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2500 or MUS 2101

Music.title: Jazz Theory and Aural Skills
Music.description: This course covers jazz harmony, chord/scale theory, ear training, spelling chords, writing original chord progressions, analyzing jazz solo transcriptions, and analyzing jazz standards. Pre-Requisite(s): MUS 1100 or FA 2501

Music.title: Research and Development Jazz Band
Music.description: The Research and Development Jazz Band is for instrumentalists wishing to learn the fundamentals of jazz improvisation and the nuances of the jazz idiom. Repertoire includes swing, jazz, rock, Latin, ballads, fusion, and other contemporary jazz styles. Public performances are given on campus and in the surrounding area. Audition required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Concert Choir
Music.description: A select ensemble made up of student and community singers studying and performing traditional choral literature ranging from chant to avant-garde compositions. Activities include campus and community performances and occasional international tours. Audition required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Masterworks in Western Music Literature
Music.description: Examination of selected works from the canon of Western music. Topics change according to faculty preferences. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2500 or FA 2501 or MUS 1100(C) or MUS 2101(C)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Music.title: Beatles and Beach Boys
Music.description: Analysis of biography, formative vs. mature style, musical structure, and historical impact of the Beatles and the Beach Boys. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Music.title: Music Composition I
Music.description: This course is a study in the art of acoustic instrumental, vocal and MIDI composition. Students will study music of contemporary composers and create compositions for performance. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 251 Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2500 or MUS 2101) and (FA 3530 or MUS 2102(C))

Music.title: Music Composition II
Music.description: This course is a continuation of Music Composition I. Students expand their skills to include composition for media including, film, television, and digital arts. Students will apply their skills to create fully realized live performances of their compositions. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2500 or MUS 2101) and (FA 3530 or MUS 2102) and (FA 3112 or MUS 3101)

Music.title: Jazz Improvisation
Music.description: Explores the elements of jazz improvisation while developing creative ideas and technical facility in the individual musician. Emphasis will be placed on learning the idiomatic use of the major scale and associated modes, the jazz melodic minor scale, the blues scale, pentatonic scales, and the 8-tone dominant scale. Development of stylistic conformity by exploring the styles of swing, bebop, cool, blues, Latin and rock/funk. Emphasis on the II-V-I progression in major and minor keys and symmetric harmony. Pre-Requisite(s): MUS 2103

Music.title: Contemporary Music: The Search for New Sounds
Music.description: Contemporary Music will explore music from the late nineteenth century through today. The focus of the class will be modern composers' search for new sounds using electronic instruments, popular music, non- western music, and new performance techniques. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2500 or MUS 2101) and (FA 3560 or MUS 2000) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Music.title: Electronic Music: History and Practice
Music.description: Introduction to the history of, and practices of making, electronic music. This course presents a survey of the most significant artists in the history of electronic music. Provides hands-on training and projects in electronic music production. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 1601 and FA 1602) or (SND 1101 and SND 1102) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 252

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Music.title: Keweenaw Symphony Orchestra
Music.description: The KSO is a college-community orchestra comprising Tech students, Tech faculty, and community musicians. The ensemble performs the great orchestra, opera, and ballet masterworks. The orchestra presents 4-5 yearly concerts, including periodic concert tours. Audition required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Superior Wind Symphony
Music.description: The Wind Symphony is a concert wind ensemble of variable size and instrumentation for students with a serious interest in musical performance at a high level. Features a comprehensive approach to the literature to be performed, including study of composers and historical background. Audition required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Jazz Lab Band
Music.description: A select ensemble of approximately twenty instrumentalists studying jazz improvisation and performing literature for the jazz ensemble. Repertoire includes swing, jazz-rock, ballads, fusion, and experimental compositions. Activities include performances at festivals, concerts, and dances, and a spring-break tour. Course work includes topics in jazz history, music theory, and improvisation. Audition required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Chamber Choir
Music.description: Participation in the Chamber Choir provides opportunities for students to explore and perform music written for small choir. Repertoire from varied styles and time periods (from antiquity to the present) will be prepared and presented in formal and informal performance settings. Audition required.

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Visual & Performing Arts Tour
Music.description: Students participating in fine arts performance tours taking place outside of regular academic terms are eligible to receive credit based on the time span of the tour and the nature of the itinerary. Requires active membership in the touring group or permission of director.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; May be repeated; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Special Topics: Music
Music.description: Tutorial, seminar, or class study of a topic of special interest and importance in visual and performing arts. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 253

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; May be repeated

Music.title: Conducting and Interpretation
Music.description: A capstone seminar course that examines philosophies of music interpretation, analyzing music scores, comparing and contrasting recorded music, and defining musicianship. Students will learn basic conducting techniques and be given the opportunity to conduct live ensemble rehearsals. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2500 or FA 2501 or MUS 1100 or MUS 2101

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Jazz Arranging
Music.description: Explores elements of jazz arranging and composition while developing creative ideas in the individual musician. Emphasis on learning to arrange for jazz combo and traditional big band. Includes developing the shape concept of triad use, 4-part and 5-part chord voicing, construction of an arrangement, and competence with FINALE notational software. Pre-Requisite(s): MUS 2103

Music.title: Chamber Music Seminar
Music.description: For students interested in the study and performance of instrumental chamber music. Small ensembles meet regularly under faculty supervision.

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Jazz Combo
Music.description: Jazz combos (e.g., Jaztec, Salsa Norte) are select small groups of musicians studying jazz improvisation and performing literature for the small jazz ensemble. Focuses on developing individual improvisational techniques, personal style, and unique original arrangements. Repertoire includes swing, jazz-rock, ballads, fusion, and experimental techniques. Activities can include performances and tours.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Independent Study: Music
Music.description: Independent research directed by Visual and Performing Arts faculty. Projects focus on topics in music. Requires a written proposal setting out goals, pland for final project, and the resources required to complete the project. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 254

tags.Credits: variable to 6.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Music.title: Visual and Performing Arts Final Project
Music.description: Capstone course extending the student's knowledge and skill in a chosen fine arts discipline through independent research or other focused creative activity. A detailed proposal of the student's final project must be approved in writing by a Visual and Performing Arts faculty advisor before the student enrolls in FA4970. Freshman, Sophomore Operations & Supply Chain Mgmt

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Operations and Supply Chain Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: Fundamental principles of operations and supply chain management; includes strategic importance and relevant interrelated concepts and tools in product/process design, work systems, forecasting, inventory and materials management, just-in-time, scheduling, and capacity management. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121) and (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710 or MA 3720 or EET 2010 or BUS 2100 or CEE 3710)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Introduction to Supply Chain Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: An introduction to supply chain management to gain a perspective on integration and coordination issues. Topics include strategy, network design, facility design, sourcing, logistics, forecasting, inventory, relationship management, and global and sustainable supply chain management. Pre-Requisite(s): OSM 3000(C)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Procurement and Supply Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: Addresses processes that facilitate the management of value- added transactions and relationships between supplier and customer organizations. The course examines the management of the business purchasing function, including supplier selection and development, cost management, performance measures, buyer- supplier relationships, and negotiation.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Project Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: The various stages in a project life cycle will be covered and include initiation, planning, execution, and closeout. Basic tools such as the Project Charter, Network Diagrams Gantt, and budgeting will be Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 255 covered. Basics of MS Project are included. Pre-Requisite(s): BUS 2100 or CEE 3710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710 or EE 3180 or BE 2110 or MA 2710 or PSY 2720

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Advanced Project Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: A project-oriented business development class focused on real-life and advanced applications of project management techniques. Students participate in a competition, prepare for the PMI CAPM exam, and may sit for the exam to obtain certification. Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore Pre-Requisite(s): OSM 3200 or ENG 4300 or OSM 4300

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Six Sigma Fundamentals
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: Course is framed in context of six sigma methodology. Topics include principles of Shewhart, Deming, Taguchi; meaning of quality; control charts for variables, individuals, and attributes; process capability analysis; variation of assemblies; and computer-based workshops. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710 or MA 3720 or BUS 2100 or CE 3710 or CEE 3710

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Logistics and Transportation Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: Focuses on the transportation and distribution services that support demand fulfillment from the receipt of customer orders to order fulfillment. Topics include customer service, order fulfillment, inventory, transportation costs and modes, facility design and operation, carrier selection, and negotiation. Pre-Requisite(s): (MA 2710 or MA 2720 or MA 3710 or CE 3710 or CEE 3710) and (MA 1135 or MA 1160 or MA 1161 or MA 1121)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Operations and Supply Chain Management.title: Special Topics in Supply Chain and Operations Management
Operations and Supply Chain Management.description: Examines additional supply chain and/or operations management topics and issues in greater depth. A single offering of this course will concentrate on one or two topics, which vary. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 256 Pre-Requisite(s): OSM 3000 Physical Education

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6

Physical Education.title: Flag Football
Physical Education.description: Fundamental skills and rules will be learned for co-recreational play of flag football.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Bait and Fly Casting
Physical Education.description: Bait and fly casting skills. Each student must have a valid current year Michigan fishing license. Trout stamp is optional. Equipment is available if needed. Requires some additional hours outside of class.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Ultimate Frisbee
Physical Education.description: Fundamental skills, rules, and play of ultimate frisbee. The class is physically strenuous. Frisbees are provided.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Bowling I
Physical Education.description: Fundamental skills, rules, and scoring of bowling.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Golf
Physical Education.description: Rules, terminology, and etiquette of golf and the individual skills of grip, stance, and swing. Equipment is supplied.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Floor Hockey
Physical Education.description: Individual skills, team techniques, rules and strategies of floor hockey. Hockey gloves or winter gloves are highly recommended. Sticks and goalie equipment are provided.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Broomball
Physical Education.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 257 Students will learn the rules, strategy, and safety needed to compete in broomball. Offensive and defensive zone coverages and individual skills are stressed. Team play with officials.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Aikido
Physical Education.description: Aikido is a specific martial arts training for physical and character development. Physically strenuous. Students should wear loose sweatsuits (with long sleeves) or white martial arts uniform.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Disc Golf
Physical Education.description: Fundamental skills, rules and play of disc golf. Students will learn recreational play and organized tournament play (various formats). Students can bring their own disc (or discs); some are provided. The class meets at MTU's Disc Golf Course on Sharon Avenue by the Advanced Technology Development Complex.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Swimming
Physical Education.description: Nonswimmers learn to have no fear of water, to float, and to swim the four fundamental strokes.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Basketball
Physical Education.description: Theory, organization, and defensive and offensive skills of basketball.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Hockey
Physical Education.description: Individual skills, team techniques, rules, and strategies. Requires basic hockey equipment of helmet with face mask, shoulder pads, hockey pants, shin pads, elbow pads, hockey gloves, skates, supporter, jersey, hockey socks, hockey stick.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Weight Training
Physical Education.description: Training methods for physical development using stationary and free weights. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 258

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Fitness Training
Physical Education.description: This course is designed to introduce students to a variety of activities to improve their fitness and well being. Activities will include using aerobic machines and strength training. Students will learn the basic concepts of fitness and how to safely and properly use the fitness center equipment.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Alpine Skiing (Downhill)
Physical Education.description: Beginning skills of alpine skiing techniques taught, evaluated, and recommendations made for improvement. Students with skills above beginner level cannot take this class. Students must provide their own transportation to Mont Ripley. It is recommended that students provide their own equipment. Daily rental and "rent for the season" equipment available at Mont Ripley.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Beginning Snowboarding
Physical Education.description: Beginning skills of snowboarding techniques taught, evaluated, and recommendations made for improvement. Students must be a beginner or have never snowboarded to this class. Students with skills above beginner level cannot take this class. Students must provide their own transportation to Mont Ripley. It is recommended that students provide own equipment. Daily rental and "rent for the season" equipment available at Mont Ripley.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Softball
Physical Education.description: Fundamentals of throwing, fielding, and hitting a softball. Bats, balls, and bases are provided. Each student should bring a glove.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Telemark Skiing
Physical Education.description: The beginning skills of Telemark skiing techniques will be taught, evaluated and recommendations made for improvement. Students must provide own transportation and Telemark ski equipment. A limited amount of rentals are available.

tags.Credits: 0.5; Repeatable to a Max of 1; Graded Pass/Fail Only

Physical Education.title: Sand Volleyball
Physical Education.description: Sand volleyball rules, basic fundamentals and team play. Passing,setting, attacking, serving, blocking, round robin, 2 vs. 2, and 4 vs. 4 tournaments, 6 vs. 6 system and drills to improve one's overall play. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 259

Physics.title: The Physics Behind Music
Physics.description: Physics concepts and methods associated with musical instruments, musical recording, and musical acoustics are discussed at an introductory level. Topics include periodic motion, normal modes and resonance, superposition and Fourier series, waves, sound and acoustics, magnetism and electromagnetic induction, and topics from non-linear physics. Course is also offered online on demand in spring and summer semesters. Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or MA 1120(C)

Physics.title: The Physics Behind Music Lab
Physics.description: A companion hands-on lab course covering topics from PH1090. Pre-Requisite(s): PH 1090(C)

Physics.title: Honors Physics I - Mechanics
Physics.description: Calculus-based introduction to classical mechanics. Topics include mathematical concepts, kinematics, Newton's laws, the gravitational force, work and energy, and collisions. Also introduces departmental facilities, research within the department, and professional opportunities in physics. Intended for physics majors; highly motivated students seeking an invigorating introduction to physics may enroll with permission of the instructor. Co-Requisite(s): PH 1161 Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1160(C) or MA 1161(C) or MA 1121(C) or MA 2160(C)

The course emphasizes understanding physical concepts through inquiry and the scientific method. Physics Co-Requisite(s): PH 1160

Physics.title: Physics by Inquiry II
Physics.description: Experiments covering Coulomb's law, electric and magnetic fields, circuits, induction, and geometric optics are explored through guided construction. The course emphasizes understanding physical concepts through inquiry and the scientific method. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 278 Pre-Requisite(s): PH 1100 or PH 1111 or PH 1141 or PH 1161

Physics.title: College Physics II
Physics.description: An overview of basic principles of static and dynamic electricity and magnetism, electromagnetic waves, reflection and refraction of light, interference and diffraction of light, special theory of relativity, wave theory of matter, particle theory of electromagnetic waves, theory of the atom, the nucleus, and elementary particles. be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Physics, Construction Management, Surveying Engineering, Electrical Eng Tech, General Technology, Mechanical Engineering Tech, Applied Physics, Computer Network & System Admn Pre-Requisite(s): PH 1200(C) and (PH 1110 or PH 1100)
