Social Sciences.description: Introduction to geospatial sciences and technologies that are widely used for mapping and analyzing geographic patterns of human activities. Students gain hands-on experience in data collection, spatial data editing, georeferencing, spatial analysis, cartography, and spatial problem solving.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
Social Sciences.description: Introduction to the field of cultural anthropology with a focus on human diversity, patterns of culture and human organization, globalization, and social change.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Archaeology
Social Sciences.description: Introduction to the methods of archaeology and the contributions of the discipline to understanding of world prehistory. Topics include the ways archaeologists discover and excavate sites, the analysis of archaeological artifacts and features, human evolution, and the patterns of world prehistory.

Social Sciences.title: Community Development and Planning
Social Sciences.description: This introductory course will explore questions by examining the physical, social, and spatial systems that influence how and where we live, work, and play in the ever-changing industrial and post-industrial city.

Social Sciences.title: Environment and Society
Social Sciences.description: Examines social approaches to understanding why environmental problems happen and how environmental problems are resolved. Includes concepts such as sustainability, market-based environmental policies, property systems, and environmental justice. Case studies may include biodiversity, deforestation, climate change, water quality, and toxics.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Human Geography
Social Sciences.description: This course introduces students to concepts, problems, and case studies that make up the study of human geography: the spatial differentiation and organization of human activity, environmental Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 308 sustainability, and the role of space and place in our everyday lives.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Sustainable Tourism
Social Sciences.description: An introduction to core travel and tourism concepts and sustainable tourism practices and policies. Focus will be upon critical comparison of tourism impacts and the conceptualization of their own sustainable tourism experience.

Social Sciences.title: United States History to 1877
Social Sciences.description: This broad historical survey will examine the social, political, and economic development of North America and the US from initial human settlement through the civil war.

Social Sciences.title: United States History Since 1877
Social Sciences.description: This broad historical survey will examine important intellectual, political, and social changes and events in the United States over the course of the twentieth century and beyond, representing the perspective of a wide variety of diverse individuals and groups.

Social Sciences.title: European History to 1650
Social Sciences.description: A survey of the history of Europe from the Archaic Greek period to 1650. Covers political, social, intellectual, religious, economic, and artistic developments of the European continent.

Social Sciences.title: European History Since 1650
Social Sciences.description: A survey of the history of Europe from the mid-seventeenth century to the present. Covers political, social, intellectual, religious, economic, and artistic developments on the European continent.

Social Sciences.title: World History to 1500
Social Sciences.description: An introduction to the basic themes and content of world history from antiquity to 1500 CE. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 309

Social Sciences.title: World History Since 1500
Social Sciences.description: Survey of world history from 1500 CE to the present. Traces the evolution of different societies from around the world, emphasizing exchanges, interactions, and conflicts that produced global change.

Social Sciences.title: Gender and the Past
Social Sciences.description: This course has two main goals: to explore the relationship between gender in the past and present; and to evaluate the actual empirical evidence that speaks to people's gendered lives in many times and places.

Social Sciences.title: American Government & Politics
Social Sciences.description: Outlines the principles and logic of American Government and politics and explores contemporary issues in national and state government.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Law and Society
Social Sciences.description: Examining the civil and criminal justice system to explain how law informs yet is shaped by political, economic, and social forces. This course covers issues such as individual rights, the jury system, tort law, legal reform movements and constitutional interpretation.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Public Policy
Social Sciences.description: Introduction to key public policy and public management concepts and issues.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to American Foreign Policy
Social Sciences.description: This course offers a general introduction to American foreign policy formulation and execution. It considers how US foreign policy institutions function to address current foreign policy challenges. The goal of this course is to provide students with the tools for understanding America's place in the world and its foreign relations.

Social Sciences.title: Comparative Politics
Social Sciences.description: Study of the government and politics of non-U.S. countries. Covers parliamentary, authoritarian, and Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 310 presidential systems. Some attention to politics of the European Union.

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Sociology
Social Sciences.description: Introduces students to the way that sociologists think about different components of society. Topics include the family, religion, markets, organizations, political systems, and educational systems. Also covers the source of individual values, beliefs, and attitudes.

Social Sciences.title: Statistics for Social Science
Social Sciences.description: Introduces students to quantitative analysis of social phenomena. Emphasizes understanding and proper interpretation of graphs; data quality; measures of central tendency, dispersion, and association; the concept of statistical significance; and interpretation of basic OLS regression. Introduces statistical software. of Sciences & Arts, College of Business Pre-Requisite(s): MA 1020(C) or MA 1030(C) or MA 1120(C) or MA 1031(C) or MA 1032(C) or ALEKS Math Placement >= 61 or ACT Mathematics >= 22 or SAT MATH SECTION SCORE-M16 >= 540

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following College(s): College of For Res & Env Sci, College

Social Sciences.title: Contemporary Racial Inequality in the United States
Social Sciences.description: This course provides a social science overview of issues of race, inequality, and social justice in America. Topics will include the idea of race and the history of race relations, understandings of the economic, political, and cultural causes and consequences of racial inequality, and the study of social movements to address racial inequality.

Social Sciences.title: Undergraduate Program for Exploration and Research in Social Sciences (UPERSS)
Social Sciences.description: An undergraduate research experience for students to work with a faculty mentor to undertake research, creative work, or community-based project. The student typically signs up for 1-3 credits per semester. Requires GPA of 2.5 or higher.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Social Sciences.title: Native American and Indigenous Communities
Social Sciences.description: Exploration of contemporary Native American and Indigenous communities worldwide, using a cross- cultural and comparative approach, with some historical context. Topics examined include the legacy of settler colonialism, issues facing Indigenous communities today, and Indigenous renewal and Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 311 resistance, with emphasis on Native North America. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Food Systems & Sustainability
Social Sciences.description: Compares the embedded nature of culturally defined food production and consumption habits: the crux of nature meeting and mixing with culture. The course features classic food system scholarship as well as emerging topics and contemporary case studies. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Archaeology of the Modern World
Social Sciences.description: Introduction to historical archaeology. Topics include the methods of historical archaeology, theoretical approaches, and sources of evidence. Emphasizes archaeological contributions to understanding of the American past, and the contributions of historical archaeology to an alternative view of American history and culture. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Field Archaeology
Social Sciences.description: Practical experience and training in the methods and techniques of field archaeology. Selected readings are followed by active participation in site survey, testing, excavation, record keeping, and analysis. Students benefit through involvement in ongoing research projects. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: variable to 8.0; Repeatable to a Max of 8

Social Sciences.title: Archaeological Sciences
Social Sciences.description: Introduction to the archaeological sciences, including geo/bioarchaeology and materials science. Course emphasizes connections between field and laboratory, and scientific and environmental perspectives on the world's peoples and cultures, both ancient and industrial. Co-Requisite(s): SS 3222

Social Sciences.title: Archaeological Sciences Laboratory
Social Sciences.description: Using hands-on exercises and project-based learning, labs include identification, analysis, and Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 312 stabilization of metals, ceramics, and organics from archaeological contexts, and include elements of geo- and bioarchaeology, and materials science. Co-Requisite(s): SS 3221

Social Sciences.title: Capitalism and the Modern World
Social Sciences.description: This course explores from an anthropological perspective themes concerned with the increasing interconnectedness of world cultures and economies after 1400. Focusing on Western expansion and the establishment of global networks in the Modern Era and tracing the social, political, and economic interactions that have shaped our contemporary world. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Archaeology of Industry
Social Sciences.description: The study of industrial heritage using archaeological and historical perspectives. Covers theories, methods, and techniques by means of lectures, readings, and case studies. Students conduct original research, generally on Copper Country industrial sites, under the guidance of the instructor. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2200 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Reading the Landscape: Anthropology, Geography, History
Social Sciences.description: Landscape is a lens through which scholars study people, environment, and place. The concept transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries. Students will read and discuss different approaches to landscape, with special focus upon anthropological, geographic, and historical perspectives. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Biological Anthropology
Social Sciences.description: A human evolution course focusing upon a summary of general bio -anthropological principles of evolutionary change, the current fossil record evidencing human evolution, and the consequences of human evolutionary change for modern human variability, health, and behavior. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Social Sciences.title: Latin American Cultural History
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 313 This course examines the diverse, but interconnected, cultures of Latin America. The class will examine the sources and patterns of particular cultural traditions, while at the same time understanding the trajectory of social, political, and economic transformations throughout the region. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Anthropology of Energy
Social Sciences.description: Examines energy and its role in culture & human society from the 19th century to the present. Case studies from around the world are used to expore energy infrastructure, consumption, and technology and its role in culture and human society. Approach is historical and comparative across disciplines emphasizing the different modes of explanation. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Sustainability Science
Social Sciences.description: Foundational scientific concepts (dynamic systems and catastrophe theory) as applied to socioecological systems. Use of indicators and indices to track progress towards sustainability goals. Review of local, national, and global sustainability policies to avoid catastrophes and guide sustainable development. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Population, Health, and Environment
Social Sciences.description: This course investigates relationships between the world's population, population change, population distribution, resource consumption, and environmental, health, and social consequences. Addresses local and global relationships and the population processes (mortality, fertility, and migration) involved. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Contemporary Europe
Social Sciences.description: Examination of the landscapes and cultures of modern Europe. Emphasizes cultural patterns and diversity, environmental quality, economic development, and forces of economic and political unification. Examines urbanization, industry, population, nationalism, and political change through regional examples. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 314 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Imaginary Worlds: Geographies of Science Fiction and Fantasy
Social Sciences.description: Connects topics from human, physical, and environmental geography to relevant work in science fiction and fantasy, how popular culture shapes understandings of nature and place, and how geography is used in media to exert and challenge power. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Making History: Historical Research and Writing
Social Sciences.description: Learn how and why historians examine the past, and how they craft stories about it for readers. Emphasis on disciplinary approaches and philosophies of history. Students will practice research skills with archival, oral, and digital sources, and apply them in written, oral, and online work products.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Military History of the U.S.
Social Sciences.description: History of the American military and its place in American society in both peace and war from the colonial period until the present. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of American Technology
Social Sciences.description: Survey of the technological changes that transformed a rural, agrarian America into an urban, industrialized nation. Focuses on how America's social values and geographical situation influenced the direction taken by its technology and engineering community and how America's industrialization, in turn, had significant effects on American society. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of Science in America
Social Sciences.description: Examines the development of scientific enterprises in the U.S. from the colonial period through the present day. Emphasizes institutional bases of science and the place of scientific activities within American society. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 315 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of Making Things: Craft and Industry in America
Social Sciences.description: Examines historical relationships between skill, tool use, embodied knowledge, and the design process in America from the colonial era to today. Includes production techniques, distribution systems, technological changes, industrialization, post-war globalization, and current craft and design. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of American Architecture
Social Sciences.description: Survey of North American architecture from prehistoric times to the present. Focuses on principal architectural styles, building types, and construction technologies. Also examines ideas about architecture to understand the American past. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: U.S. Environmental History
Social Sciences.description: Examines how human interaction with physical environment has changed in North America over the last four centuries. Topics include uses of land by Native Americans, changes associated with European colonization, incorporation of natural resources into industrial economy, early conservation and preservation movements, and environmental concerns accompanying urbanization and industrialization. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: The Automobile in America
Social Sciences.description: Examines the automobile in diverse ways, seeing it as a complex product to be manufactured, as a stimulus to reshaping the environment, as an object that has altered social behavior, and as a problem solver and problem maker. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: History of Privacy
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 316 Privacy has been a defining characteristic of human experience since ancient times. But what is privacy? Students will interrogate the experiences, meanings, and definitions of privacy throughout history. The thematic structure of this course will allow students to explore the question of 'what is privacy' through a variety of disciplinary lenses. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of Michigan
Social Sciences.description: The history of Michigan from before European settlement to the present. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: The Copper Country
Social Sciences.description: Examines the social, labor, and technological history of the Copper Country from the frontier era until the shutdown of the mines. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: History of Detroit
Social Sciences.description: An exploration of the social, cultural, political, and economic history of Detroit from the era before European contact through the present. The course will combine lectures, discussion, activities, examinations and an analytical essay in order to investigate the history of Detroit from a variety of perspectives. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Renaissance & Reformation
Social Sciences.description: The history of Europe from 1300 to 1650. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Empires in World History
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 317 This course examines the social, political, cultural, economic, and geographical dimensions of imperialism. Students will research ancient and modern empires, with an emphasis on the long-run effects of the emergence, evolution, and collapse of empires. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of England I
Social Sciences.description: The social, economic, and political history of England from Stonehenge to 1750. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of England II
Social Sciences.description: History of England from 1750 to the present, including political, social, and economic developments in the period of Britain's greatest influence in the world. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Technology and Society in History
Social Sciences.description: An exploration of the history of technology and society. The course looks at ways technology influenced development of civilization and ways societal values of civilization have conditioned technology. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: History of Science
Social Sciences.description: A survey of the development of scientific ideas (abstractions about how nature is and behaves) from the Greeks to the modern world, including major physical and life science revolutions by natural philosophers like Copernicus, Galileo, Darwin, and Einstein. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: International Relations
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 318 An introduction to the field and study of International Relations (IR). This course will cover major IR theories and current topics in global politics including: globalization, terrorism, human rights, and environmentalism. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Public Policy and Public Management
Social Sciences.description: Key public policy and public management concepts are introduced and applied to the student's field of interest. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Policy Analysis
Social Sciences.description: This course provides students with a working knowledge of how public policy decisions are made, the policy analysis tools that support decisions, and practice applying the knowledge to conduct a policy analysis project. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2620(C) and SS 2001(C) and (PSY 2720(C) or MA 2720(C) or SS 2720(C))

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Environmental Policy and Politics
Social Sciences.description: A broad survey of how environmental policy making actually works in the U.S. Covers both environmental policy processes and politics, and the major environmental policies themselves for control of air pollution, water pollution, hazardous wastes, and other major environmental problems. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Selected Topics in Cyber-Law
Social Sciences.description: Applies legal and ethical principles to evolving computer technology. Explores current legal issues such as surveillance, privacy, free speech, crime, encryption, on line contracting, intellectual property and censorship, as well as legislative efforts to resolve these and other computing dilemmas. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 319 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Intellectual Property Management
Social Sciences.description: Covers principles of intellectual property law, addressing managerial and policy issues in copyright, trademark, trade secret, and patents. Readings and discussions also cover how these property and legal systems impact the balance between property exclusivity, technological innovation, and public access. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Constitutional Law
Social Sciences.description: Introduces the U.S. Constitution and how it has been interpreted by the Supreme Court over time. Explores historical, social and political consequences of major constitutional themes such as federalism, judicial review, and evolving view of individual rights and liberties. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Civil Rights & Civil Liberties
Social Sciences.description: Seminar focused on the rights and liberties guaranteed by US Constitutional amendments. Students learn constitutional theory and interpretation on topics of privacy, speech, media, religion, criminal justice, and gender/ethnic equality. Constitutional Law I is not required. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Crime, Incarceration, and Social Policy
Social Sciences.description: Explores criminal and social justice policies including policing and control of crimes involving violence, drugs, sexual offenses, and terrorism. Sentencing, effects of mass incarceration, and inequalities based on race and class will also be examined in student writing and debate. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Social Inequality
Social Sciences.description: A critical assessment of social and cultural processes associated with group-based or categorical patterns of inequality. Examines the creation, persistence, and attempts at reduction of structured inequality based on categorical factors such as social class, race, ethnicity, and gender. May explore other significant sources of social inequality. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 320 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Sustainability and the Private Sector
Social Sciences.description: This course provides an overview of corporate social responsibility (CSR), and how it is being implemented with particular consideration for interaction with government and the non-profit sector. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Human Dimensions in Natural Resources Stewardship
Social Sciences.description: Uses sociological concepts to enhance understanding of shared natural resource stewardship regimes, including human-environment relationships, beliefs and values, rights and responsibilities associated with sovereignty; and the diversity of knowledge systems and expertise related to natural resource practices and policies. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Energy Policy and Technology
Social Sciences.description: This course examines the policies and technologies affecting the production, transportation, and use of energy. It focuses on U.S. domestic energy policy and places it in the context of the global energy system. The course aims at providing a holistic view of energy systems connecting technological options with societal and environmental concerns. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Science, Technology, & Society
Social Sciences.description: Examines the relationship between science, technology, society, and the environment. Topics may include effects of technologies such as computers, biotechnology, and chemicals on society and nature, science and technology policy, and the history of technology and its global consequences. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Environmental Justice
Social Sciences.description: This course focuses on the histories, theories, and practices of environmental justice in local, national, Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 321 and global contexts. Topics to be explored include environmental racism, industrial facility siting, sustainable development, as well as food, energy, and climate justice. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Energy Security and Justice
Social Sciences.description: This course focuses on concepts that are fundamental to energy policy: energy security and energy justice. It introduces students to the three main views of energy security (supply, demand, and energy services). In addition, the course provides a critical perspective of evaluating energy decision-making through the lenses of justice. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Energy and Society
Social Sciences.description: This course reviews extent that our lives are integrated with energy production and consumption, and related problems and solutions in our interwined energy and social systems. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Histories and Cultures
Social Sciences.description: Covers selected topics in world history, geography, or anthropology. Important concepts are the relationship between societies and regional geography, the sources and patterns of major cultures, and transformations of social, cultural, political, and economic institutions over time. May be repeated if topic differs. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Sustainable Living Practicum
Social Sciences.description: Practice, evaluate, and reflect on ways to live sustainably in daily life with a particular focus of the workings of MTU's Sustainability Demonstration House (SDH). Planning and evaluating SDH activities for continual improvement and sustainability self reflections are core tasks. Students serve as sustainability leaders for MTU and beyond. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 322

tags.Credits: variable to 2.0; May be repeated; Graded Pass/Fail Only
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Social Sciences.title: Topics in Anthropology/Archaeology
Social Sciences.description: Survey of a major branch of American anthropology or archaeology, or a specific time period or region. Topics may include North American prehistory, experimental archaeology, applied anthropology, economic anthropology, or other specialized themes. Readings will emphasize both theoretical and substantive contributions. May be repeated if topics differ. Pre-Requisite(s): (SS 2100 or SS 2200) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Social Sciences.title: Topics in American History
Social Sciences.description: Examines an important theme, topic, or era in the development of American society, ranging from the colonial era up to the present. May include such topics as the Vietnam War, sports in America, American vernacular architecture, or urban America, all from a historical viewpoint. May be repeated if topic differs. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Topics in European History
Social Sciences.description: Examines important themes, topics, or eras in European history, from late Antiquity to the present. Topics may include intellectual history, revolutions, monarchy, military history (incl. the Crusades), or migrations. May be repeated if topic differs. See department for current offering. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Topics in World History
Social Sciences.description: Examines major ideas, processes, and events in world history. Topics may include trade and commodities, imperialism, slavery, migration, or other subjects with transnational significance. May be repeated if topic differs Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 6
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Cultural Immersion
Social Sciences.description: Course designed for students on supervised study abroad or exchange programs in which they investigate and report on cultural patterns and behaviors. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 323 Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Social Sciences.title: Preparing for Cross-Cultural Immersion Experiences
Social Sciences.description: Preparation for study abroad, service learning, and cross-cultural research or internships. Students reflect on their cultures; explore how to live and work effectively with other cultural groups, discuss cross-cultural professional ethics; and practice collecting and analyzing data from cross-cultural, immersive field work. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Topics in the Social Sciences
Social Sciences.description: Examines an important theme or topic in the social sciences, such as social theory, work and society, or the engineer in American society. May be repeated if topic differs. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Independent Study
Social Sciences.description: Independent study of topic of special interest with assistance and supervision from appropriate faculty.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Social Sciences.title: History of Social Thought
Social Sciences.description: An intensive survey of the literature of 19th-20th century history of social thought, including the writings of Marx, Durkheim, Weber, and other prominent anthropologists, sociologists, and political philosophers. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Social Sciences.title: Introduction to Survey Methodology
Social Sciences.description: A general introduction to survey methods. Students will learn the basics of survey design from questionnaire construction to the measurement of complex social science concepts. Students will also demonstrate their ability to conduct an original survey through a class project.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Applied Statistics for the Social Sciences
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 324 Covers applied methods used in conducting empirical research in the social sciences. Topics include research design, hypothesis testing, measurement of concepts, and computer-based data analysis. Assumes familiarity with Social Sciences concepts. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2720 or PSY 2720 or MA 2720 or BUS 2100

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Civic Communications
Social Sciences.description: This applied course gives students practice producing professional communications for policymakers, community leaders, and other decision-makers - translating research for decision-making by writing policy briefs, creating infographics, visualizing data in charts, tables, and other graphics, and giving professional presentations to the public. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2001 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Advanced GIS Methods and Projects
Social Sciences.description: Advanced application of Geographic Information Systems in social sciences as a tool to collect and analyze qualitative and quantitative data. Students gain hands-on experience in data collection, advanced spatial analysis, and scripting. Pre-Requisite(s): (SS 2050 or FW 3540 or GE 3250 or GE 4540 or SU 3540 or SU 4010 or SU 4012) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Sustainable Development and Communities
Social Sciences.description: Advanced anthropology course that focuses on cultural, social structural, historical, and environmental analyses of sustainable development. Students engage with relevant social theory and practical applications in sustainable development case studies. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Environmental Anthropology
Social Sciences.description: A seminar on the study of culture and politics in marginal environments and disadvantaged communities. Draws upon research in anthropology and geography to examine the interaction in the Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe, the Pacific, and the Arctic. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 325 Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2100 and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Ethnographic Methods
Social Sciences.description: Field-based course that surveys basic concepts of ethnography and applies them in a class research project. Provides practical experience in field observation, interviews, field notes, and write-up of research. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Archaeological Thought in Society
Social Sciences.description: This course explores themes concerned with the intellectual development of archaeology, including research methods, theoretical concepts, and problems that have characterized the history of the discipline. Particular emphasis is placed on the broader social contexts in which archaeology has developed.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Archaeological Analysis and Interpretation
Social Sciences.description: Course focuses on how archaeologists mobilize material data to understand everyday life in the past. Discussion, exercises, and lab time are used to cover the goals of archaeology, nature of archaeological data, research design, sampling, typology, classification, database management, and quantitative and qualitative analytical methods. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2200

Social Sciences.title: Water Policy, History, and Governance
Social Sciences.description: This course will explore the global history, politics, and governance of freshwater resources. Topics will include the effects of forestry, mining, watershed management, sanitation systems, climate change, fisheries, contaminants, and agriculture on water history, governance, and policies. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 3520

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Seminar in Sustainability
Social Sciences.description: This seminar in sustainability topics will cover a rotating set of topics, depending on semester offering. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 326 Topics may include energy use, justice, pollution, green design, or regulations bearing on sustainability. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9
tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Environmental Sociology
Social Sciences.description: Examines changing relationships between social systems (government, economy, etc.) and the environment. Explores the structural and cultural causes and consequences of such topics as production, consumption, population, energy systems, climate change, pollution, and environmental justice and how to respond to these issues through policies and actions. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2700 or SS 2400

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Social Sciences.title: Memory and Heritage
Social Sciences.description: Provides a broad and deep overview into the prevalent debates, cases, and methods within the transdisciplinary fields of memory and heritage studies; students apply these processes in collaborative and individualized cases. Memory work in post-violence and post-industrialization communities, politics, and performances will be framed globally.

Social Sciences.title: Sustainable Tourism and Planning
Social Sciences.description: A sustainable and systematic approach and critique to tourism planning and development. Students assess issues of inequity, exploitation, and environmental impacts in tourism planning, modes of redress and resistance, and develop solutions in hypothetical and applied scenarios. Pre-Requisite(s): (SS 2450 or SS 2100 or SS 2400 or SS 2700) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Senior Thesis
Social Sciences.description: Directed study leading to production of a senior thesis for all social science majors. Junior, Senior

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Social Sciences.title: Historical Research
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 327 This course supports historical research in conjunction with any upper-division history seminar. Students must take both courses simultaneously, and will work directly with the instructor to produce an original research paper. Freshman

tags.Credits: 1.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Social Sciences.title: Deindustrialization and the Urban Environment
Social Sciences.description: This course examines economic, environmental, and social problems associated with deindustrialization in postwar North American cities and the strategies adopted to ameliorate them. Major topics include segregation and housing, environmental regulation, environmental justice, industrial heritage, and economic and urban development policy. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Global Environmental History
Social Sciences.description: This course explores changes in human interactions with earth systems over time, starting with the development of agriculture and continuning to the present. Case studies include mining, forestry, water, agricultural, sustainability, and urban development. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 3520

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: History of Technology
Social Sciences.description: Advanced reading and discussion course focusing on the various ways in which we understand writing about the history of technology. This course provides the theoretical framework for research and writing in the field, and culminates in a major research project with primary source research as well as a required interpretive component. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2500 or SS 2501 or SS 2502 or SS 2503 or SS 3510 or SS 3580

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Industrial Communities
Social Sciences.description: Introduces advanced students to scholarly literature on industrial communities and company towns. Focus will be in North America, but also includes cases in Latin America, Europe, Africa, and Asia. Students will acquire skills in oral history, work with archival materials, and conduct field-based research. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 328

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Historical Archaeology
Social Sciences.description: This course examines the relevance of archaeology and the varied approaches archaeologists use in examining our Modern World. How do archaeologists interpret the archaeological record and how do archaeological perspectives effect the questions, interpretations, and meanings we bring to understanding the past, the present, and the future.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Material Culture Studies
Social Sciences.description: Advanced reading and research in material culture studies. Learn to interpret the cultural and historical meanings in physical objects such as tools, housewares, memorials, furniture, etc. Emphasis on American craft, industry, and deindustrialization. Methodologies from archaeology, American studies, museum studies, public history, art history, etc. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 3513

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Industrial Archaeology
Social Sciences.description: This course is an advanced exploration of the industrial past using archaeological perspectives. It is a seminar combining scholarship from different fields and using material evidence to examine the evolution of work and production in industrial society. Pre-Requisite(s): SS 2200 or SS 3200 or SS 3230 or SS 3270

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Social Sciences.title: Advanced Research in the Social Sciences
Social Sciences.description: Capstone course for students to develop an original social science thesis research project in the areas of History, Anthropology, Law, Sociology, or Sustainability. Students will prepare a proposal for a senior research project or thesis.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Social Sciences.title: Communities and Research
Social Sciences.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 329 A rural sociology course analyzing the sustainability of rural communities (socially, environmentally, economically, and culturally). The course involves participatory research conducted together with a local community organization. Students practice research skills while making a difference in improving community life. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.title: Geographies of Migrant Communities
Social Sciences.description: Covers the geographies of ethnic identity and nationalism, national identity and territory, borderlands and diasporas, national separatism and the variety of ways in which cultural difference asserts itself. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.title: Seminar in Social Sciences
Social Sciences.description: An intensive seminar study of a topic of importance and special interest in the social sciences. Topics could focus on the history of anthropological theory or on world religious systems in comparison. May be repeated if topic differs.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0; Repeatable to a Max of 9

Social Sciences.description: Assessment of learning and preparation for post-graduate work, professional training, or graduate school. Sciences, Anthropology, History; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Social Sciences.description: Internship, on or off campus, providing appropriate practical, professional experience in an area related directly to a student's course of study. Students work under professional supervision. Requires a written evaluation of the work.

Social Sciences.title: Washington Internship - Professional Practicum
Social Sciences.description: Students participate in a colloquium in Washington D.C., offered as part of an academic internship Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 330 program, that includes a range of prominent speakers, information interviews, and a capstone reflection. This course will have a program fee attached that is equal to the room and board fee charged by the Washington Center. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Social Sciences.description: Students take an academic course that is offered as part of an academic internship program in Washington D.C., with offerings including courses in American history and government, international affairs, and law.

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0
tags.Restrictions: Permission of department required

Social Sciences.title: Directed Study in Anthropology
Social Sciences.description: An original study of an anthropological problem, including literature search, data collection, and analysis, culminating in a research report. Senior Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Credits: variable to 3.0
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es):

Social Sciences.title: Topics in the Social Sciences
Social Sciences.description: Examines an important theme or topic in the social sciences, such as social theory, work and society, or the engineer in American society. May be repeated if topic differs. Surveying

Surveying.title: Introduction to Geospatial Engineering
Surveying.description: Introduction to the geospatial engineering profession with emphasis on technology and careers. Topics include: technology, specialties, education, professional practice, life-long learning, and ethics related to geospatial engineering. Geospatial Engineering

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Surveying Engineering,

Surveying.title: Introduction to Surveying
Surveying.description: An introductory course exploring surveying instruments and their use in the measurement of angles, distances and elevations. Subject areas apply mathematics, fundamentals of mapping, computational Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 331 methods, measurement analysis and proper instrument care in plane surveying.

Surveying.title: Geospatial Computations
Surveying.description: Course covers the methods and techniques to observe, analyze and report field measurement data through surveying applications. Topics include horizontal and vertical control, survey data reduction, computations, computer applications, and coordinate geometry. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2000(C)

Surveying.title: Route and Engineering Surveying
Surveying.description: Study of the geometry and computations utilized in the design and construction of roads and highways. Topics include horizontal, spiral and vertical curves, alignments, centerline profiles/cross sections, grades, earthwork quantities and mass diagrams. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2050 or SU 2000

Surveying.title: Surveying Field Practice
Surveying.description: Field to finish survey projects using current surveying instrumentation and software. Field applications include: Cadastral, topographic, as-built, quantity, construction layout, ALTA, and control surveys. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2220 and SU 2050

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Surveying.title: Boundary Surveying Principles
Surveying.description: Interpretation of property descriptions used to establish land boundaries. Resolving conflicts in boundary descriptions as well as conflicts in evidence. Review doctrines pertaining to transferring title and the role of the surveyor in issuing opinions on boundary location in boundary disputes. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2000

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Surveying.title: Surveying Computations and Adjustments
Surveying.description: Basic computations and analysis of surveying measurements by adjustment theory are introduced. Students will gain the ability to use computer software to perform the computations. Analysis of measurements and errors based on statistical principles and least squares principles will be discussed. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 332 Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2050 and (MA 2320 or MA 2321 or MA 2330) and MA 3710(C)

Surveying.title: Geospatial Concepts, Technologies, and Data
Surveying.description: High level review of geospatial data acquisition systems, sensors, and associated processing technologies. Course considers geospatial metadata generation principles, interoperability, and major tools for manipulation with geospatial data. Course may help in transition of non-geospatial majors to geospatial field. Engineering, Geospatial Engineering

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Integrated Geospatial Tech, Surveying

Surveying.title: Cadastre and Land Information Systems
Surveying.description: Topics include: an introduction to land rights, land ownership, lease, and traditional rights, mortgaging and land as capital, description of land rights, boundary description, land information systems, examples of cadastre types over the globe, and modern technical aspects.

Surveying.title: Geospatial Data Mining and Crowdsourcing
Surveying.description: This course comprises theory and applications of geospatial data mining. Typical application scenarios are covered. Attention is given to open-source data and systems crowdsourcing, as well as social media. Special focus on imaging and visual analytics.

Surveying.title: Hydrographic Mapping and Surveying
Surveying.description: This course comprises theory and applications of hydrographic mapping technologies. Typical application scenarios are covered. An intensive lab component provides hands-on experience in hydrographic data processing and visualization.

Surveying.title: Geodesy
Surveying.description: Introduction to geometrical and physical geodesy. Examines computations on the ellipsoid, elements of datums, map projections, and state plane coordinate systems. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 333 Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2050 and (MA 2320 or MA 2321 or MA 2330) and MA 2160

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Surveying.title: Geodetic Positioning
Surveying.description: Introduces the theory and practice of global positioning systems, primarily global navigation satellite systems (GNSS). Examines data collection, quality assessment, analysis and adjustment. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 4060 and SU 3600(C)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Surveying.title: Photogrammetry & UAV Mapping
Surveying.description: Basic principles of photogrammetry and its role as a technology for spatial data collection. Use of photogrammetry in the fields of surveying, engineering, and geographic information management will be discussed.

Surveying.title: 3D Surveying and Modeling with Laser Scanner Data
Surveying.description: Theory and application of terrestrial LIDAR scanning. Typical application scenarios are also included. Intensive lab component provides hands-on experience in LIDAR point cloud processing and visualization.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Surveying.title: Land Subdivision Design
Surveying.description: Introduces aspects of land use within the framework of state and local regulations of land divisions for development. Additional topics include: legal principles, preparing land descriptions, state surveying laws, rules, ethics and professional conduct. Pre-Requisite(s): SU 3180 and (CMG 3200 or SU 3210)

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Junior, Senior

Surveying.title: Geospatial Monitoring of Engineering Structures and Geodynamic Processes
Surveying.description: Course comprises methods and applications of geospatial monitoring technologies. Typical application scenarios are presented in this course. Course has a number of labs which allow students to get a hands-on experience in processing and modeling monitoring data. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 334 Surveying Engineering, Geospatial Engineering Pre-Requisite(s): SU 2000 or SU 2050

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Integrated Geospatial Tech,

Surveying.title: R for Geosciences in Applied and Fundamental Tasks and Research
Surveying.description: R for Geosciences is intended to build up modern engineers and scientists and to get them acquainted with a powerful tool for the solution of miscellaneous applied statistical tasks in geosciences.

Surveying.title: Capstone Design Project
Surveying.description: An engineering design project which integrates multiple aspects of previous surveying coursework while working with an industry partner. Includes project description, project planning, field work, office analysis, computer-aided design, final project completion and oral presentation skills. Surveying Engineering; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Surveying.description: Selected additional topics of interest in Geospatial Technologies based on student and faculty demand and interest. May be a tutorial, seminar, workshop, project, or class study. Surveying Engineering; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Surveying.description: Independent study of an approved topic under the guidance of a Surveying Engineering faculty member. May be either an academic, design, or research problem/project. Surveying Engineering, Geospatial Engineering; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Senior

Surveying.description: An undergraduate research experience in Geospatial Technologies. May require more than one semester to complete. Surveying Engineering, Geospatial Engineering; Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 335 Senior

Surveying.description: A review of the elements of the NCEES Fundamentals of Surveying examination, utilizing on-line quizzes, as well as administering the Michigan Tech Surveying Engineering Exit Exam. Course taken in final semester only. Theatre

Theatre.title: Theatre Appreciation
Theatre.description: Students engage theatre as a phenomenon precipitating experiences affirming life and sparking insight. Exploration of creativity comes through exercises and play writing; critical thinking is practiced in script analysis. Aesthetics, and production roles are applied in staging a short play.

Theatre.title: Backstage Technology
Theatre.description: Overview of the basic techniques, theories, and terminology of technical theatre. Focus on practical application of stagecraft and rigging for a theatrical production, safety in technical theatre, physical theatre structures, production processes, and theatre organization.

Theatre.title: Lighting Technology
Theatre.description: Overview of the basics of theatrical lighting, stage electrics, and techniques for theatrical production. Focus on practical application of static and automated lighting for a theatrical production, including instrumentation and control.

Theatre.title: Costume Technology
Theatre.description: Introduction to basics of costume shop technology, costume construction/sewing. Focus on costume shop procedures, practical use of tools, machines, and techniques through individual projects and costuming for mainstage productions. Overview of hand sewing and pattern fitting/alteration.

Theatre.title: Voice and Articulation
Theatre.description: An applied study of the use of voice. Students work to develop stronger, more vibrant and articulate professional speech. Accent reduction is covered extensively. Additionally, techniques Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 336 for media are introduced.

Theatre.title: Beginning Acting
Theatre.description: Teaches basic techniques of acting to include script and character analysis, internal and external approaches to performance, and basic use of voice and body.

Theatre.title: Movement for Performers
Theatre.description: Develops physical flexibility and strength, beginning with discovery of the body's physical center. The student will learn to create characters by focusing on posture, movement in space, and kinesics.

Theatre.title: Beginning Acting Practicum
Theatre.description: Performance in a stage production or media project. The project must be approved by the instructor either through audition or written contract of panned project.

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Theatre.title: Readings in Dramatic Literature
Theatre.description: An examination of dramatic literature with an emphasis on theatre production. Students will examine a selection of plays each semester. Students can repeat the course up to four times; each semester examines different plays. Audio Production & Technology, Theatre & Entertain Tech (BS), Theater Arts, Theatre & Electr. Media Perf.; May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 4

Theatre.title: Intermediate Backstage Technology
Theatre.description: Focus on construction and the variable applications of stagecraft, rigging, and production processes with attention to safety and typical structures for the entertainment industry. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1701 or THEA 1110

Theatre.title: Stage Properties - Designing and Crafting
Theatre.description: Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 337 A focus on the design, research, production, and management of stage properties including: script, analysis, period and style, appropriateness, set dressing. Development and utilization of effective tools, materials, and techniques for structure, details, and finishing. Sec-Rec-Lab: (0-3-0) Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1701 or THEA 1110(C)

Theatre.title: Lighting II: Implementation
Theatre.description: A practical overview of the pre-production and technical process of installing and programming a lighting design. Pre-Requisite(s): THEA 1120

Theatre.description: Research and exploration of the theatrical techniques used to create costume crafts and personal props. Practical projects will challenge students to develop skills in millinery, leatherwork, painting and dyeing, fabric manipulation, mask making, jewelry, and safe use of materials.

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Theatre.title: Drafting for the Entertainment Industry
Theatre.description: Introduction to hand drafting conventions and standards by the entertainment industry. Focus on technical and design techniques using CAD for views such as: ground plans, elevations, sections, detail drawings, orthographic projections, and scale perspective drawings.

Theatre.title: Stage Makeup
Theatre.description: A practical guide to the theory and practice of makeup for the stage. Students will study basic techniques including corrective, aging, character makeup, and special effects.

Theatre.title: Intermediate Acting
Theatre.description: Introduction to standard acting techniques and theories applied to scene study for theatre and media, building upon concentration skills, risk taking, and vulnerability. Pre-Requisite(s): THEA 1400 or FA 2600 Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 338

Theatre.title: Voice Acting Fundamentals
Theatre.description: Introduction to recording, editing and mixing audio and video for specific genres of voice acting and an exploration of hiring entities in the voice acting industry. Students will learn the basics of reading copy for various genres and how to find material for producing auditions. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2830 or THEA 1170) and (FA 2600 or THEA 1400) and (FA 1601 or SND 1102)

Theatre.description: Performance in a stage production or electronic media project. The project must be approved by the instructor either through audition or written contract of planned project. Pre-Requisite(s): THEA 1400 or THEA 1600

Theatre.description: Open to students selected for the crew of a mainstage theatre production sponsored by the Department of Visual and Performing Arts. Theatre.description: Provides students the opportunity to attend professional events which contribute to the development of their careers. Students will experience seminars, workshops, performance opportunities, competitions, and may perform services and interact with professionals at such events as KCACTF and USITT. (BS), Theatre & Electr. Media Perf., Audio Production & Technology

Theatre.description: Practical experience in theatre productions researching and analyzing scripts and relevant topics to enrich the theatrical experience for both producer and audience.

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 3

Theatre.title: Advanced Backstage Technology
Theatre.description: Techniques, theories, and terminology of technical theatre. Focus on application of advanced stagecraft through safety, woodworking, metalworking, budgeting, project management, and shop management. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 339 Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2701 or THEA 2310) and (FA 2706 or THEA 2110)

Theatre.title: Advanced Costume Construction
Theatre.description: Building on basic sewing skills and costume technology, students will explore fabrics and more advanced construction techniques: patterning methods such as flat patterning, draping, gridding, pattern alterations for fit and using slopers, construction of historical costumes such as corsets. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1703

Theatre.title: Acting with an Accent
Theatre.description: An exploration of the most popular dialects used in the entertainment industry. Co-Requisite(s): THEA 1170 Pre-Requisite(s): THEA 1170 or FA 2830

Theatre.description: Study of the Cultural History of Theatre from is likely beginnings through the English Restoration, including traditions of both eastern and western theatre. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Theatre.title: Theatre History II
Theatre.description: Study of the Cultural History of Theatre from the end of the English Restoration through the contemporary Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Theatre.title: Costume History
Theatre.description: A study of costume fashion, emphasis on the western world, from antiquity through the 20th Century. Including: basic characteristics of each period, environmental & cultural influences, specific costume terminology. Comparative analysis of historic costume choices found in film & theatre. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher) Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 340

Theatre.title: Lighting Design
Theatre.description: Fundamentals of designing theatrical lighting through various explorations and projects. Focus on professional design development and presentation techniques: theatrical drafting conventions, light sketches, plots. Also, designer/director relationships, script analysis, research, design concepts/history. Students are introduced to a mainstage theatre design. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1702 or FA 2820 or THEA 1000 or THEA 1120

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Theatre.title: Costume Design
Theatre.description: Fundamentals of designing theatrical costumes through various explorations and projects. Focus on professional design development and presentation techniques: costume renderings, patterning, color/fabric analysis. Also, designer/director relationships, script/character analyses, research, design concepts. Students are introduced to a mainstage theatre design. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Theatre.title: Scenic Design
Theatre.description: An introduction to scenic design for theatre and collaborative design in entertainment. This project- based class develops technical and conceptual skills: collaborative relationships, design development, story boards, rendering paint elevations, model making, hand drafting. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1701 or FA 2820 or THEA 1000 or THEA 1110

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Theatre.title: Advanced Acting
Theatre.description: Students explore acting through analytical and theoretical study of script and characters. Understanding of characters in the context of a play or or film will prepare students to apply advanced acting techniques such as Meisner and Stanislavski. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2600 or THEA 1400) and UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Theatre.title: Acting for Television and Film
Theatre.description: Advanced applications of fundamental acting technique and presentation skills with the added dynamic Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 341 of the camera. Students will explore scene work for television and film, as well as commercial performance techniques for advertising in digital media. Pre-Requisite(s): THEA 2400(C)

Theatre.title: Voice Acting Styles
Theatre.description: Performance techniques for the various genres of voice acting including video games, audiobooks, technical narration, commercials, animated videos and radio dramas. Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 1601 or SND 1102) and (FA 2830 or THEA 1170) and (FA 2600 or THEA 1400) and THEA 2470

Theatre.title: Vocal Approaches for Theatre and Electronic Media
Theatre.description: Students will learn vocal approaches to specific types of speaking situations, including radio commercials, instructional videos, announcing, cartoons, and theatrical productions. Students will practice vocal projection for a large theatre/auditorium, as well as microphone technique for electronic media.

Theatre.title: Puppet Construction and Manipulation
Theatre.description: Exploration and analysis of design principles for puppetry, introduction to construction and manipulation methods in shadow puppets, foam-based puppets, and rod puppets. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Theatre.title: Advanced Acting Practicum for Film/Video/Stage
Theatre.description: Practical experience of the production processes of theatre and media. Students will research, rehearse, and perform a role in an approved theatre or media project. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2660 or THEA 2600

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 2
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Theatre.title: Audition Techniques
Theatre.description: Students learn to prepare for the many types of auditions encountered in the professional world of performance through simulated audition situations, from the theatrical cattle-call to the screen test in film. Additionally, professional interviewing techniques are taught and practiced through simulation. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 342 Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2600 or THEA 1400) and THEA 1600 and THEA 2400

Theatre.title: Portfolio Development
Theatre.description: Techniques for building a professional design and technical portfolio for the theatre and entertainment industry. The final result of the course will be a portfolio of all work to date.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman, Sophomore

Theatre.title: Stage Management
Theatre.description: Procedures and skills for effective stage management of theatrical productions, including coordination of performers and technicians during rehearsal and performance periods. Instruction in stage manager's notation used for blocking, scene shifts, and cues for lighting, sound, special effects, and performers.

tags.Restrictions: May not be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

Theatre.title: Design & Management Practicum
Theatre.description: Open to students who take significant responsibility for a Visual and Performing Arts production, such as stage manager, assistant designer, or assistant director. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 2661 or THEA 2610

tags.Credits: 2.0; May be repeated
tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Theatre.title: Professional Presentation
Theatre.description: Provides students the opportunity to present at professional events which contribute to the development of their careers. Students will prepare and present design, technical, or performance projects, papers, and/or posters to be viewed and critiqued by professionals at such events as KCACTF, AES, USITT, and URTA. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 3700 or FA 3730 or FA 3750 or FA 3760 or FA 3650 or FA 2640 or FA 2730 or FA 2705 or THEA 3340(C) or SND 3330(C) or THEA 3320(C) or THEA 3330(C) or THEA 3660(C) or THEA 2330(C) or THEA 2130(C) or THEA 2111(C)

tags.Credits: 1.0; Repeatable to a Max of 4

Theatre.description: The objective of this course is to provide experience for performers to engage in auditioning for Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 343 professional media and theatre companies. Theatre.description: Special workshop projects in the visual and performing arts.

Theatre.title: Stage Mechanics and Rigging
Theatre.description: Practical application and theory of stage mechanics and rigging. Emphasis will be placed on theatrical systems such as line-sets, turntables, and scenery lifts. Course will also explore automation through pneumatics, hydraulics, and motor control. Pre-Requisite(s): FA 1701 or THEA 1110

Theatre.title: Directing for Theatre
Theatre.description: A comprehensive, in-depth study of mounting a theatre production with an emphasis on directing. Through script analysis, students study the necessary production elements, how they interrelate, and directing techniques to create a unified production from the director's vision.

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

Theatre.title: Period Acting Styles
Theatre.description: Provides knowledge and experience in playing the manners, movement, and language in plays of the most frequently performed periods. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 344 Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2820 or THEA 1000) and (FA 2600 or THEA 1400) and THEA 2400 and (FA 3600 or THEA 3400(C))

Theatre.title: Musical Theatre Performance
Theatre.description: Provides specialized experience in performance styles of the musical theatre through scene-study and process from sheet music to the stage. Pre-Requisite(s): UN 1015 and (UN 1025 or Modern Language - 3000 level or higher)

Theatre.title: Voice Acting Lessons
Theatre.description: Private intensive in voice acting focusing on one specific genre (i.e. audio book narration, radio/television commercials, animated videos, technical narration, IVR messaging, etc.) Course covers basic skills for chosen genre and includes private coaching with the instructor as well as an industry professional. be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman Pre-Requisite(s): (FA 2830 or THEA 1170) and THEA 1400 and (THEA 2470 or THEA 3480(C) or THEA 3470(C))

Theatre.description: Focus on techniques to coordinate production and artistic operations for the theatre and entertainment industries and venues.
