Theatre.description: Independent research directed by Visual and Performing Arts faculty. Projects focus on one or more of the visual and performing genres; theatre, music, visual art. Theatre.description: Capstone course extending the student's knowledge and skill in a chosen fine arts discipline through independent research or other focused creative activity. University Wide.title: Effective Scholarship
University Wide.description: Course meets federal requirements for responsible conduct of research training for graduate students. Students who pass the course will be awarded a certificate of completion.

University Wide.title: Frameworks for Success for ExSEL
University Wide.description: Course that explores ways to become a more effective student. The course focuses on metacognition and individual learning styles, the skills and habits that support academic success, and utilizing campus resources. Counts as a free elective.

University Wide.title: Initiatives for Success
University Wide.description: Course that explores ways to become a more effective student. The course focuses on metacognition and individual learning styles, the skills and habits that support academic success, and utilizing campus resources. This course includes a mandatory learning center appointment assigned upon registration. Course counts as a free elective. Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 346

University Wide.title: Creating Your Success for Themed Communities
University Wide.description: First year seminar course that develops community among members of residential themed communities and provides an introduction for creating academic, professional, and personal success. This course is required for all first-year and transfer (with less than 30 credits) students living in a residential themed community. Course counts as a free elective.

University Wide.title: Strategies for Success
University Wide.description: Seminar course that provides a framework to assess the strategies a student is currently using to achieve academic, professional, and personal success. The course is designed to look at ways to improve upon a student's strategies for success or adopt new ones. This course is required for all first- year or transfer (with less than 30 credits) students who are on academic probation for the first time after fall or spring of their first year. This course is also available with permission from the Dean of Students, to any student who feels they would benefit from additional strategies for success. Course counts as a free elective.

University Wide.title: Composition
University Wide.description: Provides direct instruction in composition. Students examine and interpret communication practices and apply what they learn to their own written, aural, and visual compositions. Class projects ask students to communicate in a variety of modes and to attend to audience, purpose, and context.

tags.Restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Class(es): Freshman

University Wide.title: Husky Connect Success 101
University Wide.description: This course is designed to aid students in their transition from high school to college by introducing academic strategies and resources. Subjects will focus on successful transition from dependent to independent learning, time prioritization, major and career planning, academic integrity, leadership, and diversity.

tags.Restrictions: Permission of instructor required

University Wide.title: Global Issues
University Wide.description: Study of contemporary global issues, their origins, impacts, and solutions through the thematic and comparative exploration of worldview and culture, population, globalization, development, politics and global governance, environment, and sustainability. Emphasis on global literacy and information Undergraduate Course Descriptions Effective Fall 2023, Page 347 literacy.

University Wide.title: Fundamentals of Nanoscale Science and Engineering
University Wide.description: Team-taught introduction to the fundamentals of nanotechnology, emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of this field. Modern instrumentation, key scientific foundations, and current and potential applications will be discussed. Real and potential societal implications of nanotechnology will be explored.
